dialogue: “The mater will be delighted to see you again—after all those years,”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “Your mother keeps well?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Oh, yes. I suppose you know that she has married again?”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “Rotten little bounder too!”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “I can tell you, Hastings, it’s making life jolly difficult for us. As for Evie—you remember Evie?”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “No.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Oh, I suppose she was after your time. She’s the mater’s factotum, companion, Jack of all trades! A great sport—old Evie! Not precisely young and beautiful, but as game as they make them.”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “You were going to say——?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Oh, this fellow! He turned up from nowhere, on the pretext of being a second cousin or something of Evie’s, though she didn’t seem particularly keen to acknowledge the relationship. The fellow is an absolute outsider, anyone can see that. He’s got a great black beard, and wears patent leather boots in all weathers! But the mater cottoned to him at once, took him on as secretary—you know how she’s always running a hundred societies?”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “Well, of course the war has turned the hundreds into thousands. No doubt the fellow was very useful to her. But you could have knocked us all down with a feather when, three months ago, she suddenly announced that she and Alfred were engaged! The fellow must be at least twenty years younger than she is! It’s simply bare-faced fortune hunting; but there you are—she is her own mistress, and she’s married him.”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “It must be a difficult situation for you all.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Difficult! It’s damnable!”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “Got a drop or two of petrol still, you see,”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “Mainly owing to the mater’s activities.”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “I’m afraid you’ll find it very quiet down here, Hastings.”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “My dear fellow, that’s just what I want.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Oh, it’s pleasant enough if you want to lead the idle life. I drill with the volunteers twice a week, and lend a hand at the farms. My wife works regularly ‘on the land’. She is up at five every morning to milk, and keeps at it steadily until lunchtime. It’s a jolly good life taking it all round—if it weren’t for that fellow Alfred Inglethorp!”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “I wonder if we’ve time to pick up Cynthia. No, she’ll have started from the hospital by now.”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “Cynthia! That’s not your wife?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “No, Cynthia is a protégée of my mother’s, the daughter of an old schoolfellow of hers, who married a rascally solicitor. He came a cropper, and the girl was left an orphan and penniless. My mother came to the rescue, and Cynthia has been with us nearly two years now. She works in the Red Cross Hospital at Tadminster, seven miles away.”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “Hullo, Evie, here’s our wounded hero! Mr. Hastings—Miss Howard.”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “Hullo, Evie, here’s our wounded hero! Mr. Hastings—Miss Howard.”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “Weeds grow like house afire. Can’t keep even with ’em. Shall press you in. Better be careful.”
speaker: Evelyn Howard

dialogue: “Weeds grow like house afire. Can’t keep even with ’em. Shall press you in. Better be careful.”
speaker: Evelyn Howard

dialogue: “I’m sure I shall be only too delighted to make myself useful,”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Don’t say it. Never does. Wish you hadn’t later.”
speaker: Evelyn Howard

dialogue: “You’re a cynic, Evie,”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “Where’s tea to-day—inside or out?”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “Out. Too fine a day to be cooped up in the house.”
speaker: Evelyn Howard

dialogue: “Come on then, you’ve done enough gardening for to-day. ‘The labourer is worthy of his hire’, you know. Come and be refreshed.”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “Well,”
speaker: Evelyn Howard

dialogue: “I’m inclined to agree with you.”
speaker: Evelyn Howard

dialogue: “My wife, Hastings,”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “Then you’ll write to the Princess after tea, Alfred? I’ll write to Lady Tadminster for the second day, myself. Or shall we wait until we hear from the Princess? In case of a refusal, Lady Tadminster might open it the first day, and Mrs. Crosbie the second. Then there’s the Duchess—about the school fête.”
speaker: Emily Inglethorp

dialogue: “Yes, certainly. After tea will do quite well. You are so thoughtful, Alfred dear.”
speaker: Emily Inglethorp

dialogue: “Why, if it isn’t too delightful to see you again, Mr. Hastings, after all these years. Alfred, darling, Mr. Hastings—my husband.”
speaker: Emily Inglethorp

dialogue: “Why, if it isn’t too delightful to see you again, Mr. Hastings, after all these years. Alfred, darling, Mr. Hastings—my husband.”
speaker: Emily Inglethorp

dialogue: “This is a pleasure, Mr. Hastings.”
speaker: Alfred Inglethorp

dialogue: “Emily dearest, I think that cushion is a little damp.”
speaker: Alfred Inglethorp

dialogue: “Is soldiering your regular profession, Mr. Hastings?”
speaker: Alfred Inglethorp

dialogue: “No, before the war I was in Lloyd’s.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “And you will return there after it is over?”
speaker: Alfred Inglethorp

dialogue: “Perhaps. Either that or a fresh start altogether.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “What would you really choose as a profession, if you could just consult your inclination?”
speaker: Mary Cavendish

dialogue: “Well, that depends.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “No secret hobby?”
speaker: Mary Cavendish

dialogue: “Tell me—you’re drawn to something? Everyone is—usually something absurd.”
speaker: Mary Cavendish

dialogue: “You’ll laugh at me.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Perhaps.”
speaker: Mary Cavendish

dialogue: “Well, I’ve always had a secret hankering to be a detective!”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “The real thing—Scotland Yard? Or Sherlock Holmes?”
speaker: Mary Cavendish

dialogue: “Oh, Sherlock Holmes by all means. But really, seriously, I am awfully drawn to it. I came across a man in Belgium once, a very famous detective, and he quite inflamed me. He was a marvellous little fellow. He used to say that all good detective work was a mere matter of method. My system is based on his—though of course I have progressed rather further. He was a funny little man, a great dandy, but wonderfully clever.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Like a good detective story myself,”
speaker: Evelyn Howard

dialogue: “Lots of nonsense written, though. Criminal discovered in last chapter. Everyone dumbfounded. Real crime—you’d know at once.”
speaker: Evelyn Howard

dialogue: “There have been a great number of undiscovered crimes,”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Don’t mean the police, but the people that are right in it. The family. You couldn’t really hoodwink them. They’d know.”
speaker: Evelyn Howard

dialogue: “Then,”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “you think that if you were mixed up in a crime, say a murder, you’d be able to spot the murderer right off?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Of course I should. Mightn’t be able to prove it to a pack of lawyers. But I’m certain I’d know. I’d feel it in my fingertips if he came near me.”
speaker: Evelyn Howard

dialogue: “It might be a ‘she’,”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Might. But murder’s a violent crime. Associate it more with a man.”
speaker: Evelyn Howard

dialogue: “Not in a case of poisoning.”
speaker: Mary Cavendish

dialogue: “Dr. Bauerstein was saying yesterday that, owing to the general ignorance of the more uncommon poisons among the medical profession, there were probably countless cases of poisoning quite unsuspected.”
speaker: Mary Cavendish

dialogue: “Why, Mary, what a gruesome conversation!”
speaker: Emily Inglethorp

dialogue: “It makes me feel as if a goose were walking over my grave. Oh, there’s Cynthia!”
speaker: Emily Inglethorp

dialogue: “Why, Cynthia, you are late to-day. This is Mr. Hastings—Miss Murdoch.”
speaker: Emily Inglethorp

dialogue: “Sit down here on the grass, do. It’s ever so much nicer.”
speaker: Cynthia Murdoch

dialogue: “You work at Tadminster, don’t you, Miss Murdoch?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “For my sins.”
speaker: Cynthia Murdoch

dialogue: “Do they bully you, then?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “I should like to see them!”
speaker: Cynthia Murdoch

dialogue: “I have got a cousin who is nursing,”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “And she is terrified of ‘Sisters’.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “I don’t wonder. Sisters are, you know, Mr. Hastings. They simp-ly are! You’ve no idea! But I’m not a nurse, thank heaven, I work in the dispensary.”
speaker: Cynthia Murdoch

dialogue: “How many people do you poison?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Oh, hundreds!”
speaker: Cynthia Murdoch

dialogue: “Cynthia,”
speaker: Emily Inglethorp

dialogue: “do you think you could write a few notes for me?”
speaker: Emily Inglethorp

dialogue: “Certainly, Aunt Emily.”
speaker: Cynthia Murdoch

dialogue: “John will show you your room. Supper is at half-past seven. We have given up late dinner for some time now. Lady Tadminster, our Member’s wife—she was the late Lord Abbotsbury’s daughter—does the same. She agrees with me that one must set an example of economy. We are quite a war household; nothing is wasted here—every scrap of waste paper, even, is saved and sent away in sacks.”
speaker: Emily Inglethorp

dialogue: “Cynthia”
speaker: Emily Inglethorp

dialogue: “Look here, Mary, there’s the deuce of a mess. Evie’s had a row with Alfred Inglethorp, and she’s off.”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “Evie? Off?”
speaker: Mary Cavendish

dialogue: “Yes; you see she went to the mater, and—Oh,—here’s Evie herself.”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “At any rate,”
speaker: Evelyn Howard

dialogue: “I’ve spoken my mind!”
speaker: Evelyn Howard

dialogue: “My dear Evelyn,”
speaker: Mary Cavendish

dialogue: “this can’t be true!”
speaker: Mary Cavendish

dialogue: “True enough! Afraid I said some things to Emily she won’t forget or forgive in a hurry. Don’t mind if they’ve only sunk in a bit. Probably water off a duck’s back, though. I said right out: ‘You’re an old woman, Emily, and there’s no fool like an old fool. The man’s twenty years younger than you, and don’t you fool yourself as to what he married you for. Money! Well, don’t let him have too much of it. Farmer Raikes has got a very pretty young wife. Just ask your Alfred how much time he spends over there.’ She was very angry. Natural! I went on, ‘I’m going to warn you, whether you like it or not. That man would as soon murder you in your bed as look at you. He’s a bad lot. You can say what you like to me, but remember what I’ve told you. He’s a bad lot!’”
speaker: Evelyn Howard

dialogue: “What did she say?”
speaker: Mary Cavendish

dialogue: “‘Darling Alfred’—‘dearest Alfred’—‘wicked calumnies’ —‘wicked lies’—‘wicked woman’—to accuse her ‘dear husband!’ The sooner I left her house the better. So I’m off.”
speaker: Evelyn Howard

dialogue: “But not now?”
speaker: Mary Cavendish

dialogue: “This minute!”
speaker: Evelyn Howard

dialogue: “Mr. Hastings, you’re honest. I can trust you?”
speaker: Evelyn Howard

dialogue: “Look after her, Mr. Hastings. My poor Emily. They’re a lot of sharks—all of them. Oh, I know what I’m talking about. There isn’t one of them that’s not hard up and trying to get money out of her. I’ve protected her as much as I could. Now I’m out of the way, they’ll impose upon her.”
speaker: Evelyn Howard

dialogue: “Of course, Miss Howard,”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “I’ll do everything I can, but I’m sure you’re excited and overwrought.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Young man, trust me. I’ve lived in the world rather longer than you have. All I ask you is to keep your eyes open. You’ll see what I mean.”
speaker: Evelyn Howard

dialogue: “Above all, Mr. Hastings, watch that devil—her husband!”
speaker: Evelyn Howard

dialogue: “Who is that?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “That’s Dr. Bauerstein,”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “And who is Dr. Bauerstein?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “He’s staying in the village doing a rest cure, after a bad nervous breakdown. He’s a London specialist; a very clever man—one of the greatest living experts on poisons, I believe.”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “And he’s a great friend of Mary’s,”
speaker: Cynthia Murdoch

dialogue: “Come for a stroll, Hastings. This has been a most rotten business. She always had a rough tongue, but there is no stauncher friend in England than Evelyn Howard.”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “That’s a pretty girl,”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “That is Mrs. Raikes.”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “The one that Miss Howard——”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Exactly,”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “Styles is really a glorious old place,”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Yes, it’s a fine property. It’ll be mine some day—should be mine now by rights, if my father had only made a decent will. And then I shouldn’t be so damned hard up as I am now.”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “Hard up, are you?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “My dear Hastings, I don’t mind telling you that I’m at my wits’ end for money.”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “Couldn’t your brother help you?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Lawrence? He’s gone through every penny he ever had, publishing rotten verses in fancy bindings. No, we’re an impecunious lot. My mother’s always been awfully good to us, I must say. That is, up to now. Since her marriage, of course——”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “Such a charming invitation from Mrs. Rolleston. Lady Tadminster’s sister, you know. The Rollestons came over with the Conqueror—one of our oldest families.”
speaker: Emily Inglethorp

dialogue: “Nibs.”
speaker: Cynthia Murdoch

dialogue: “What a lot of bottles!”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Do you really know what’s in them all?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Say something original,”
speaker: Cynthia Murdoch

dialogue: “Every single person who comes up here says that. We are really thinking of bestowing a prize on the first individual who does not say: ‘What a lot of bottles!’ And I know the next thing you’re going to say is: ‘How many people have you poisoned?’”
speaker: Cynthia Murdoch

dialogue: “If you people only knew how fatally easy it is to poison someone by mistake, you wouldn’t joke about it. Come on, let’s have tea. We’ve got all sorts of secret stores in that cupboard. No, Lawrence—that’s the poison cupboard. The big cupboard—that’s right.”
speaker: Cynthia Murdoch

dialogue: “If you people only knew how fatally easy it is to poison someone by mistake, you wouldn’t joke about it. Come on, let’s have tea. We’ve got all sorts of secret stores in that cupboard. No, Lawrence—that’s the poison cupboard. The big cupboard—that’s right.”
speaker: Cynthia Murdoch

dialogue: “Come in,”
speaker: Cynthia Murdoch

dialogue: “I’m not really here to-day.”
speaker: Nibs

dialogue: “This should have been sent up this morning.”
speaker: Cynthia Murdoch

dialogue: “Sister is very sorry. She forgot.”
speaker: Nurse

dialogue: “Sister should read the rules outside the door.”
speaker: Cynthia Murdoch

dialogue: “So now it can’t be done until to-morrow,”
speaker: Cynthia Murdoch

dialogue: “Don’t you think you could possibly let us have it to-night?”
speaker: Nurse

dialogue: “Well,”
speaker: Cynthia Murdoch

dialogue: “we are very busy, but if we have time it shall be done.”
speaker: Cynthia Murdoch

dialogue: “Discipline must be maintained?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Exactly. Come out on our little balcony. You can see all the outside wards there.”
speaker: Cynthia Murdoch

dialogue: “Nothing more to do, Nibs?”
speaker: Cynthia Murdoch

dialogue: “No.”
speaker: Nibs

dialogue: “All right. Then we can lock up and go.”
speaker: Cynthia Murdoch

dialogue: “Mon ami Hastings!”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “It is indeed mon ami Hastings!”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Poirot!”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “This is a very pleasant meeting for me, Miss Cynthia. This is my old friend, Monsieur Poirot, whom I have not seen for years.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Oh, we know Monsieur Poirot,”
speaker: Cynthia Murdoch

dialogue: “But I had no idea he was a friend of yours.”
speaker: Cynthia Murdoch

dialogue: “Yes, indeed,”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “I know Mademoiselle Cynthia. It is by the charity of that good Mrs. Inglethorp that I am here.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Yes, my friend, she had kindly extended hospitality to seven of my countrypeople who, alas, are refugees from their native land. We Belgians will always remember her with gratitude.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “He’s a dear little man,”
speaker: Cynthia Murdoch

dialogue: “I’d no idea you knew him.”
speaker: Cynthia Murdoch

dialogue: “You’ve been entertaining a celebrity unawares,”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Oh, it’s you,”
speaker: Emily Inglethorp

dialogue: “Is there anything the matter, Aunt Emily?”
speaker: Cynthia Murdoch

dialogue: “Certainly not,”
speaker: Emily Inglethorp

dialogue: “What should there be?”
speaker: Emily Inglethorp

dialogue: “Yes, m’m.”
speaker: Dorcas

dialogue: “Don’t you think, m’m, you’d better get to bed? You’re looking very tired.”
speaker: Dorcas

dialogue: “Perhaps you’re right, Dorcas—yes—no—not now. I’ve some letters I must finish by post-time. Have you lighted the fire in my room as I told you?”
speaker: Emily Inglethorp

dialogue: “Yes, m’m.”
speaker: Dorcas

dialogue: “Then I’ll go to bed directly after supper.”
speaker: Emily Inglethorp

dialogue: “Goodness gracious! I wonder what’s up?”
speaker: Cynthia Murdoch

dialogue: “Had a good walk with Dr. Bauerstein?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “I didn’t go,”
speaker: Mary Cavendish

dialogue: “Where is Mrs. Inglethorp?”
speaker: Mary Cavendish

dialogue: “In the boudoir.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Then you won’t show it to me?”
speaker: Mary Cavendish

dialogue: “My dear Mary, it has nothing to do with that matter.”
speaker: Emily Inglethorp

dialogue: “Then show it to me.”
speaker: Mary Cavendish

dialogue: “I tell you it is not what you imagine. It does not concern you in the least.”
speaker: Emily Inglethorp

dialogue: “Of course, I might have known you would shield him.”
speaker: Mary Cavendish

dialogue: “I say! There’s been the most awful row! I’ve got it all out of Dorcas.”
speaker: Cynthia Murdoch

dialogue: “What kind of a row?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Between Aunt Emily and him. I do hope she’s found him out at last!”
speaker: Cynthia Murdoch

dialogue: “Was Dorcas there, then?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Of course not. She ‘happened to be near the door’. It was a real old bust-up. I do wish I knew what it was all about.”
speaker: Cynthia Murdoch

dialogue: “Aunt Emily will send him away, and will never speak to him again.”
speaker: Cynthia Murdoch

dialogue: “Send my coffee in here, Mary,”
speaker: Emily Inglethorp

dialogue: “I’ve just five minutes to catch the post.”
speaker: Emily Inglethorp

dialogue: “Do you young people want lights, or do you enjoy the twilight?”
speaker: Mary Cavendish

dialogue: “Do you young people want lights, or do you enjoy the twilight?”
speaker: Mary Cavendish

dialogue: “Will you take Mrs. Inglethorp her coffee, Cynthia? I will pour it out.”
speaker: Mary Cavendish

dialogue: “Do not trouble, Mary,”
speaker: Alfred Inglethorp

dialogue: “I will take it to Emily.”
speaker: Alfred Inglethorp

dialogue: “It’s almost too hot,”
speaker: Mary Cavendish

dialogue: “We shall have a thunderstorm.”
speaker: Mary Cavendish

dialogue: “It’s almost too hot,”
speaker: Mary Cavendish

dialogue: “We shall have a thunderstorm.”
speaker: Mary Cavendish

dialogue: “Dr. Bauerstein!”
speaker: Cynthia Murdoch

dialogue: “What a funny time to come.”
speaker: Cynthia Murdoch

dialogue: “What have you been doing, doctor?”
speaker: Mary Cavendish

dialogue: “I must make my apologies,”
speaker: Dr. Bauerstein

dialogue: “I did not really mean to come in, but Mr. Inglethorp insisted.”
speaker: Dr. Bauerstein

dialogue: “Well, Bauerstein, you are in a plight,”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “Have some coffee, and tell us what you have been up to.”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “Thank you, I will.”
speaker: Dr. Bauerstein

dialogue: “The sun soon dried me off,”
speaker: Dr. Bauerstein

dialogue: “but I’m afraid my appearance is very disreputable.”
speaker: Dr. Bauerstein

dialogue: “Just carry up my despatch-case, will you, dear? I’m going to bed.”
speaker: Emily Inglethorp

dialogue: “I’ll walk down to the village with you,”
speaker: Alfred Inglethorp

dialogue: “I must see our agent over those estate accounts.”
speaker: Alfred Inglethorp

dialogue: “No one need sit up. I will take the latch-key.”
speaker: Alfred Inglethorp

dialogue: “What’s the matter?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “We are afraid my mother is very ill. She seems to be having some kind of fit. Unfortunately she has locked herself in.”
speaker: Lawrence Cavendish

dialogue: “I’ll come at once.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “What do you think we had better do?”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “Try going through Mr. Inglethorp’s room, sir,”
speaker: Dorcas

dialogue: “Oh, the poor mistress!”
speaker: Dorcas

dialogue: “Oh, dear, sir,”
speaker: Dorcas

dialogue: “what ever shall we do?”
speaker: Dorcas

dialogue: “We must try and break the door in, I suppose. It’ll be a tough job, though. Here, let one of the maids go down and wake Baily and tell him to go for Dr. Wilkins at once. Now then, we’ll have a try at the door. Half a moment, though, isn’t there a door into Miss Cynthia’s rooms?”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “Yes, sir, but that’s always bolted. It’s never been undone.”
speaker: Dorcas

dialogue: “Well, we might just see.”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “No good. That’s bolted too. We must break in the door. I think this one is a shade less solid than the one in the passage.”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “No good. That’s bolted too. We must break in the door. I think this one is a shade less solid than the one in the passage.”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “Better now—very sudden—stupid of me—to lock myself in.”
speaker: Emily Inglethorp

dialogue: “Better now—very sudden—stupid of me—to lock myself in.”
speaker: Emily Inglethorp

dialogue: “Better now—very sudden—stupid of me—to lock myself in.”
speaker: Emily Inglethorp

dialogue: “Poor Cynthia is quite frightened,”
speaker: Mary Cavendish

dialogue: “Poor Cynthia is quite frightened,”
speaker: Mary Cavendish

dialogue: “Alfred—Alfred——”
speaker: Emily Inglethorp

dialogue: “Ve—ry sad. Ve—ry sad,”
speaker: Dr. Wilkins

dialogue: “Poor dear lady. Always did far too much—far too much—against my advice. I warned her. Her heart was far from strong. ‘Take it easy,’ I said to her, ‘Take—it—easy’. But no—her zeal for good works was too great. Nature rebelled. Na—ture—re—belled.”
speaker: Dr. Wilkins

dialogue: “The convulsions were of a peculiar violence, Dr. Wilkins. I am sorry you were not here in time to witness them. They were quite—tetanic in character.”
speaker: Dr. Bauerstein

dialogue: “Ah!”
speaker: Dr. Wilkins

dialogue: “I should like to speak to you in private,”
speaker: Dr. Bauerstein

dialogue: “You do not object?”
speaker: Dr. Bauerstein

dialogue: “Certainly not.”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “What is it? Why did Dr. Bauerstein seem so—peculiar?”
speaker: Mary Cavendish

dialogue: “Do you know what I think?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “What?”
speaker: Mary Cavendish

dialogue: “Listen!”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “I believe she has been poisoned! I’m certain Dr. Bauerstein suspects it.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “What?”
speaker: Mary Cavendish

dialogue: “No, no—not that—not that!”
speaker: Mary Cavendish

dialogue: “No, no—leave me. I’d rather be alone. Let me just be quiet for a minute or two. Go down to the others.”
speaker: Mary Cavendish

dialogue: “Where is Mr. Inglethorp?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Where is Mr. Inglethorp?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “He’s not in the house.”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “Mr. Cavendish, I should like your consent to a post-mortem.”
speaker: Dr. Wilkins

dialogue: “Is that necessary?”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “Absolutely,”
speaker: Dr. Bauerstein

dialogue: “You mean by that——?”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “That neither Dr. Wilkins nor myself could give a death certificate under the circumstances.”
speaker: Dr. Bauerstein

dialogue: “In that case, I have no alternative but to agree.”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “Thank you,”
speaker: Dr. Wilkins

dialogue: “We propose that it should take place to-morrow night—or rather to-night.”
speaker: Dr. Wilkins

dialogue: “Under the circumstances, I am afraid an inquest can hardly be avoided—these formalities are necessary, but I beg that you won’t distress yourselves.”
speaker: Dr. Wilkins

dialogue: “Under the circumstances, I am afraid an inquest can hardly be avoided—these formalities are necessary, but I beg that you won’t distress yourselves.”
speaker: Dr. Wilkins

speaker: Dr. Wilkins

dialogue: “Under the circumstances, I am afraid an inquest can hardly be avoided—these formalities are necessary, but I beg that you won’t distress yourselves.”
speaker: Dr. Wilkins

dialogue: “These are the keys of the two rooms. I have locked them and, in my opinion, they would be better kept locked for the present.”
speaker: Dr. Wilkins

dialogue: “John,”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “I am going to ask you something.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Well?”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “You remember my speaking of my friend Poirot? The Belgian who is here? He has been a most famous detective.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Yes.”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “I want you to let me call him in—to investigate this matter.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “What—now? Before the post-mortem?”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “Yes, time is an advantage if—if—there has been foul play.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Rubbish!”
speaker: Lawrence Cavendish

dialogue: “In my opinion the whole thing is a mare’s nest of Bauerstein’s! Wilkins hadn’t an idea of such a thing, until Bauerstein put it into his head. But, like all specialists, Bauerstein’s got a bee in his bonnet. Poisons are his hobby, so of course he sees them everywhere.”
speaker: Lawrence Cavendish

dialogue: “In my opinion the whole thing is a mare’s nest of Bauerstein’s! Wilkins hadn’t an idea of such a thing, until Bauerstein put it into his head. But, like all specialists, Bauerstein’s got a bee in his bonnet. Poisons are his hobby, so of course he sees them everywhere.”
speaker: Lawrence Cavendish

dialogue: “I can’t feel as you do, Lawrence,”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “I’m inclined to give Hastings a free hand, though I should prefer to wait a bit. We don’t want any unnecessary scandal.”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “I’m inclined to give Hastings a free hand, though I should prefer to wait a bit. We don’t want any unnecessary scandal.”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “No, no,”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “you need have no fear of that. Poirot is discretion itself.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Very well, then, have it your own way. I leave it in your hands. Though, if it is as we suspect, it seems a clear enough case. God forgive me if I am wronging him!”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “My God! This is terrible! My poor wife! I have only just heard.”
speaker: Alfred Inglethorp

dialogue: “Where have you been?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Denby kept me late last night. It was one o’clock before we’d finished. Then I found that I’d forgotten the latch-key after all. I didn’t want to arouse the household, so Denby gave me a bed.”
speaker: Alfred Inglethorp

dialogue: “How did you hear the news?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Wilkins knocked Denby up to tell him. My poor Emily! She was so self-sacrificing—such a noble character. She over-taxed her strength.”
speaker: Alfred Inglethorp

dialogue: “I must hurry on,”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Wait, my friend, I will let you in, and you shall recount to me the affair whilst I dress.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “The mind is confused? Is it not so? Take time, mon ami. You are agitated; you are excited—it is but natural. Presently, when we are calmer, we will arrange the facts, neatly, each in his proper place. We will examine—and reject. Those of importance we will put on one side; those of no importance, pouf!”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “blow them away!”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “That’s all very well,”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “but how are you going to decide what is important, and what isn’t? That always seems the difficulty to me.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Not so. Voyons! One fact leads to another—so we continue. Does the next fit in with that? A merveille! Good! We can proceed. This next little fact—no! Ah, that is curious! There is something missing—a link in the chain that is not there. We examine. We search. And that little curious fact, that possibly paltry little detail that will not tally, we put it here!”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “It is significant! It is tremendous!”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Ah!”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Beware! Peril to the detective who says: ‘It is so small—it does not matter. It will not agree. I will forget it.’ That way lies confusion! Everything matters.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “I know. You always told me that. That’s why I have gone into all the details of this thing whether they seemed to me relevant or not.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “And I am pleased with you. You have a good memory, and you have given me the facts faithfully. Of the order in which you present them, I say nothing—truly, it is deplorable! But I make allowances—you are upset. To that I attribute the circumstance that you have omitted one fact of paramount importance.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “What is that?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “You have not told me if Mrs. Inglethorp ate well last night.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “I don’t remember,”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “And, anyway, I don’t see——”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “You do not see? But it is of the first importance.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “I can’t see why,”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “As far as I can remember, she didn’t eat much. She was obviously upset, and it had taken her appetite away. That was only natural.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Yes,”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “it was only natural.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Now I am ready. We will proceed to the château, and study matters on the spot. Excuse me, mon ami, you dressed in haste, and your tie is on one side. Permit me.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Ça y est! Now, shall we start?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “So beautiful, so beautiful, and yet, the poor family, plunged in sorrow, prostrated with grief.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “No, you are right,”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “it is not as though there was a blood tie. She has been kind and generous to these Cavendishes, but she was not their own mother. Blood tells—always remember that—blood tells.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Poirot,”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “I wish you would tell me why you wanted to know if Mrs. Inglethorp ate well last night? I have been turning it over in my mind, but I can’t see how it has anything to do with the matter?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “I do not mind telling you—though, as you know, it is not my habit to explain until the end is reached. The present contention is that Mrs. Inglethorp died of strychnine poisoning, presumably administered in her coffee.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Yes?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Well, what time was the coffee served?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “About eight o’clock.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Therefore she drank it between then and half-past eight—certainly not much later. Well, strychnine is a fairly rapid poison. Its effects would be felt very soon, probably in about an hour. Yet, in Mrs. Inglethorp’s case, the symptoms do not manifest themselves until five o’clock the next morning: nine hours! But a heavy meal, taken at about the same time as the poison, might retard its effects, though hardly to that extent. Still, it is a possibility to be taken into account. But, according to you, she ate very little for supper, and yet the symptoms do not develop until early the next morning! Now that is a curious circumstance, my friend. Something may arise at the autopsy to explain it. In the meantime, remember it.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “This is a very dreadful business, Monsieur Poirot,”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “Hastings has explained to you that we are anxious for no publicity?”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “I comprehend perfectly.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “You see, it is only suspicion so far. We have nothing to go upon.”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “Precisely. It is a matter of precaution only.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “You know that fellow Inglethorp is back?”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “Yes. I met him.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “It’s jolly difficult to know how to treat him.”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “It’s jolly difficult to know how to treat him.”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “That difficulty will not exist long,”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Show Monsieur Poirot everything he wants to see.”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “The rooms are locked?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Dr. Bauerstein considered it advisable.”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “Then he is very sure. Well, that simplifies matters for us.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “What have you, my friend,”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “that you remain there like—how do you say it?—ah, yes, the stuck pig?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Foot-marks? But what an idea! There has already been practically an army in the room! What foot-marks are we likely to find? No, come here and aid me in my search. I will put down my little case until I need it.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Eh voilà une table!”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Ah, my friend, one may live in a big house and yet have no comfort.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Cocoa—with—I think—rum in it.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Ah, this is curious,”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “I must confess that I see nothing particularly curious about it.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “You do not? Observe the lamp—the chimney is broken in two places; they lie there as they fell. But see, the coffee-cup is absolutely smashed to powder.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Well,”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “I suppose someone must have stepped on it.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Exactly,”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Someone stepped on it.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Mon ami,”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “somebody stepped on that cup, grinding it to powder, and the reason they did so was either because it contained strychnine or—which is far more serious—because it did not contain strychnine!”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “I have no authority to go through these papers. But it should be done—at once!”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “We have found in this room,”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “six points of interest. Shall I enumerate them, or will you?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Oh, you,”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Very well, then. One, a coffee-cup that has been ground into powder; two, a despatch-case with a key in the lock; three, a stain on the floor.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “That may have been done some time ago,”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “No, for it is still perceptibly damp and smells of coffee. Four, a fragment of some dark green fabric—only a thread or two, but recognizable.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Ah!”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “That was what you sealed up in the envelope.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Yes. It may turn out to be a piece of one of Mrs. Inglethorp’s own dresses, and quite unimportant. We shall see. Five, this!”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “It must have been done since yesterday, otherwise a good housemaid would have at once removed it with blotting-paper and a hot iron. One of my best hats once—but that is not to the point.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “It was very likely done last night. We were very agitated. Or perhaps Mrs. Inglethorp herself dropped her candle.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “You brought only one candle into the room?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Yes. Lawrence Cavendish was carrying it. But he was very upset. He seemed to see something over here”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “that absolutely paralysed him.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “That is interesting,”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Yes, it is suggestive”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “but it was not his candle that made this great patch, for you perceive that this is white grease; whereas Monsieur Lawrence’s candle, which is still on the dressing-table, is pink. On the other hand, Mrs. Inglethorp had no candlestick in the room, only a reading-lamp.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Then,”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “what do you deduce?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “And the sixth point?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “I suppose it is the sample of cocoa.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “No,”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “I might have included that in the six, but I did not. No, the sixth point I will keep to myself for the present.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “There is nothing more to be done here, I think, unless”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “The fire burns—and it destroys. But by chance—there might be—let us see!”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “The forceps, Hastings!”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “There, mon ami!”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “What do you think of that?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Poirot!”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “This is a fragment of a will!”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Exactly.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “You are not surprised?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “No,”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “I expected it.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Now, my friend,”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “we will go. I should like to ask a few questions of the parlourmaid—Dorcas, her name is, is it not?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Poirot,”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “where are you?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “I am here, my friend.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Admirable!”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Admirable! What symmetry! Observe that crescent; and those diamonds—their neatness rejoices the eye. The spacing of the plants, also, is perfect. It has been recently done; is it not so?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Yes, I believe they were at it yesterday afternoon. But come in—Dorcas is here.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Eh bien, eh bien! Do not grudge me a moment’s satisfaction of the eye.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Yes, but this affair is more important.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “And how do you know that these fine begonias are not of equal importance?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “You do not agree? But such things have been. Well, we will come in and interview the brave Dorcas.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Pray be seated, mademoiselle.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Thank you, sir.”
speaker: Dorcas

dialogue: “You have been with your mistress many years, is it not so?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Ten years, sir.”
speaker: Dorcas

dialogue: “That is a long time, and very faithful service. You were much attached to her, were you not?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “She was a very good mistress to me, sir.”
speaker: Dorcas

dialogue: “Then you will not object to answering a few questions. I put them to you with Mr. Cavendish’s full approval.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Oh, certainly, sir.”
speaker: Dorcas

dialogue: “Then I will begin by asking you about the events of yesterday afternoon. Your mistress had a quarrel?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Yes, sir. But I don’t know that I ought——”
speaker: Dorcas

dialogue: “My good Dorcas, it is necessary that I should know every detail of that quarrel as fully as possible. Do not think that you are betraying your mistress’s secrets. Your mistress lies dead, and it is necessary that we should know all—if we are to avenge her. Nothing can bring her back to life, but we do hope, if there has been foul play, to bring the murderer to justice.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Amen to that,”
speaker: Dorcas

dialogue: “And, naming no names, there’s one in this house that none of us could ever abide! And an ill day it was when first he darkened the threshold.”
speaker: Dorcas

dialogue: “Now, as to this quarrel? What is the first you heard of it?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Well, sir, I happened to be going along the hall outside yesterday——”
speaker: Dorcas

dialogue: “What time was that?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “I couldn’t say exactly, sir, but it wasn’t tea-time by a long way. Perhaps four o’clock—or it may have been a bit later. Well, sir, as I said, I happened to be passing along, when I heard voices very loud and angry in here. I didn’t exactly mean to listen, but—well, there it is. I stopped. The door was shut, but the mistress was speaking very sharp and clear, and I heard what she said quite plainly. ‘You have lied to me, and deceived me,’ she said. I didn’t hear what Mr. Inglethorp replied. He spoke a good bit lower than she did—but she answered: ‘How dare you? I have kept you and clothed you and fed you! You owe everything to me! And this is how you repay me! By bringing disgrace upon our name!’ Again I didn’t hear what he said, but she went on: ‘Nothing that you can say will make any difference. I see my duty clearly. My mind is made up. You need not think that any fear of publicity, or scandal between husband and wife will deter me.’ Then I thought I heard them coming out, so I went off quickly.”
speaker: Dorcas

dialogue: “You are sure it was Mr. Inglethorp’s voice you heard?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Oh, yes, sir, whose else’s could it be?”
speaker: Dorcas

dialogue: “Well, what happened next?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Later, I came back to the hall; but it was all quiet. At five o’clock, Mrs. Inglethorp rang the bell and told me to bring her a cup of tea—nothing to eat—to the boudoir. She was looking dreadful—so white and upset. ‘Dorcas,’ she says, ‘I’ve had a great shock.’ ‘I’m sorry for that, m’m,’ I says. ‘You’ll feel better after a nice hot cup of tea, m’m.’ She had something in her hand. I don’t know if it was a letter, or just a piece of paper, but it had writing on it, and she kept staring at it, almost as if she couldn’t believe what was written there. She whispered to herself, as though she had forgotten I was there: ‘These few words—and everything’s changed.’ And then she says to me: ‘Never trust a man, Dorcas, they’re not worth it!’ I hurried off, and got her a good strong cup of tea, and she thanked me, and said she’d feel better when she’d drunk it. ‘I don’t know what to do,’ she says. ‘Scandal between husband and wife is a dreadful thing, Dorcas. I’d rather hush it up if I could.’ Mrs. Cavendish came in just then, so she didn’t say any more.”
speaker: Dorcas

dialogue: “She still had the letter, or whatever it was, in her hand?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Yes, sir.”
speaker: Dorcas

dialogue: “What would she be likely to do with it afterwards?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Well, I don’t know, sir, I expect she would lock it up in that purple case of hers.”
speaker: Dorcas

dialogue: “Is that where she usually kept important papers?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Yes, sir. She brought it down with her every morning, and took it up every night.”
speaker: Dorcas

dialogue: “When did she lose the key of it?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “She missed it yesterday at lunch-time, sir, and told me to look carefully for it. She was very much put out about it.”
speaker: Dorcas

dialogue: “But she had a duplicate key?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Oh, yes, sir.”
speaker: Dorcas

dialogue: “Never mind, Dorcas, it is my business to know things. Is this the key that was lost?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “That’s it, sir, right enough. But where did you find it? I looked everywhere for it.”
speaker: Dorcas

dialogue: “Ah, but you see it was not in the same place yesterday as it was to-day. Now, to pass to another subject, had your mistress a dark green dress in her wardrobe?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “No, sir.”
speaker: Dorcas

dialogue: “Are you quite sure?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Oh, yes, sir.”
speaker: Dorcas

dialogue: “Has anyone else in the house got a green dress?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Miss Cynthia has a green evening dress.”
speaker: Dorcas

dialogue: “Light or dark green?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “A light green, sir; a sort of chiffon, they call it.”
speaker: Dorcas

dialogue: “Ah, that is not what I want. And nobody else has anything green?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “No, sir—not that I know of.”
speaker: Dorcas

dialogue: “Good, we will leave that and pass on. Have you any reason to believe that your mistress was likely to take a sleeping powder last night?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Not last night, sir, I know she didn’t.”
speaker: Dorcas

dialogue: “Why do you know so positively?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Because the box was empty. She took the last one two days ago, and she didn’t have any more made up.”
speaker: Dorcas

dialogue: “You are quite sure of that?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Positive, sir.”
speaker: Dorcas

dialogue: “Then that is cleared up! By the way, your mistress didn’t ask you to sign any paper yesterday?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “To sign a paper? No, sir.”
speaker: Dorcas

dialogue: “When Mr. Hastings and Mr. Lawrence came in yesterday evening, they found your mistress busy writing letters. I suppose you can give me no idea to whom these letters were addressed?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “I’m afraid I couldn’t, sir. I was out in the evening. Perhaps Annie could tell you, though she’s a careless girl. Never cleared the coffee-cups away last night. That’s what happens when I’m not here to look after things.”
speaker: Dorcas

dialogue: “Since they have been left, Dorcas, leave them a little longer, I pray you. I should like to examine them.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Very well, sir.”
speaker: Dorcas

dialogue: “What time did you go out last evening?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “About six o’clock, sir.”
speaker: Dorcas

dialogue: “Thank you, Dorcas, that is all I have to ask you.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “I have been admiring these flower beds. How many gardeners are employed here, by the way?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Only three now, sir. Five, we had, before the war, when it was kept as a gentleman’s place should be. I wish you could have seen it then, sir. A fair sight it was. But now there’s only old Manning, and young William, and a new-fashioned woman gardener in breeches and such-like. Ah, these are dreadful times!”
speaker: Dorcas

dialogue: “The good times will come again, Dorcas. At least, we hope so. Now, will you send Annie to me here?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Yes, sir. Thank you, sir.”
speaker: Dorcas

dialogue: “How did you know that Mrs. Inglethorp took sleeping powders?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “And about the lost key and the duplicate?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “One thing at a time. As to the sleeping powders, I knew by this.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Where did you find it?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “In the wash-stand drawer in Mrs. Inglethorp’s bedroom. It was Number Six of my catalogue.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “But I suppose, as the last powder was taken two days ago, it is not of much importance?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Probably not, but do you notice anything that strikes you as peculiar about this box?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “No, I can’t say that I do.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Look at the label.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “‘One powder to be taken at bedtime, if required. Mrs. Inglethorp.’ No, I see nothing unusual.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Not the fact that there is no chemist’s name?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Ah!”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “To be sure, that is odd!”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Have you ever known a chemist to send out a box like that, without his printed name?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “No, I can’t say that I have.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Yet the explanation is quite simple. So do not intrigue yourself, my friend.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “I sent for you, Annie, because I thought you might be able to tell me something about the letters Mrs. Inglethorp wrote last night. How many were there? And can you tell me any of the names and addresses?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “There were four letters, sir. One was to Miss Howard, and one was to Mr. Wells, the lawyer, and the other two I don’t think I remember, sir—oh, yes, one was to Ross’s, the caterers in Tadminster. The other one, I don’t remember.”
speaker: Annie

dialogue: “Think,”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “I’m sorry, sir, but it’s clean gone. I don’t think I can have noticed it.”
speaker: Annie

dialogue: “It does not matter,”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Now I want to ask you about something else. There is a saucepan in Mrs. Inglethorp’s room with some cocoa in it. Did she have that every night?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Yes, sir, it was put in her room every evening, and she warmed it up in the night—whenever she fancied it.”
speaker: Annie

dialogue: “What was it? Plain cocoa?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Yes, sir, made with milk, with a teaspoonful of sugar, and two teaspoonfuls of rum in it.”
speaker: Annie

dialogue: “Who took it to her room?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “I did, sir.”
speaker: Annie

dialogue: “Always?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Yes, sir.”
speaker: Annie

dialogue: “At what time?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “When I went to draw the curtains, as a rule, sir.”
speaker: Annie

dialogue: “Did you bring it straight up from the kitchen then?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “No, sir, you see there’s not much room on the gas stove, so cook used to make it early, before putting the vegetables on for supper. Then I used to bring it up, and put it on the table by the swing door, and take it into her room later.”
speaker: Annie

dialogue: “The swing door is in the left wing, is it not?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Yes, sir.”
speaker: Annie

dialogue: “And the table, is it on this side of the door, or on the farther—servants’ side?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “It’s this side, sir.”
speaker: Annie

dialogue: “What time did you bring it up last night?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “About quarter-past seven, I should say, sir.”
speaker: Annie

dialogue: “And when did you take it into Mrs. Inglethorp’s room?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “When I went to shut up, sir. About eight o’clock. Mrs. Inglethorp came up to bed before I’d finished.”
speaker: Annie

dialogue: “Then, between seven-fifteen and eight o’clock, the cocoa was standing on the table in the left wing?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Yes, sir.”
speaker: Annie

dialogue: “And if there was salt in it, sir, it wasn’t me. I never took the salt near it.”
speaker: Annie

dialogue: “What makes you think there was salt in it?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Seeing it on the tray, sir.”
speaker: Annie

dialogue: “You saw some salt on the tray?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Yes. Coarse kitchen salt, it looked. I never noticed it when I took the tray up, but when I came to take it into the mistress’s room I saw it at once, and I suppose I ought to have taken it down again, and asked cook to make some fresh. But I was in a hurry, because Dorcas was out, and I thought maybe the cocoa itself was all right, and the salt had only gone on the tray. So I dusted it off with my apron, and took it in.”
speaker: Annie

dialogue: “When you went into Mrs. Inglethorp’s room, was the door leading into Miss Cynthia’s room bolted?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Oh! Yes, sir; it always was. It had never been opened.”
speaker: Annie

dialogue: “And the door into Mr. Inglethorp’s room? Did you notice if that was bolted too?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “I couldn’t rightly say, sir; it was shut but I couldn’t say whether it was bolted or not.”
speaker: Annie

dialogue: “When you finally left the room, did Mrs. Inglethorp bolt the door after you?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “No, sir, not then, but I expect she did later. She usually did lock it at night. The door into the passage, that is.”
speaker: Annie

dialogue: “Did you notice any candle grease on the floor when you did the room yesterday?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Candle grease? Oh, no, sir. Mrs. Inglethorp didn’t have a candle, only a reading-lamp.”
speaker: Annie

dialogue: “Then, if there had been a large patch of candle grease on the floor, you think you would have been sure to have seen it?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Yes, sir, and I would have taken it out with a piece of blotting-paper and a hot iron.”
speaker: Annie

dialogue: “Did your mistress ever have a green dress?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “No, sir.”
speaker: Annie

dialogue: “Nor a mantle, nor a cape, nor a—how do you call it?—a sports coat?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Not green, sir.”
speaker: Annie

dialogue: “Nor anyone else in the house?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “No, sir.”
speaker: Annie

dialogue: “You are sure of that?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Quite sure.”
speaker: Annie

dialogue: “Bien! That is all I want to know. Thank you very much.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Poirot,”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “I congratulate you! This is a great discovery.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “What is a great discovery?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Why, that it was the cocoa and not the coffee that was poisoned. That explains everything! Of course it did not take effect until the early morning, since the cocoa was only drunk in the middle of the night.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “So you think that the cocoa—mark well what I say, Hastings, the cocoa—contained strychnine?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Of course! That salt on the tray, what else could it have been?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “It might have been salt,”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “You are not pleased with me, mon ami?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “My dear Poirot,”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “it is not for me to dictate to you. You have a right to your own opinion, just as I have to mine.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “A most admirable sentiment,”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Now I have finished with this room. By the way, whose is the smaller desk in the corner?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Mr. Inglethorp’s.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Ah!”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Locked. But perhaps one of Mrs. Inglethorp’s keys would open it.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Voilà! It is not the key, but it will open it at a pinch.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Decidedly, he is a man of method, this Mr. Inglethorp!”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “There were no stamps in his desk, but there might have been, eh, mon ami? There might have been? Yes”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “this boudoir has nothing more to tell us. It did not yield much. Only this.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Where did you find this?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “In the waste-paper basket. You recognise the handwriting?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Yes, it is Mrs. Inglethorp’s. But what does it mean?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “I cannot say—but it is suggestive.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Come,”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “now to examine the coffee-cups!”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “My dear Poirot! What on earth is the good of that, now that we know about the cocoa?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Oh, là là! That miserable cocoa!”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “And, anyway,”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “as Mrs. Inglethorp took her coffee upstairs with her, I do not see what you expect to find, unless you consider it likely that we shall discover a packet of strychnine on the coffee tray!”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Come, come, my friend,”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Ne vous fâchez pas! Allow me to interest myself in my coffee-cups, and I will respect your cocoa. There! Is it a bargain?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “So Mrs. Cavendish stood by the tray—and poured out. Yes. Then she came across to the window where you sat with Mademoiselle Cynthia. Yes. Here are the three cups. And the cup on the mantelpiece, half drunk, that would be Mr. Lawrence Cavendish’s. And the one on the tray?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “John Cavendish’s. I saw him put it down there.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Good. One, two, three, four, five—but where, then, is the cup of Mr. Inglethorp?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “He does not take coffee.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Then all are accounted for. One moment, my friend.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Bien!”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “It is evident! I had an idea—but clearly I was mistaken. Yes, altogether I was mistaken. Yet it is strange. But no matter!”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Breakfast is ready,”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “You will breakfast with us, Monsieur Poirot?”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “May I ask how things are proceeding?”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “Do your investigations point to my mother having died a natural death—or—or must we prepare ourselves for the worst?”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “I think, Mr. Cavendish,”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “that you would do well not to buoy yourself up with any false hopes. Can you tell me the views of the other members of the family?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “My brother Lawrence is convinced that we are making a fuss over nothing. He says that everything points to its being a simple case of heart failure.”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “He does, does he? That is very interesting—very interesting,”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “And Mrs. Cavendish?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “I have not the least idea what my wife’s views on the subject are.”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “I told you, didn’t I, that Mr. Inglethorp has returned?”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “It’s an awkward position for all of us. Of course one has to treat him as usual—but, hang it all, one’s gorge does rise at sitting down to eat with a possible murderer!”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “I quite understand. It is a very difficult situation for you, Mr. Cavendish. I would like to ask you one question. Mr. Inglethorp’s reason for not returning last night was, I believe, that he had forgotten the latch-key. Is not that so?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Yes.”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “I suppose you are quite sure that the latch-key was forgotten—that he did not take it after all?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “I have no idea. I never thought of looking. We always keep it in the hall drawer. I’ll go and see if it’s there now.”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “No, no, Mr. Cavendish, it is too late now. I am certain that you would find it. If Mr. Inglethorp did take it, he has had ample time to replace it by now.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “But do you think——”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “I think nothing. If anyone had chanced to look this morning before his return, and seen it there, it would have been a valuable point in his favour. That is all.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Do not worry,”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “I assure you that you need not let it trouble you. Since you are so kind, let us go and have some breakfast.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Yes, I’ve got the most beastly headache.”
speaker: Cynthia Murdoch

dialogue: “Have another cup of coffee, mademoiselle?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “It will revive you. It is unparalleled for the mal de tête.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “No sugar,”
speaker: Cynthia Murdoch

dialogue: “No sugar? You abandon it in the war-time, eh?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “No, I never take it in coffee.”
speaker: Cynthia Murdoch

dialogue: “Sacré!”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Mr. Wells to see you, sir,”
speaker: Dorcas

dialogue: “Show him into my study.”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “My mother’s lawyer,”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “He is also Coroner—you understand. Perhaps you would like to come with me?”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “My mother’s lawyer,”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “He is also Coroner—you understand. Perhaps you would like to come with me?”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “There will be an inquest then?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “What is it? You are not attending to what I say.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “It is true, my friend. I am much worried.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Why?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Because Mademoiselle Cynthia does not take sugar in her coffee.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “What? You cannot be serious?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “But I am most serious. Ah, there is something there that I do not understand. My instinct was right.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “What instinct?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “The instinct that led me to insist on examining those coffee-cups. Chut! no more now!”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “You will understand, Wells,”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “that this is all strictly private. We are still hoping that there will turn out to be no need for investigation of any kind.”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “Quite so, quite so,”
speaker: Mr. Wells

dialogue: “I wish we could have spared you the pain and publicity of an inquest, but of course it’s quite unavoidable in the absence of a doctor’s certificate.”
speaker: Mr. Wells

dialogue: “Yes, I suppose so.”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “Clever man, Bauerstein. Great authority on toxicology, I believe.”
speaker: Mr. Wells

dialogue: “Indeed,”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “Shall we have to appear as witnesses—all of us, I mean?”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “You, of course—and ah—er—Mr.—er—Inglethorp.”
speaker: Mr. Wells

dialogue: “Any other evidence will be simply confirmatory, a mere matter of form.”
speaker: Mr. Wells

dialogue: “I see.”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “If you know of nothing to the contrary,”
speaker: Mr. Wells

dialogue: “I had thought of Friday. That will give us plenty of time for the doctor’s report. The post-mortem is to take place to-night, I believe?”
speaker: Mr. Wells

dialogue: “Yes.”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “Then that arrangement will suit you?”
speaker: Mr. Wells

dialogue: “Perfectly.”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “I need not tell you, my dear Cavendish, how distressed I am at this most tragic affair.”
speaker: Mr. Wells

dialogue: “Can you give us no help in solving it, monsieur?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Yes, we heard that Mrs. Inglethorp wrote to you last night. You should have received the letter this morning.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “I did, but it contains no information. It is merely a note asking me to call upon her this morning, as she wanted my advice on a matter of great importance.”
speaker: Mr. Wells

dialogue: “She gave you no hint as to what that matter might be?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Unfortunately, no.”
speaker: Mr. Wells

dialogue: “That is a pity,”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “A great pity,”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Mr. Wells, there is one thing I should like to ask you—that is, if it is not against professional etiquette. In the event of Mrs. Inglethorp’s death, who would inherit her money?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “The knowledge will be public property very soon, so if Mr. Cavendish does not object——”
speaker: Mr. Wells

dialogue: “Not at all,”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “I do not see any reason why I should not answer your question. By her last will, dated August of last year, after various unimportant legacies to servants, etc., she gave her entire fortune to her stepson, Mr. John Cavendish.”
speaker: Mr. Wells

dialogue: “Was not that—pardon the question, Mr. Cavendish—rather unfair to her other stepson, Mr. Lawrence Cavendish?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “No, I do not think so. You see, under the terms of their father’s will, while John inherited the property, Lawrence, at his stepmother’s death, would come into a considerable sum of money. Mrs. Inglethorp left her money to her elder stepson, knowing that he would have to keep up Styles. It was, to my mind, a very fair and equitable distribution.”
speaker: Mr. Wells

dialogue: “I see. But I am right in saying, am I not, that by your English law that will was automatically revoked when Mrs. Inglethorp remarried?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “As I was about to proceed, Monsieur Poirot, that document is now null and void.”
speaker: Mr. Wells

dialogue: “Hein!”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Was Mrs. Inglethorp herself aware of that fact?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “I do not know. She may have been.”
speaker: Mr. Wells

dialogue: “She was,”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “We were discussing the matter of wills being revoked by marriage only yesterday.”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “Ah! One more question, Mr. Wells. You say ‘her last will.’ Had Mrs. Inglethorp, then, made several former wills?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “On an average, she made a new will at least once a year,”
speaker: Mr. Wells

dialogue: “She was given to changing her mind as to her testamentary dispositions, now benefiting one, now another member of her family.”
speaker: Mr. Wells

dialogue: “Suppose,”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “that, unknown to you, she had made a new will in favour of someone who was not, in any sense of the word, a member of the family—we will say Miss Howard, for instance—would you be surprised?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Not in the least.”
speaker: Mr. Wells

dialogue: “Ah!”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Do you think Mrs. Inglethorp made a will leaving all her money to Miss Howard?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “No.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Then why did you ask?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Hush!”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Will you come with us, Monsieur Poirot? We are going through my mother’s papers. Mr. Inglethorp is quite willing to leave it entirely to Mr. Wells and myself.”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “Which simplifies matters very much,”
speaker: Mr. Wells

dialogue: “As technically, of course, he was entitled——”
speaker: Mr. Wells

dialogue: “We will look through the desk in the boudoir first,”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “and go up to her bedroom afterwards. She kept her most important papers in a purple despatch-case, which we must look through carefully.”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “Yes,”
speaker: Mr. Wells

dialogue: “it is quite possible that there may be a later will than the one in my possession.”
speaker: Mr. Wells

dialogue: “There is a later will.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “There is a later will.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “What?”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “What?”
speaker: Mr. Wells

dialogue: “Or, rather,”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “there was one.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Or, rather,”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “there was one.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “What do you mean—there was one? Where is it now?”
speaker: Mr. Wells

dialogue: “Burnt!”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Burnt?”
speaker: Mr. Wells

dialogue: “Yes. See here.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “But possibly this is an old will?”
speaker: Mr. Wells

dialogue: “I do not think so. In fact I am almost certain that it was made no earlier than yesterday afternoon.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “What?”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “Impossible!”
speaker: Mr. Wells

dialogue: “If you will allow me to send for your gardener, I will prove it to you.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Oh, of course—but I don’t see——”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “Do as I ask you. Afterwards you shall question as much as you please.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Very well.”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “Dorcas, will you tell Manning to come round and speak to me here.”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “Yes, sir.”
speaker: Dorcas

dialogue: “Come inside, Manning,”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “I want to speak to you.”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “Manning,”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “this gentleman will put some questions to you which I want you to answer.”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “Yessir,”
speaker: Manning

dialogue: “You were planting a bed of begonias round by the south side of the house yesterday afternoon, were you not, Manning?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Yes, sir, me and Willum.”
speaker: Manning

dialogue: “And Mrs. Inglethorp came to the window and called you, did she not?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Yes, sir, she did.”
speaker: Manning

dialogue: “Tell me in your own words exactly what happened after that.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Well, sir, nothing much. She just told Willum to go on his bicycle down to the village, and bring back a form of will, or such-like—I don’t know what exactly—she wrote it down for him.”
speaker: Manning

dialogue: “Well?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Well, he did, sir.”
speaker: Manning

dialogue: “And what happened next?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “We went on with the begonias, sir.”
speaker: Manning

dialogue: “Did not Mrs. Inglethorp call you again?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Yes, sir, both me and Willum, she called.”
speaker: Manning

dialogue: “And then?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “She made us come right in, and sign our names at the bottom of a long paper—under where she’d signed.”
speaker: Manning

dialogue: “Did you see anything of what was written above her signature?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “No, sir, there was a bit of blotting paper over that part.”
speaker: Manning

dialogue: “And you signed where she told you?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Yes, sir, first me and then Willum.”
speaker: Manning

dialogue: “What did she do with it afterwards?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Well, sir, she slipped it into a long envelope, and put it inside a sort of purple box that was standing on the desk.”
speaker: Manning

dialogue: “What time was it when she first called you?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “About four, I should say, sir.”
speaker: Manning

dialogue: “Not earlier? Couldn’t it have been about half-past three?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “No, I shouldn’t say so, sir. It would be more likely to be a bit after four—not before it.”
speaker: Manning

dialogue: “Thank you, Manning, that will do,”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Good heavens!”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “What an extraordinary coincidence.”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “How—a coincidence?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “That my mother should have made a will on the very day of her death!”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “Are you so sure it is a coincidence, Cavendish?”
speaker: Mr. Wells

dialogue: “What do you mean?”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “Your mother, you tell me, had a violent quarrel with—someone yesterday afternoon——”
speaker: Mr. Wells

dialogue: “What do you mean?”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “In consequence of that quarrel, your mother very suddenly and hurriedly makes a new will. The contents of that will we shall never know. She told no one of its provisions. This morning, no doubt, she would have consulted me on the subject—but she had no chance. The will disappears, and she takes its secret with her to her grave. Cavendish, I much fear there is no coincidence there. Monsieur Poirot, I am sure you agree with me that the facts are very suggestive.”
speaker: Mr. Wells

dialogue: “Suggestive, or not,”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “we are most grateful to Monsieur Poirot for elucidating the matter. But for him, we should never have known of this will. I suppose, I may not ask you, monsieur, what first led you to suspect the fact?”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “A scribbled over old envelope, and a freshly planted bed of begonias.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Evie!”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “Excuse me, Wells.”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “Miss Howard,”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Ah, I am glad she has come. There is a woman with a head and a heart too, Hastings. Though the good God gave her no beauty!”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Started the moment I got the wire. Just come off night duty. Hired car. Quickest way to get here.”
speaker: Evelyn Howard

dialogue: “Have you had anything to eat this morning, Evie?”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “No.”
speaker: Evelyn Howard

dialogue: “I thought not. Come along, breakfast’s not cleared away yet, and they’ll make you some fresh tea.”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “Look after her, Hastings, will you? Wells is waiting for me. Oh, here’s Monsieur Poirot. He’s helping us, you know, Evie.”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “What do you mean—helping us?”
speaker: Evelyn Howard

dialogue: “Helping us to investigate.”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “Nothing to investigate. Have they taken him to prison yet?”
speaker: Evelyn Howard

dialogue: “Taken who to prison?”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “Who? Alfred Inglethorp, of course!”
speaker: Evelyn Howard

dialogue: “My dear Evie, do be careful. Lawrence is of the opinion that my mother died from heart seizure.”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “More fool, Lawrence!”
speaker: Evelyn Howard

dialogue: “Of course Alfred Inglethorp murdered poor Emily—as I always told you he would.”
speaker: Evelyn Howard

dialogue: “My dear Evie, don’t shout so. Whatever we may think or suspect, it is better to say as little as possible for the present. The inquest isn’t until Friday.”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “Not until fiddlesticks!”
speaker: Evelyn Howard

dialogue: “You’re all off your heads. The man will be out of the country by then. If he’s any sense, he won’t stay here tamely and wait to be hanged.”
speaker: Evelyn Howard

dialogue: “I know what it is,”
speaker: Evelyn Howard

dialogue: “you’ve been listening to the doctors. Never should. What do they know? Nothing at all—or just enough to make them dangerous. I ought to know—my own father was a doctor. That little Wilkins is about the greatest fool that even I have ever seen. Heart seizure! Sort of thing he would say. Anyone with any sense could see at once that her husband had poisoned her. I always said he’d murder her in her bed, poor soul. Now he’s done it. And all you can do is to murmur silly things about ‘heart seizure’ and ‘inquest on Friday.’ You ought to be ashamed of yourself, John Cavendish.”
speaker: Evelyn Howard

dialogue: “What do you want me to do?”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “Dash it all, Evie, I can’t haul him down to the local police station by the scruff of his neck.”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “Well, you might do something. Find out how he did it. He’s a crafty beggar. Dare say he soaked fly papers. Ask cook if she’s missed any.”
speaker: Evelyn Howard

dialogue: “Mademoiselle,”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “I want to ask you something.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Ask away,”
speaker: Evelyn Howard

dialogue: “I want to be able to count upon your help.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “I’ll help you to hang Alfred with pleasure,”
speaker: Evelyn Howard

dialogue: “Hanging’s too good for him. Ought to be drawn and quartered, like in good old times.”
speaker: Evelyn Howard

dialogue: “We are at one then,”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “for I, too, want to hang the criminal.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Alfred Inglethorp?”
speaker: Evelyn Howard

dialogue: “Him, or another.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “No question of another. Poor Emily was never murdered until he came along. I don’t say she wasn’t surrounded by sharks—she was. But it was only her purse they were after. Her life was safe enough. But along comes Mr. Alfred Inglethorp—and within two months—hey presto!”
speaker: Evelyn Howard

dialogue: “Believe me, Miss Howard,”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “if Mr. Inglethorp is the man, he shall not escape me. On my honour, I will hang him as high as Haman!”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “That’s better,”
speaker: Evelyn Howard

dialogue: “But I must ask you to trust me. Now your help may be very valuable to me. I will tell you why. Because, in all this house of mourning, yours are the only eyes that have wept.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “If you mean that I was fond of her—yes, I was. You know, Emily was a selfish old woman in her way. She was very generous, but she always wanted a return. She never let people forget what she had done for them—and, that way she missed love. Don’t think she ever realized it, though, or felt the lack of it. Hope not, anyway. I was on a different footing. I took my stand from the first. ‘So many pounds a year I’m worth to you. Well and good. But not a penny piece besides—not a pair of gloves, nor a theatre ticket.’ She didn’t understand—was very offended sometimes. Said I was foolishly proud. It wasn’t that—but I couldn’t explain.
