Anyway, I kept my self-respect. And so, out of the whole bunch, I was the only one who could allow myself to be fond of her. I watched over her. I guarded her from the lot of them, and then a glib-tongued scoundrel comes along, and pooh! all my years of devotion go for nothing.”
speaker: Evelyn Howard

dialogue: “I understand, mademoiselle, I understand all you feel. It is most natural. You think that we are lukewarm—that we lack fire and energy—but trust me, it is not so.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Look here, what’s going to happen when these two meet?”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “I’ve told Mary to keep them apart if she can.”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “Will she be able to do so?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “The Lord only knows. There’s one thing, Inglethorp himself won’t be too keen on meeting her.”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “You’ve got the keys still, haven’t you, Poirot?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “My mother kept most of her important papers in this despatch-case, I believe,”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “My mother kept most of her important papers in this despatch-case, I believe,”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “My mother kept most of her important papers in this despatch-case, I believe,”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “Permit me. I locked it, out of precaution, this morning.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “But it’s not locked now.”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “Impossible!”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “See.”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “Milles tonnerres!”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “And I—who have both the keys in my pocket!”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Eh voilà une affaire! This lock has been forced.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “What?”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “But who forced it? Why should they? When? But the door was locked?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “But who forced it? Why should they? When? But the door was locked?”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “But who forced it? Why should they? When? But the door was locked?”
speaker: Mr. Wells

dialogue: “Who? That is the question. Why? Ah, if I only knew. When? Since I was here an hour ago. As to the door being locked, it is a very ordinary lock. Probably any other of the doorkeys in this passage would fit it.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “See here, it was like this,”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “There was something in that case—some piece of evidence, slight in itself perhaps, but still enough of a clue to connect the murderer with the crime. It was vital to him that it should be destroyed before it was discovered and its significance appreciated. Therefore, he took the risk, the great risk, of coming in here. Finding the case locked, he was obliged to force it, thus betraying his presence. For him to take that risk, it must have been something of great importance.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “See here, it was like this,”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “There was something in that case—some piece of evidence, slight in itself perhaps, but still enough of a clue to connect the murderer with the crime. It was vital to him that it should be destroyed before it was discovered and its significance appreciated. Therefore, he took the risk, the great risk, of coming in here. Finding the case locked, he was obliged to force it, thus betraying his presence. For him to take that risk, it must have been something of great importance.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “See here, it was like this,”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “There was something in that case—some piece of evidence, slight in itself perhaps, but still enough of a clue to connect the murderer with the crime. It was vital to him that it should be destroyed before it was discovered and its significance appreciated. Therefore, he took the risk, the great risk, of coming in here. Finding the case locked, he was obliged to force it, thus betraying his presence. For him to take that risk, it must have been something of great importance.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “But what was it?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Ah!”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “That, I do not know! A document of some kind, without doubt, possibly the scrap of paper Dorcas saw in her hand yesterday afternoon. And I—”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “miserable animal that I am! I guessed nothing! I have behaved like an imbecile! I should never have left that case here. I should have carried it away with me. Ah, triple pig! And now it is gone. It is destroyed—but is it destroyed? Is there not yet a chance—we must leave no stone unturned—”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “What has happened to your extraordinary little friend, Mr. Hastings? He has just rushed past me like a mad bull.”
speaker: Mary Cavendish

dialogue: “He’s rather upset about something,”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “They haven’t met yet, have they?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Who?”
speaker: Mary Cavendish

dialogue: “Mr. Inglethorp and Miss Howard.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Do you think it would be such a disaster if they did meet?”
speaker: Mary Cavendish

dialogue: “Well, don’t you?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “No.”
speaker: Mary Cavendish

dialogue: “I should like to see a good flare up. It would clear the air. At present we are all thinking so much, and saying so little.”
speaker: Mary Cavendish

dialogue: “John doesn’t think so,”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “He’s anxious to keep them apart.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Oh, John!”
speaker: Mary Cavendish

dialogue: “Old John’s an awfully good sort.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “You are loyal to your friend. I like you for that.”
speaker: Mary Cavendish

dialogue: “Aren’t you my friend too?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “I am a very bad friend.”
speaker: Mary Cavendish

dialogue: “Why do you say that?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Because it is true. I am charming to my friends one day, and forget all about them the next.”
speaker: Mary Cavendish

dialogue: “Yet you seem to be invariably charming to Dr. Bauerstein!”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “My dear fellow,”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “is this wise? Surely you don’t want the whole house to know of this occurrence? You are actually playing into the criminal’s hands.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “You think so, Hastings?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “I am sure of it.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Well, well, my friend, I will be guided by you.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Good. Although, unfortunately, it is a little too late now.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Sure.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Well,”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “let us go, mon ami.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “You have finished here?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “For the moment, yes. You will walk back with me to the village?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Willingly.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Excuse me, mademoiselle, one minute.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Yes?”
speaker: Cynthia Murdoch

dialogue: “Did you ever make up Mrs. Inglethorp’s medicines?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “No.”
speaker: Cynthia Murdoch

dialogue: “Only her powders?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Oh, yes, I did make up some sleeping powders for her once.”
speaker: Cynthia Murdoch

dialogue: “These?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Can you tell me what they were? Sulphonal? Veronal?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “No, they were bromide powders.”
speaker: Cynthia Murdoch

dialogue: “Ah! Thank you, mademoiselle; good morning.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “My friend,”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “I have a little idea, a very strange, and probably utterly impossible idea. And yet—it fits in.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “So that is the explanation of the blank label on the box,”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Very simple, as you said. I really wonder that I did not think of it myself.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “They have made one more discovery, là-bas,”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Mr. Wells told me as we were going upstairs.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “What was it?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Locked up in the desk in the boudoir, they found a will of Mrs. Inglethorp’s, dated before her marriage, leaving her fortune to Alfred Inglethorp. It must have been made just at the time they were engaged. It came quite as a surprise to Wells—and to John Cavendish also. It was written on one of those printed will forms, and witnessed by two of the servants—not Dorcas.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Did Mr. Inglethorp know of it?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “He says not.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “One might take that with a grain of salt,”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “All these wills are very confusing. Tell me, how did those scribbled words on the envelope help you to discover that a will was made yesterday afternoon?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Mon ami, have you ever, when writing a letter, been arrested by the fact that you did not know how to spell a certain word?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Yes, often. I suppose everyone has.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Exactly. And have you not, in such a case, tried the word once or twice on the edge of the blotting-paper, or a spare scrap of paper, to see if it looked right? Well, that is what Mrs. Inglethorp did. You will notice that the word ‘possessed’ is spelt first with one ‘s’ and subsequently with two—correctly. To make sure, she had further tried it in a sentence, thus: ‘I am possessed.’ Now, what did that tell me? It told me that Mrs. Inglethorp had been writing the word ‘possessed’ that afternoon, and, having the fragment of paper found in the grate fresh in my mind, the possibility of a will—(a document almost certain to contain that word)—occurred to me at once. This possibility was confirmed by a further circumstance. In the general confusion, the boudoir had not been swept that morning, and near the desk were several traces of brown mould and earth. The weather had been perfectly fine for some days, and no ordinary boots would have left such a heavy deposit.
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “I strolled to the window, and saw at once that the begonia beds had been newly planted. The mould in the beds was exactly similar to that on the floor of the boudoir, and also I learnt from you that they had been planted yesterday afternoon. I was now sure that one, or possibly both of the gardeners—for there were two sets of footprints in the bed—had entered the boudoir, for if Mrs. Inglethorp had merely wished to speak to them she would in all probability have stood at the window, and they would not have come into the room at all. I was now quite convinced that she had made a fresh will, and had called the two gardeners in to witness her signature. Events proved that I was right in my supposition.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “That was very ingenious,”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “I must confess that the conclusions I drew from those few scribbled words were quite erroneous.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “You gave too much rein to your imagination. Imagination is a good servant, and a bad master. The simplest explanation is always the most likely.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Another point—how did you know that the key of the despatch-case had been lost?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “I did not know it. It was a guess that turned out to be correct. You observed that it had a piece of twisted wire through the handle. That suggested to me at once that it had possibly been wrenched off a flimsy key-ring. Now, if it had been lost and recovered, Mrs. Inglethorp would at once have replaced it on her bunch; but on her bunch I found what was obviously the duplicate key, very new and bright, which led me to the hypothesis that somebody else had inserted the original key in the lock of the despatch-case.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Yes,”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Alfred Inglethorp, without doubt.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “You are very sure of his guilt?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Well, naturally. Every fresh circumstance seems to establish it more clearly.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “On the contrary,”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “there are several points in his favour.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Oh, come now!”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Yes.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “I see only one.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “And that?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “That he was not in the house last night.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “‘Bad shot!’ as you English say! You have chosen the one point that to my mind tells against him.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “How is that?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Because if Mr. Inglethorp knew that his wife would be poisoned last night, he would certainly have arranged to be away from the house. His excuse was an obviously trumped up one. That leaves us two possibilities: either he knew what was going to happen or he had a reason of his own for his absence.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “And that reason?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “How should I know? Discreditable, without doubt. This Mr. Inglethorp, I should say, is somewhat of a scoundrel—but that does not of necessity make him a murderer.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “We do not agree, eh?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Well, let us leave it. Time will show which of us is right. Now let us turn to other aspects of the case. What do you make of the fact that all the doors of the bedroom were bolted on the inside?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Well——”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “One must look at it logically.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “True.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “I should put it this way. The doors were bolted—our own eyes have told us that—yet the presence of the candle grease on the floor, and the destruction of the will, prove that during the night someone entered the room. You agree so far?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Perfectly. Put with admirable clearness. Proceed.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Well,”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “as the person who entered did not do so by the window, nor by miraculous means, it follows that the door must have been opened from inside by Mrs. Inglethorp herself. That strengthens the conviction that the person in question was her husband. She would naturally open the door to her own husband.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Why should she? She had bolted the door leading into his room—a most unusual proceeding on her part—she had had a most violent quarrel with him that very afternoon. No, he was the last person she would admit.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “But you agree with me that the door must have been opened by Mrs. Inglethorp herself?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “There is another possibility. She may have forgotten to bolt the door into the passage when she went to bed, and have got up later, towards morning, and bolted it then.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Poirot, is that seriously your opinion?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “No, I do not say it is so, but it might be. Now, to turn to another feature, what do you make of the scrap of conversation you overheard between Mrs. Cavendish and her mother-in-law?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “I had forgotten that,”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “That is as enigmatical as ever. It seems incredible that a woman like Mrs. Cavendish, proud and reticent to the last degree, should interfere so violently in what was certainly not her affair.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Precisely. It was an astonishing thing for a woman of her breeding to do.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “It is certainly curious,”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Still, it is unimportant, and need not be taken into account.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “What have I always told you? Everything must be taken into account. If the fact will not fit the theory—let the theory go.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Well, we shall see,”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Yes, we shall see.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Look, Poirot!”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Tiens!”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “It is Mr. Mace, from the chemist’s shop. He is coming here.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “A little minute,”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “I come.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Oh, Mr. Poirot, I’m sorry for the inconvenience, but I heard that you’d just come back from the Hall?”
speaker: Albert Mace

dialogue: “Yes, we have.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “It’s all over the village about old Mrs. Inglethorp dying so suddenly. They do say—”
speaker: Albert Mace

dialogue: “that it’s poison?”
speaker: Albert Mace

dialogue: “Only the doctors can tell us that, Mr. Mace.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Yes, exactly—of course——”
speaker: Albert Mace

dialogue: “Just tell me this, Mr. Poirot, it isn’t—it isn’t strychnine, is it?”
speaker: Albert Mace

dialogue: “Yes,”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “He will have evidence to give at the inquest.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Not now, not now, mon ami. I have need of reflection. My mind is in some disorder—which is not well.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “It is well. The bad moment has passed. Now all is arranged and classified. One must never permit confusion. The case is not clear yet—no. For it is of the most complicated! It puzzles me. Me, Hercule Poirot! There are two facts of significance.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “And what are they?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “The first is the state of the weather yesterday. That is very important.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “But it was a glorious day!”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Poirot, you’re pulling my leg!”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Not at all. The thermometer registered 80 degrees in the shade. Do not forget that, my friend. It is the key to the whole riddle!”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “And the second point?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “The important fact that Monsieur Inglethorp wears very peculiar clothes, has a black beard, and uses glasses.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Poirot, I cannot believe you are serious.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “I am absolutely serious, my friend.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “But this is childish!”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “No, it is very momentous.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “And supposing the Coroner’s jury returns a verdict of Wilful Murder against Alfred Inglethorp. What becomes of your theories, then?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “They would not be shaken because twelve stupid men had happened to make a mistake! But that will not occur. For one thing, a country jury is not anxious to take responsibility upon itself, and Mr. Inglethorp stands practically in the position of local squire. Also,”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “I should not allow it!”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “You would not allow it?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “No.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Oh, yes, mon ami, I would do what I say.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “In all this, you see, I think of that poor Mrs. Inglethorp who is dead. She was not extravagantly loved—no. But she was very good to us Belgians—I owe her a debt.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Let me tell you this, Hastings. She would never forgive me if I let Alfred Inglethorp, her husband, be arrested now—when a word from me could save him!”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “You’m from the Hall, bain’t you?”
speaker: Aged Rustic

dialogue: “Yes. I’m looking for a friend of mine whom I thought might have walked this way.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “A little chap? As waves his hands when he talks? One of them Belgies from the village?”
speaker: Aged Rustic

dialogue: “Yes,”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “He has been here, then?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Oh, ay, he’s been here, right enough. More’n once too. Friend of yours, is he? Ah, you gentlemen from the Hall—you’m a pretty lot!”
speaker: Aged Rustic

dialogue: “Why, do the gentlemen from the Hall come here often?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “One does, mister. Naming no names, mind. And a very liberal gentleman too! Oh, thank you, sir, I’m sure.”
speaker: Aged Rustic

dialogue: “Is it possible that she could have swallowed the poison by accident?”
speaker: Coroner

dialogue: “I should consider it very unlikely. Strychnine is not used for domestic purposes, as some poisons are, and there are restrictions placed on its sale.”
speaker: Dr. Bauerstein

dialogue: “Does anything in your examination lead you to determine how the poison was administered?”
speaker: Coroner

dialogue: “No.”
speaker: Dr. Bauerstein

dialogue: “You arrived at Styles before Dr. Wilkins, I believe?”
speaker: Coroner

dialogue: “That is so. The motor met me just outside the lodge gates, and I hurried there as fast as I could.”
speaker: Dr. Bauerstein

dialogue: “Will you relate to us exactly what happened next?”
speaker: Coroner

dialogue: “I entered Mrs. Inglethorp’s room. She was at that moment in a typical tetanic convulsion. She turned towards me, and gasped out: ‘Alfred—Alfred——’”
speaker: Dr. Bauerstein

dialogue: “Could the strychnine have been administered in Mrs. Inglethorp’s after-dinner coffee which was taken to her by her husband?”
speaker: Coroner

dialogue: “Possibly, but strychnine is a fairly rapid drug in its action. The symptoms appear from one to two hours after it has been swallowed. It is retarded under certain conditions, none of which, however, appear to have been present in this case. I presume Mrs. Inglethorp took the coffee after dinner about eight o’clock, whereas the symptoms did not manifest themselves until the early hours of the morning, which, on the face of it, points to the drug having been taken much later in the evening.”
speaker: Dr. Bauerstein

dialogue: “Mrs. Inglethorp was in the habit of drinking a cup of cocoa in the middle of the night. Could the strychnine have been administered in that?”
speaker: Coroner

dialogue: “No, I myself took a sample of the cocoa remaining in the saucepan and had it analysed. There was no strychnine present.”
speaker: Dr. Bauerstein

dialogue: “How did you know?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Listen.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “I should say”
speaker: Dr. Bauerstein

dialogue: “that I would have been considerably surprised at any other result.”
speaker: Dr. Bauerstein

dialogue: “Why?”
speaker: Coroner

dialogue: “Simply because strychnine has an unusually bitter taste. It can be detected in a solution of one in seventy thousand, and can only be disguised by some strongly flavoured substance. Cocoa would be quite powerless to mask it.”
speaker: Dr. Bauerstein

dialogue: “No. Coffee has a bitter taste of its own which would probably cover the taste of strychnine.”
speaker: Dr. Bauerstein

dialogue: “Then you consider it more likely that the drug was administered in the coffee, but that for some unknown reason its action was delayed.”
speaker: Coroner

dialogue: “Yes, but, the cup being completely smashed, there is no possibility of analyzing its contents.”
speaker: Dr. Bauerstein

dialogue: “I should like to make a suggestion if I may?”
speaker: Lawrence Cavendish

dialogue: “Certainly, Mr. Cavendish, we are here to arrive at the truth of this matter, and welcome anything that may lead to further elucidation.”
speaker: Coroner

dialogue: “It is just an idea of mine,”
speaker: Lawrence Cavendish

dialogue: “Of course I may be quite wrong, but it still seems to me that my mother’s death might be accounted for by natural means.”
speaker: Lawrence Cavendish

dialogue: “How do you make that out, Mr. Cavendish?”
speaker: Coroner

dialogue: “My mother, at the time of her death, and for some time before it, was taking a tonic containing strychnine.”
speaker: Lawrence Cavendish

dialogue: “Ah!”
speaker: Coroner

dialogue: “I believe,”
speaker: Lawrence Cavendish

dialogue: “that there have been cases where the cumulative effect of a drug, administered for some time, has ended by causing death. Also, is it not possible that she may have taken an overdose of her medicine by accident?”
speaker: Lawrence Cavendish

dialogue: “This is the first we have heard of the deceased taking strychnine at the time of her death. We are much obliged to you, Mr. Cavendish.”
speaker: Coroner

dialogue: “What Mr. Cavendish suggests is quite impossible. Any doctor would tell you the same. Strychnine is, in a certain sense, a cumulative poison, but it would be quite impossible for it to result in sudden death in this way. There would have to be a long period of chronic symptoms which would at once have attracted my attention. The whole thing is absurd.”
speaker: Dr. Wilkins

dialogue: “And the second suggestion? That Mrs. Inglethorp may have inadvertently taken an overdose?”
speaker: Coroner

dialogue: “Three, or even four doses, would not have resulted in death. Mrs. Inglethorp always had an extra large amount of medicine made up at a time, as she dealt with Coot’s, the Cash Chemists in Tadminster. She would have had to take very nearly the whole bottle to account for the amount of strychnine found at the post-mortem.”
speaker: Dr. Wilkins

dialogue: “Then you consider that we may dismiss the tonic as not being in any way instrumental in causing her death?”
speaker: Coroner

dialogue: “Certainly. The supposition is ridiculous.”
speaker: Dr. Wilkins

dialogue: “That, of course, is always possible,”
speaker: Dr. Wilkins

dialogue: “That would have been the table by the bed?”
speaker: Coroner

dialogue: “I opened my door,”
speaker: Mary Cavendish

dialogue: “and listened. In a few minutes a bell rang violently. Dorcas came running down and woke my husband, and we all went to my mother-in-law’s room, but it was locked——”
speaker: Mary Cavendish

dialogue: “I really do not think we need trouble you further on that point. We know all that can be known of the subsequent happenings. But I should be obliged if you would tell us all you overheard of the quarrel the day before.”
speaker: Coroner

dialogue: “Yes. I understand,”
speaker: Coroner

dialogue: “that you were sitting reading on the bench just outside the long window of the boudoir. That is so, is it not?”
speaker: Coroner

dialogue: “Yes, that is so.”
speaker: Mary Cavendish

dialogue: “And the boudoir window was open, was it not?”
speaker: Coroner

dialogue: “Yes.”
speaker: Mary Cavendish

dialogue: “Then you cannot have failed to hear the voices inside, especially as they were raised in anger. In fact, they would be more audible where you were than in the hall.”
speaker: Coroner

dialogue: “Possibly.”
speaker: Mary Cavendish

dialogue: “Will you repeat to us what you overheard of the quarrel?”
speaker: Coroner

dialogue: “I really do not remember hearing anything.”
speaker: Mary Cavendish

dialogue: “Do you mean to say you did not hear voices?”
speaker: Coroner

dialogue: “Oh, yes, I heard the voices, but I did not hear what they said.”
speaker: Mary Cavendish

dialogue: “I am not in the habit of listening to private conversations.”
speaker: Mary Cavendish

dialogue: “And you remember nothing at all? Nothing, Mrs. Cavendish? Not one stray word or phrase to make you realize that it was a private conversation?”
speaker: Coroner

dialogue: “Yes; I remember. Mrs. Inglethorp said something—I do not remember exactly what—about causing scandal between husband and wife.”
speaker: Mary Cavendish

dialogue: “Ah!”
speaker: Coroner

dialogue: “That corresponds with what Dorcas heard. But excuse me, Mrs. Cavendish, although you realized it was a private conversation, you did not move away? You remained where you were?”
speaker: Coroner

dialogue: “No. I was very comfortable where I was. I fixed my mind on my book.”
speaker: Mary Cavendish

dialogue: “And that is all you can tell us?”
speaker: Coroner

dialogue: “That is all.”
speaker: Mary Cavendish

dialogue: “You did not hear the table fall?”
speaker: Coroner

dialogue: “No. I was fast asleep.”
speaker: Cynthia Murdoch

dialogue: “A good conscience makes a sound sleeper,”
speaker: Coroner

dialogue: “Thank you, Miss Murdoch, that is all.”
speaker: Coroner

dialogue: “Miss Howard.”
speaker: Coroner

dialogue: “I fear it does not help us much,”
speaker: Coroner

dialogue: “There is no mention of any of the events of that afternoon.”
speaker: Coroner

dialogue: “Plain as a pikestaff to me,”
speaker: Evelyn Howard

dialogue: “It shows clearly enough that my poor old friend had just found out she’d been made a fool of!”
speaker: Evelyn Howard

dialogue: “It says nothing of the kind in the letter,”
speaker: Coroner

dialogue: “No, because Emily never could bear to put herself in the wrong. But I know her. She wanted me back. But she wasn’t going to own that I’d been right. She went round about. Most people do. Don’t believe in it myself.”
speaker: Evelyn Howard

dialogue: “Anyway, all this tomfoolery is a great waste of time,”
speaker: Evelyn Howard

dialogue: “Talk—talk—talk! When all the time we know perfectly well——”
speaker: Evelyn Howard

dialogue: “Thank you, Miss Howard, that is all.”
speaker: Coroner

dialogue: “Mr. Mace, have you lately sold strychnine to any unauthorized person?”
speaker: Coroner

dialogue: “Yes, sir.”
speaker: Albert Mace

dialogue: “When was this?”
speaker: Coroner

dialogue: “Last Monday night.”
speaker: Albert Mace

dialogue: “Monday? Not Tuesday?”
speaker: Coroner

dialogue: “No, sir, Monday, the 16th.”
speaker: Albert Mace

dialogue: “Will you tell us to whom you sold it?”
speaker: Coroner

dialogue: “Yes, sir. It was to Mr. Inglethorp.”
speaker: Albert Mace

dialogue: “You are sure of what you say?”
speaker: Coroner

dialogue: “Quite sure, sir.”
speaker: Albert Mace

dialogue: “Are you in the habit of selling strychnine indiscriminately over the counter?”
speaker: Coroner

dialogue: “Oh, no, sir—of course not. But, seeing it was Mr. Inglethorp of the Hall, I thought there was no harm in it. He said it was to poison a dog.”
speaker: Albert Mace

dialogue: “Is it not customary for anyone purchasing poison to sign a book?”
speaker: Coroner

dialogue: “Yes, sir, Mr. Inglethorp did so.”
speaker: Albert Mace

dialogue: “Have you got the book here?”
speaker: Coroner

dialogue: “Yes, sir.”
speaker: Albert Mace

dialogue: “On Monday evening last, did you purchase strychnine for the purpose of poisoning a dog?”
speaker: Coroner

dialogue: “No, I did not. There is no dog at Styles, except an outdoor sheepdog, which is in perfect health.”
speaker: Alfred Inglethorp

dialogue: “You deny absolutely having purchased strychnine from Albert Mace on Monday last?”
speaker: Coroner

dialogue: “I do.”
speaker: Alfred Inglethorp

dialogue: “Do you also deny this?”
speaker: Coroner

dialogue: “Certainly I do. The hand-writing is quite different from mine. I will show you.”
speaker: Alfred Inglethorp

dialogue: “Then what is your explanation of Mr. Mace’s statement?”
speaker: Coroner

dialogue: “Mr. Mace must have been mistaken.”
speaker: Alfred Inglethorp

dialogue: “Mr. Inglethorp, as a mere matter of form, would you mind telling us where you were on the evening of Monday, July 16th?”
speaker: Coroner

dialogue: “Really—I cannot remember.”
speaker: Alfred Inglethorp

dialogue: “That is absurd, Mr. Inglethorp,”
speaker: Coroner

dialogue: “Think again.”
speaker: Coroner

dialogue: “I cannot tell you. I have an idea that I was out walking.”
speaker: Alfred Inglethorp

dialogue: “In what direction?”
speaker: Coroner

dialogue: “I really can’t remember.”
speaker: Alfred Inglethorp

dialogue: “Were you in company with anyone?”
speaker: Coroner

dialogue: “No.”
speaker: Alfred Inglethorp

dialogue: “Did you meet anyone on your walk?”
speaker: Coroner

dialogue: “No.”
speaker: Alfred Inglethorp

dialogue: “That is a pity,”
speaker: Coroner

dialogue: “I am to take it then that you decline to say where you were at the time that Mr. Mace positively recognized you as entering the shop to purchase strychnine?”
speaker: Coroner

dialogue: “If you like to take it that way, yes.”
speaker: Alfred Inglethorp

dialogue: “Be careful, Mr. Inglethorp.”
speaker: Coroner

dialogue: “Sacré!”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Does this imbecile of a man want to be arrested?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “You had a discussion with your wife on Tuesday afternoon?”
speaker: Coroner

dialogue: “Pardon me,”
speaker: Alfred Inglethorp

dialogue: “you have been misinformed. I had no quarrel with my dear wife. The whole story is absolutely untrue. I was absent from the house the entire afternoon.”
speaker: Alfred Inglethorp

dialogue: “Have you anyone who can testify to that?”
speaker: Coroner

dialogue: “You have my word,”
speaker: Alfred Inglethorp

dialogue: “There are two witnesses who will swear to having heard your disagreement with Mrs. Inglethorp.”
speaker: Coroner

dialogue: “Those witnesses were mistaken.”
speaker: Alfred Inglethorp

dialogue: “Mr. Inglethorp,”
speaker: Coroner

dialogue: “you have heard your wife’s dying words repeated here. Can you explain them in any way?”
speaker: Coroner

dialogue: “Certainly I can.”
speaker: Alfred Inglethorp

dialogue: “You can?”
speaker: Coroner

dialogue: “It seems to me very simple. The room was dimly lighted. Dr. Bauerstein is much of my height and build, and, like me, wears a beard. In the dim light, and suffering as she was, my poor wife mistook him for me.”
speaker: Alfred Inglethorp

dialogue: “Ah!”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “But it is an idea, that!”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “You think it is true?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “I do not say that. But it is truly an ingenious supposition.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “You read my wife’s last words as an accusation”
speaker: Alfred Inglethorp

dialogue: “they were, on the contrary, an appeal to me.”
speaker: Alfred Inglethorp

dialogue: “I believe, Mr. Inglethorp, that you yourself poured out the coffee, and took it to your wife that evening?”
speaker: Coroner

dialogue: “I poured it out, yes. But I did not take it to her. I meant to do so, but I was told that a friend was at the hall door, so I laid down the coffee on the hall table. When I came through the hall again a few minutes later, it was gone.”
speaker: Alfred Inglethorp

dialogue: “Do you know who that little man is?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “That is Detective Inspector James Japp of Scotland Yard—Jimmy Japp. The other man is from Scotland Yard too. Things are moving quickly, my friend.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Wilful Murder against some person or persons unknown.”
speaker: Coroner

dialogue: “I fear you do not remember me, Inspector Japp.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Why, if it isn’t Mr. Poirot!”
speaker: Inspector Japp

dialogue: “You’ve heard me speak of Mr. Poirot? It was in 1904 he and I worked together—the Abercrombie forgery case—you remember, he was run down in Brussels. Ah, those were great days, moosier. Then, do you remember ‘Baron’ Altara? There was a pretty rogue for you! He eluded the clutches of half the police in Europe. But we nailed him in Antwerp—thanks to Mr. Poirot here.”
speaker: Inspector Japp

dialogue: “I need hardly ask what you are doing here, gentlemen,”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “I need hardly ask what you are doing here, gentlemen,”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “No, indeed. Pretty clear case I should say.”
speaker: Inspector Japp

dialogue: “There I differ from you.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Oh, come!”
speaker: Superintendent Summerhaye

dialogue: “Surely the whole thing is clear as daylight. The man’s caught red-handed. How he could be such a fool beats me!”
speaker: Superintendent Summerhaye

dialogue: “Hold your fire, Summerhaye,”
speaker: Inspector Japp

dialogue: “Me and Moosier here have met before—and there’s no man’s judgment I’d sooner take than his. If I’m not greatly mistaken, he’s got something up his sleeve. Isn’t that so, moosier?”
speaker: Inspector Japp

dialogue: “Me and Moosier here have met before—and there’s no man’s judgment I’d sooner take than his. If I’m not greatly mistaken, he’s got something up his sleeve. Isn’t that so, moosier?”
speaker: Inspector Japp

dialogue: “I have drawn certain conclusions—yes.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “It’s this way,”
speaker: Inspector Japp

dialogue: “so far, we’ve only seen the case from the outside. That’s where the Yard’s at a disadvantage in a case of this kind, where the murder’s only out, so to speak, after the inquest. A lot depends on being on the spot first thing, and that’s where Mr. Poirot’s had the start of us. We shouldn’t have been here as soon as this even, if it hadn’t been for the fact that there was a smart doctor on the spot, who gave us the tip through the Coroner. But you’ve been on the spot from the first, and you may have picked up some little hints. From the evidence at the inquest, Mr. Inglethorp murdered his wife as sure as I stand here, and if anyone but you hinted the contrary I’d laugh in his face. I must say I was surprised the jury didn’t bring it in Wilful Murder against him right off. I think they would have, if it hadn’t been for the Coroner—he seemed to be holding them back.”
speaker: Inspector Japp

dialogue: “Perhaps, though, you have a warrant for his arrest in your pocket now,”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Perhaps I have, and perhaps I haven’t,”
speaker: Inspector Japp

dialogue: “I am very anxious, Messieurs, that he should not be arrested.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “I am very anxious, Messieurs, that he should not be arrested.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “I dare say,”
speaker: Superintendent Summerhaye

dialogue: “Can’t you go a little further, Mr. Poirot? A wink’s as good as a nod—from you. You’ve been on the spot—and the Yard doesn’t want to make any mistakes, you know.”
speaker: Inspector Japp

dialogue: “That is exactly what I thought. Well, I will tell you this. Use your warrant: Arrest Mr. Inglethorp. But it will bring you no kudos—the case against him will be dismissed at once! Comme ça!”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “I daren’t do it, Mr. Poirot. I’d take your word, but there’s others over me who’ll be asking what the devil I mean by it. Can’t you give me a little more to go on?”
speaker: Inspector Japp

dialogue: “It can be done,”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “I admit I do not wish it. It forces my hand. I would have preferred to work in the dark just for the present, but what you say is very just—the word of a Belgian policeman, whose day is past, is not enough! And Alfred Inglethorp must not be arrested. That I have sworn, as my friend Hastings here knows. See, then, my good Japp, you go at once to Styles?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Well, in about half an hour. We’re seeing the Coroner and the doctor first.”
speaker: Inspector Japp

dialogue: “Good. Call for me in passing—the last house in the village. I will go with you. At Styles, Mr. Inglethorp will give you, or if he refuses—as is probable—I will give you such proofs that shall satisfy you that the case against him could not possibly be sustained. Is that a bargain?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “That’s a bargain,”
speaker: Inspector Japp

dialogue: “And, on behalf of the Yard, I’m much obliged to you, though I’m bound to confess I can’t at present see the faintest possible loop-hole in the evidence, but you always were a marvel! So long, then, moosier.”
speaker: Inspector Japp

dialogue: “Well, my friend,”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “what do you think? Mon Dieu! I had some warm moments in that court; I did not figure to myself that the man would be so pig-headed as to refuse to say anything at all. Decidedly, it was the policy of an imbecile.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “H’m! There are other explanations besides that of imbecility,”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “For, if the case against him is true, how could he defend himself except by silence?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Why, in a thousand ingenious ways,”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “See; say that it is I who have committed this murder, I can think of seven most plausible stories! Far more convincing than Mr. Inglethorp’s stony denials!”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “My dear Poirot, I am sure you are capable of thinking of seventy! But, seriously, in spite of what I heard you say to the detectives, you surely cannot still believe in the possibility of Alfred Inglethorp’s innocence?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Why not now as much as before? Nothing has changed.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “But the evidence is so conclusive.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Yes, too conclusive.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Yes, yes, too conclusive,”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Real evidence is usually vague and unsatisfactory. It has to be examined—sifted. But here the whole thing is cut and dried. No, my friend, this evidence has been very cleverly manufactured—so cleverly that it has defeated its own ends.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “How do you make that out?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Because, so long as the evidence against him was vague and intangible, it was very hard to disprove. But, in his anxiety, the criminal has drawn the net so closely that one cut will set Inglethorp free.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Let us look at the matter like this. Here is a man, let us say, who sets out to poison his wife. He has lived by his wits as the saying goes. Presumably, therefore, he has some wits. He is not altogether a fool. Well, how does he set about it? He goes boldly to the village chemist’s and purchases strychnine under his own name, with a trumped up story about a dog which is bound to be proved absurd. He does not employ the poison that night. No, he waits until he has had a violent quarrel with her, of which the whole household is cognisant, and which naturally directs their suspicions upon him. He prepares no defence—no shadow of an alibi, yet he knows the chemist’s assistant must necessarily come forward with the facts. Bah! Do not ask me to believe that any man could be so idiotic! Only a lunatic, who wished to commit suicide by causing himself to be hanged, would act so!”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Still—I do not see——”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Neither do I see. I tell you, mon ami, it puzzles me. Me—Hercule Poirot!”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “But if you believe him innocent, how do you explain his buying the strychnine?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Very simply. He did not buy it.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “But Mace recognized him!”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “I beg your pardon, he saw a man with a black beard like Mr. Inglethorp’s, and wearing glasses like Mr. Inglethorp, and dressed in Mr. Inglethorp’s rather noticeable clothes. He could not recognize a man whom he had probably only seen in the distance, since, you remember, he himself had only been in the village a fortnight, and Mrs. Inglethorp dealt principally with Coot’s in Tadminster.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Then you think——”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Mon ami, do you remember the two points I laid stress upon? Leave the first one for the moment, what was the second?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “The important fact that Alfred Inglethorp wears peculiar clothes, has a black beard, and uses glasses,”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Exactly. Now suppose anyone wished to pass himself off as John or Lawrence Cavendish. Would it be easy?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “No,”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Of course an actor——”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “And why would it not be easy? I will tell you, my friend: Because they are both clean-shaven men. To make up successfully as one of these two in broad daylight, it would need an actor of genius, and a certain initial facial resemblance. But in the case of Alfred Inglethorp, all that is changed. His clothes, his beard, the glasses which hide his eyes—those are the salient points about his personal appearance. Now, what is the first instinct of the criminal? To divert suspicion from himself, is it not so? And how can he best do that? By throwing it on someone else. In this instance, there was a man ready to his hand. Everybody was predisposed to believe in Mr. Inglethorp’s guilt. It was a foregone conclusion that he would be suspected; but, to make it a sure thing there must be tangible proof—such as the actual buying of the poison, and that, with a man of the peculiar appearance of Mr. Inglethorp, was not difficult. Remember, this young Mace had never actually spoken to Mr. Inglethorp. How should he doubt that the man in his clothes, with his beard and his glasses, was not Alfred Inglethorp?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “It may be so,”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “But, if that was the case, why does he not say where he was at six o’clock on Monday evening?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Ah, why indeed?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “If he were arrested, he probably would speak, but I do not want it to come to that. I must make him see the gravity of his position. There is, of course, something discreditable behind his silence. If he did not murder his wife, he is, nevertheless, a scoundrel, and has something of his own to conceal, quite apart from the murder.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “What can it be?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Can you not guess?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “No, can you?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Oh, yes, I had a little idea sometime ago—and it has turned out to be correct.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “You never told me,”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Pardon me, mon ami, you were not precisely sympathique.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Tell me—you see now that he must not be arrested?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Perhaps,”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Come, my friend,”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “apart from Mr. Inglethorp, how did the evidence at the inquest strike you?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Oh, pretty much what I expected.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Did nothing strike you as peculiar about it?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “In what way?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Well, Mr. Lawrence Cavendish’s evidence for instance?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Oh, Lawrence! No, I don’t think so. He’s always a nervous chap.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “His suggestion that his mother might have been poisoned accidentally by means of the tonic she was taking, that did not strike you as strange— hein?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “No, I can’t say it did. The doctors ridiculed it of course. But it was quite a natural suggestion for a layman to make.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “But Monsieur Lawrence is not a layman. You told me yourself that he had started by studying medicine, and that he had taken his degree.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Yes, that’s true. I never thought of that.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “It is odd.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “From the first, his behaviour has been peculiar. Of all the household, he alone would be likely to recognize the symptoms of strychnine poisoning, and yet we find him the only member of the family to uphold strenuously the theory of death from natural causes. If it had been Monsieur John, I could have understood it. He has no technical knowledge, and is by nature unimaginative. But Monsieur Lawrence—no! And now, to-day, he puts forward a suggestion that he himself must have known was ridiculous. There is food for thought in this, mon ami!”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “It’s very confusing,”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Then there is Mrs. Cavendish,”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “That’s another who is not telling all she knows! What do you make of her attitude?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “I don’t know what to make of it. It seems inconceivable that she should be shielding Alfred Inglethorp. Yet that is what it looks like.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Yes, it is queer. One thing is certain, she overheard a good deal more of that ‘private conversation’ than she was willing to admit.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “And yet she is the last person one would accuse of stooping to eavesdrop!”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Exactly. One thing her evidence has shown me. I made a mistake. Dorcas was quite right. The quarrel did take place earlier in the afternoon, about four o’clock, as she said.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Yes, a good deal that was peculiar came out to-day,”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Dr. Bauerstein, now, what was he doing up and dressed at that hour in the morning? It is astonishing to me that no one commented on the fact.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “He has insomnia, I believe,”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Which is a very good, or a very bad explanation,”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “It covers everything, and explains nothing. I shall keep my eye on our clever Dr. Bauerstein.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Any more faults to find with the evidence?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Mon ami,”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “when you find that people are not telling you the truth—look out! Now, unless I am much mistaken, at the inquest to-day only one—at most, two persons were speaking the truth without reservation or subterfuge.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Oh, come now, Poirot! I won’t cite Lawrence, or Mrs. Cavendish. But there’s John—and Miss Howard, surely they were speaking the truth?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Both of them, my friend? One, I grant you, but both——!”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Do you really think so?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Miss Howard had always seemed to me so essentially honest—almost uncomfortably so.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Miss Murdoch too,”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “there’s nothing untruthful about her.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “No. But it was strange that she never heard a sound, sleeping next door; whereas Mrs. Cavendish, in the other wing of the building, distinctly heard the table fall.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Well, she’s young. And she sleeps soundly.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Ah, yes, indeed! She must be a famous sleeper, that one!”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Mesdames and messieurs,”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “I have asked you to come here all together, for a certain object. That object, it concerns Mr. Alfred Inglethorp.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Mesdames and messieurs,”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “I have asked you to come here all together, for a certain object. That object, it concerns Mr. Alfred Inglethorp.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Mesdames and messieurs,”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “I have asked you to come here all together, for a certain object. That object, it concerns Mr. Alfred Inglethorp.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Mesdames and messieurs,”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Mesdames and messieurs,”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “I have asked you to come here all together, for a certain object. That object, it concerns Mr. Alfred Inglethorp.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Mr. Inglethorp,”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “a very dark shadow is resting on this house—the shadow of murder.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “My poor wife,”
speaker: Alfred Inglethorp

dialogue: “Poor Emily! It is terrible.”
speaker: Alfred Inglethorp

dialogue: “I do not think, monsieur,”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “that you quite realize how terrible it may be—for you.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Mr. Inglethorp, you are standing in very grave danger.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Anything you say will be used in evidence against you,”
speaker: Superintendent Summerhaye

dialogue: “Do you understand now, monsieur?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “No. What do you mean?”
speaker: Alfred Inglethorp

dialogue: “I mean,”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “that you are suspected of poisoning your wife.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Good heavens!”
speaker: Alfred Inglethorp

dialogue: “What a monstrous idea! I—poison my dearest Emily!”
speaker: Alfred Inglethorp

dialogue: “I do not think”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “that you quite realize the unfavourable nature of your evidence at the inquest. Mr. Inglethorp, knowing what I have now told you, do you still refuse to say where you were at six o’clock on Monday afternoon?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Speak!”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “You will not speak?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “No. I do not believe that anyone could be so monstrous as to accuse me of what you say.”
speaker: Alfred Inglethorp

dialogue: “Soit!”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Then I must speak for you.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “You? How can you speak? You do not know——”
speaker: Alfred Inglethorp

dialogue: “Mesdames and messieurs! I speak! Listen! I, Hercule Poirot, affirm that the man who entered the chemist’s shop, and purchased strychnine at six o’clock on Monday last was not Mr. Inglethorp, for at six o’clock on that day Mr. Inglethorp was escorting Mrs. Raikes back to her home from a neighbouring farm. I can produce no less than five witnesses to swear to having seen them together, either at six or just after and, as you may know, the Abbey Farm, Mrs. Raikes’s home, is at least two and a half miles distant from the village. There is absolutely no question as to the alibi!”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “My word,”
speaker: Inspector Japp

dialogue: “you’re the goods! And no mistake, Mr. Poirot! These witnesses of yours are all right, I suppose?”
speaker: Inspector Japp

dialogue: “Voilà! I have prepared a list of them—names and addresses. You must see them, of course. But you will find it all right.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “I’m sure of that.”
speaker: Inspector Japp

dialogue: “I’m much obliged to you. A pretty mare’s nest arresting him would have been.”
speaker: Inspector Japp

dialogue: “But, if you’ll excuse me, sir, why couldn’t you say all this at the inquest?”
speaker: Inspector Japp

dialogue: “I will tell you why,”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “There was a certain rumour——”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “A most malicious and utterly untrue one,”
speaker: Alfred Inglethorp

dialogue: “And Mr. Inglethorp was anxious to have no scandal revived just at present. Am I right?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Quite right.”
speaker: Alfred Inglethorp

dialogue: “With my poor Emily not yet buried, can you wonder I was anxious that no more lying rumours should be started.”
speaker: Alfred Inglethorp

dialogue: “Between you and me, sir,”
speaker: Inspector Japp

dialogue: “I’d sooner have any amount of rumours than be arrested for murder. And I venture to think your poor lady would have felt the same. And, if it hadn’t been for Mr. Poirot here, arrested you would have been, as sure as eggs is eggs!”
speaker: Inspector Japp

dialogue: “I was foolish, no doubt,”
speaker: Alfred Inglethorp

dialogue: “But you do not know, inspector, how I have been persecuted and maligned.”
speaker: Alfred Inglethorp

dialogue: “Now, sir,”
speaker: Inspector Japp

dialogue: “I should like to see the lady’s bedroom, please, and after that I’ll have a little chat with the servants. Don’t you bother about anything. Mr. Poirot, here, will show me the way.”
speaker: Inspector Japp

dialogue: “Quick, go to the other wing. Stand there—just this side of the baize door. Do not move till I come.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “You have not stirred?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “No, I’ve stuck here like a rock. Nothing’s happened.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Ah!”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “You’ve seen nothing at all?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “No.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “But you have probably heard something? A big bump—eh, mon ami?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “No.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Is it possible? Ah, but I am vexed with myself! I am not usually clumsy. I made but a slight gesture”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “with the left hand, and over went the table by the bed!”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Never mind, old chap. What does it matter? Your triumph downstairs excited you. I can tell you, that was a surprise to us all. There must be more in this affair of Inglethorp’s with Mrs. Raikes than we thought, to make him hold his tongue so persistently. What are you going to do now? Where are the Scotland Yard fellows?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Gone down to interview the servants. I showed them all our exhibits. I am disappointed in Japp. He has no method!”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Hullo!”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Here’s Dr. Bauerstein. I believe you’re right about that man, Poirot. I don’t like him.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “He is clever,”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Oh, clever as the devil! I must say I was overjoyed to see him in the plight he was in on Tuesday. You never saw such a spectacle!”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “He looked a regular scarecrow! Plastered with mud from head to foot.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “You saw him, then?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Yes. Of course, he didn’t want to come in—it was just after dinner—but Mr. Inglethorp insisted.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “What?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Was Dr. Bauerstein here on Tuesday evening? Here? And you never told me? Why did you not tell me? Why? Why?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “My dear Poirot,”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “I never thought it would interest you. I didn’t know it was of any importance.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Importance? It is of the first importance! So Dr. Bauerstein was here on Tuesday night—the night of the murder. Hastings, do you not see? That alters everything—everything!”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Yes, that alters everything—everything.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Allons!”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “We must act at once. Where is Mr. Cavendish?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Mr. Cavendish, I have some important business in Tadminster. A new clue. May I take your motor?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Why, of course. Do you mean at once?”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “If you please.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Now, Poirot,”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “perhaps you will tell me what all this is about?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Well, mon ami, a good deal you can guess for yourself. Of course you realize that, now Mr. Inglethorp is out of it, the whole position is greatly changed. We are face to face with an entirely new problem. We know now that there is one person who did not buy the poison. We have cleared away the manufactured clues. Now for the real ones. I have ascertained that anyone in the household, with the exception of Mrs. Cavendish, who was playing tennis with you, could have personated Mr. Inglethorp on Monday evening. In the same way, we have his statement that he put the coffee down in the hall. No one took much notice of that at the inquest—but now it has a very different significance. We must find out who did take that coffee to Mrs. Inglethorp eventually, or who passed through the hall whilst it was standing there. From your account, there are only two people whom we can positively say did not go near the coffee—Mrs. Cavendish, and Mademoiselle Cynthia.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Yes, that is so.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “In clearing Alfred Inglethorp,”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “I have been obliged to show my hand sooner than I intended. As long as I might be thought to be pursuing him, the criminal would be off his guard. Now, he will be doubly careful. Yes—doubly careful.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Tell me, Hastings, you yourself—have you no suspicions of anybody?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “You couldn’t call it a suspicion,”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “It’s so utterly foolish.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Come now,”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Do not fear. Speak your mind. You should always pay attention to your instincts.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Well then,”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “it’s absurd—but I suspect Miss Howard of not telling all she knows!”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Miss Howard?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Yes—you’ll laugh at me——”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Not at all. Why should I?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “I can’t help feeling,”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “that we’ve rather left her out of the possible suspects, simply on the strength of her having been away from the place. But, after all, she was only fifteen miles away. A car would do it in half an hour. Can we say positively that she was away from Styles on the night of the murder?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Yes, my friend,”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “we can. One of my first actions was to ring up the hospital where she was working.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Well?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Well, I learnt that Miss Howard had been on afternoon duty on Tuesday, and that—a convoy coming in unexpectedly—she had kindly offered to remain on night duty, which offer was gratefully accepted. That disposes of that.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Oh!”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Really,”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “it’s her extraordinary vehemence against Inglethorp that started me off suspecting her. I can’t help feeling she’d do anything against him. And I had an idea she might know something about the destroying of the will. She might have burnt the new one, mistaking it for the earlier one in his favour. She is so terribly bitter against him.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “You consider her vehemence unnatural?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Y—es. She is so very violent. I wondered really whether she is quite sane on that point.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “No, no, you are on a wrong tack there. There is nothing weak-minded or degenerate about Miss Howard. She is an excellent specimen of well-balanced English beef and brawn. She is sanity itself.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Yet her hatred of Inglethorp seems almost a mania. My idea was—a very ridiculous one, no doubt—that she had intended to poison him—and that, in some way, Mrs. Inglethorp got hold of it by mistake. But I don’t at all see how it could have been done. The whole thing is absurd and ridiculous to the last degree.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Still you are right in one thing. It is always wise to suspect everybody until you can prove logically, and to your own satisfaction, that they are innocent. Now, what reasons are there against Miss Howard’s having deliberately poisoned Mrs. Inglethorp?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Why, she was devoted to her!”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Tcha! Tcha!”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “You argue like a child. If Miss Howard were capable of poisoning the old lady, she would be quite equally capable of simulating devotion. No, we must look elsewhere. You are perfectly correct in your assumption that her vehemence against Alfred Inglethorp is too violent to be natural; but you are quite wrong in the deduction you draw from it. I have drawn my own deductions, which I believe to be correct, but I will not speak of them at present.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Now, to my way of thinking, there is one insuperable objection to Miss Howard’s being the murderess.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “And that is?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “That in no possible way could Mrs. Inglethorp’s death benefit Miss Howard. Now there is no murder without a motive.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Could not Mrs. Inglethorp have made a will in her favour?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “But you yourself suggested that possibility to Mr. Wells?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “That was for a reason. I did not want to mention the name of the person who was actually in my mind. Miss Howard occupied very much the same position, so I used her name instead.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Still, Mrs. Inglethorp might have done so. Why, that will, made on the afternoon of her death may——”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “No, my friend. I have certain little ideas of my own about that will. But I can tell you this much—it was not in Miss Howard’s favour.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Well,”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “we will acquit Miss Howard, then. It is partly your fault that I ever came to suspect her. It was what you said about her evidence at the inquest that set me off.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “What did I say about her evidence at the inquest?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Don’t you remember? When I cited her and John Cavendish as being above suspicion?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Oh—ah—yes.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “By the way, Hastings, there is something I want you to do for me.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Certainly. What is it?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Next time you happen to be alone with Lawrence Cavendish, I want you to say this to him. ‘I have a message for you, from Poirot. He says: “Find the extra coffee-cup, and you can rest in peace!”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “‘Find the extra coffee-cup, and you can rest in peace.’ Is that right?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Excellent.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “But what does it mean?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Ah, that I will leave you to find out. You have access to the facts. Just say that to him, and see what he says.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Very well—but it’s all extremely mysterious.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “There,”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “That is all my business.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “What were you doing there?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “I left something to be analysed.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Yes, but what?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “The sample of cocoa I took from the saucepan in the bedroom.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “But that has already been tested!”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Dr. Bauerstein had it tested, and you yourself laughed at the possibility of there being strychnine in it.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “I know Dr. Bauerstein had it tested,”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Well, then?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Well, I have a fancy for having it analysed again, that is all.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “And really it’s a great relief to think he’s going, Hastings,”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “It was bad enough before, when we thought he’d done it, but I’m hanged if it isn’t worse now, when we all feel guilty for having been so down on the fellow. The fact is, we’ve treated him abominably. Of course, things did look black against him. I don’t see how anyone could blame us for jumping to the conclusions we did. Still, there it is, we were in the wrong, and now there’s a beastly feeling that one ought to make amends; which is difficult, when one doesn’t like the fellow a bit better than one did before. The whole thing’s damned awkward! And I’m thankful he’s had the tact to take himself off. It’s a good thing Styles wasn’t the mater’s to leave to him. Couldn’t bear to think of the fellow lording it here. He’s welcome to her money.”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “You’ll be able to keep up the place all right?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Oh, yes. There are the death duties, of course, but half my father’s money goes with the place, and Lawrence will stay with us for the present, so there is his share as well. We shall be pinched at first, of course, because, as I once told you, I am in a bit of a hole financially myself. Still, the Johnnies will wait now.”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “Certainly. What is it, Dorcas?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Well, it’s just this, sir. You’ll be seeing the Belgian gentleman to-day perhaps?”
speaker: Dorcas

dialogue: “Well, sir, you know how he asked me so particular if the mistress, or anyone else, had a green dress?”
speaker: Dorcas

dialogue: “Yes, yes. You have found one?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “No, not that, sir. But since then I’ve remembered what the young gentlemen”
speaker: Dorcas

dialogue: “call the ‘dressing-up box.’ It’s up in the front attic, sir. A great chest, full of old clothes and fancy dresses, and what not. And it came to me sudden like that there might be a green dress amongst them. So, if you’d tell the Belgian gentleman——”
speaker: Dorcas

dialogue: “I will tell him, Dorcas,”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Thank you very much, sir. A very nice gentleman he is, sir. And quite a different class from them two detectives from London, what goes prying about, and asking questions. I don’t hold with foreigners as a rule, but from what the newspapers say I make out as how these brave Belges isn’t the ordinary run of foreigners, and certainly he’s a most polite spoken gentleman.”
speaker: Dorcas

dialogue: “Ah, the brave Dorcas! We will look at the chest, although—but no matter—we will examine it all the same.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “What is it?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Look!”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Ohó!”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Ohó!”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “New,”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Yes, quite new.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “We have been looking through that chest, Dorcas. I am much obliged to you for mentioning it. There is, indeed, a fine collection there. Are they often used, may I ask?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Well, sir, not very often nowadays, though from time to time we do have what the young gentlemen call ‘a dress-up night.’ And very funny it is sometimes, sir. Mr. Lawrence, he’s wonderful. Most comic! I shall never forget the night he came down as the Char of Persia, I think he called it—a sort of Eastern King it was. He had the big paper knife in his hand, and ‘Mind, Dorcas,’ he says, ‘you’ll have to be very respectful. This is my specially sharpened scimitar, and it’s off with your head if I’m at all displeased with you!’ Miss Cynthia, she was what they call an Apache, or some such name—a Frenchified sort of cut-throat, I take it to be. A real sight she looked. You’d never have believed a pretty young lady like that could have made herself into such a ruffian. Nobody would have known her.”
speaker: Dorcas

dialogue: “These evenings must have been great fun,”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “I suppose Mr. Lawrence wore that fine black beard in the chest upstairs, when he was Shah of Persia?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “He did have a beard, sir,”
speaker: Dorcas

dialogue: “And well I know it, for he borrowed two skeins of my black wool to make it with! And I’m sure it looked wonderfully natural at a distance. I didn’t know as there was a beard up there at all. It must have been got quite lately, I think. There was a red wig, I know, but nothing else in the way of hair. Burnt corks they use mostly—though ‘tis messy getting it off again. Miss Cynthia was a character once, and, oh, the trouble she had.”
speaker: Dorcas

dialogue: “So Dorcas knows nothing about that black beard,”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Do you think it is the one?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “I do. You notice it had been trimmed?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “No.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Yes. It was cut exactly the shape of Mr. Inglethorp’s, and I found one or two snipped hairs. Hastings, this affair is very deep.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Who put it in the chest, I wonder?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Someone with a good deal of intelligence,”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “You realize that he chose the one place in the house to hide it where its presence would not be remarked? Yes, he is intelligent. But we must be more intelligent. We must be so intelligent that he does not suspect us of being intelligent at all.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “There, mon ami, you will be of great assistance to me.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Yes,”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “you will be invaluable.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “I must have an ally in the house,”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “You have me,”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “True, but you are not sufficient.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “You do not quite take my meaning. You are known to be working with me. I want somebody who is not associated with us in any way.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Oh, I see. How about John?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “No, I think not.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “The dear fellow isn’t perhaps very bright,”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Here comes Miss Howard,”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “She is the very person. But I am in her black books, since I cleared Mr. Inglethorp. Still, we can but try.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Well, Monsieur Poirot,”
speaker: Evelyn Howard

dialogue: “what is it? Out with it. I’m busy.”
speaker: Evelyn Howard

dialogue: “Do you remember, mademoiselle, that I once asked you to help me?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Yes, I do.”
speaker: Evelyn Howard

dialogue: “And I told you I’d help you with pleasure—to hang Alfred Inglethorp.”
speaker: Evelyn Howard

dialogue: “Ah!”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Miss Howard, I will ask you one question. I beg of you to reply to it truthfully.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Never tell lies,”
speaker: Evelyn Howard

dialogue: “It is this. Do you still believe that Mrs. Inglethorp was poisoned by her husband?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “What do you mean?”
speaker: Evelyn Howard

dialogue: “You needn’t think your pretty explanations influence me in the slightest. I’ll admit that it wasn’t he who bought strychnine at the chemist’s shop. What of that? I dare say he soaked fly paper, as I told you at the beginning.”
speaker: Evelyn Howard

dialogue: “That is arsenic—not strychnine,”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “What does that matter? Arsenic would put poor Emily out of the way just as well as strychnine. If I’m convinced he did it, it doesn’t matter a jot to me how he did it.”
speaker: Evelyn Howard

dialogue: “Exactly. If you are convinced he did it,”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “I will put my question in another form. Did you ever in your heart of hearts believe that Mrs. Inglethorp was poisoned by her husband?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Good heavens!”
speaker: Evelyn Howard

dialogue: “Haven’t I always told you the man is a villain? Haven’t I always told you he would murder her in her bed? Haven’t I always hated him like poison?”
speaker: Evelyn Howard

dialogue: “Exactly,”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “That bears out my little idea entirely.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “What little idea?”
speaker: Evelyn Howard

dialogue: “Miss Howard, do you remember a conversation that took place on the day of my friend’s arrival here? He repeated it to me, and there is a sentence of yours that has impressed me very much. Do you remember affirming that if a crime had been committed, and anyone you loved had been murdered, you felt certain that you would know by instinct who the criminal was, even if you were quite unable to prove it?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Yes, I remember saying that. I believe it too. I suppose you think it nonsense?”
speaker: Evelyn Howard

dialogue: “Not at all.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “And yet you will pay no attention to my instinct against Alfred Inglethorp.”
speaker: Evelyn Howard

dialogue: “No,”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Because your instinct is not against Mr. Inglethorp.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “What?”
speaker: Evelyn Howard

dialogue: “No. You wish to believe he committed the crime. You believe him capable of committing it. But your instinct tells you he did not commit it. It tells you more—shall I go on?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Shall I tell you why you have been so vehement against Mr. Inglethorp? It is because you have been trying to believe what you wish to believe. It is because you are trying to drown and stifle your instinct, which tells you another name——”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “No, no, no!”
speaker: Evelyn Howard

dialogue: “Don’t say it! Oh, don’t say it! It isn’t true! It can’t be true. I don’t know what put such a wild—such a dreadful—idea into my head!”
speaker: Evelyn Howard

dialogue: “I am right, am I not?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Yes, yes; you must be a wizard to have guessed. But it can’t be so—it’s too monstrous, too impossible. It must be Alfred Inglethorp.”
speaker: Evelyn Howard

dialogue: “Don’t ask me about it,”
speaker: Evelyn Howard

dialogue: “because I shan’t tell you. I won’t admit it, even to myself. I must be mad to think of such a thing.”
speaker: Evelyn Howard

dialogue: “I will ask you nothing. It is enough for me that it is as I thought. And I—I, too, have an instinct. We are working together towards a common end.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Don’t ask me to help you, because I won’t. I wouldn’t lift a finger to—to——”
speaker: Evelyn Howard

dialogue: “You will help me in spite of yourself. I ask you nothing—but you will be my ally. You will not be able to help yourself. You will do the only thing that I want of you.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “And that is?”
speaker: Evelyn Howard

dialogue: “You will watch!”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Yes, I can’t help doing that. I am always watching—always hoping I shall be proved wrong.”
speaker: Evelyn Howard

dialogue: “If we are wrong, well and good,”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “No one will be more pleased than I shall. But, if we are right? If we are right, Miss Howard, on whose side are you then?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “I don’t know, I don’t know——”
speaker: Evelyn Howard

dialogue: “Come now.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “It could be hushed up.”
speaker: Evelyn Howard

dialogue: “There must be no hushing up.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “But Emily herself——”
speaker: Evelyn Howard

dialogue: “Miss Howard,”
speaker: Hercule Poirot
