dialogue: “this is unworthy of you.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Yes,”
speaker: Evelyn Howard

dialogue: “that was not Evelyn Howard who spoke!”
speaker: Evelyn Howard

dialogue: “This is Evelyn Howard! And she is on the side of Justice! Let the cost be what it may.”
speaker: Evelyn Howard

dialogue: “There,”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “goes a very valuable ally. That woman, Hastings, has got brains as well as a heart.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Instinct is a marvellous thing,”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “It can neither be explained nor ignored.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “You and Miss Howard seem to know what you are talking about,”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Perhaps you don’t realize that I am still in the dark.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Really? Is that so, mon ami?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Yes. Enlighten me, will you?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “No, my friend.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Oh, look here, why not?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Two is enough for a secret.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Well, I think it is very unfair to keep back facts from me.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “I am not keeping back facts. Every fact that I know is in your possession. You can draw your own deductions from them. This time it is a question of ideas.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Still, it would be interesting to know.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “You see,”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “you have no instincts.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “It was intelligence you were requiring just now,”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “The two often go together,”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “I’ve been looking for you,”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Have you?”
speaker: Lawrence Cavendish

dialogue: “Yes. The truth is, I’ve got a message for you—from Poirot.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Yes?”
speaker: Lawrence Cavendish

dialogue: “He told me to wait until I was alone with you,”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Well?”
speaker: Lawrence Cavendish

dialogue: “This is the message.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “‘Find the extra coffee-cup, and you can rest in peace.’”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “What on earth does he mean?”
speaker: Lawrence Cavendish

dialogue: “Don’t you know?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Not in the least. Do you?”
speaker: Lawrence Cavendish

dialogue: “What extra coffee-cup?”
speaker: Lawrence Cavendish

dialogue: “I don’t know.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “He’d better ask Dorcas, or one of the maids, if he wants to know about coffee-cups. It’s their business, not mine. I don’t know anything about the coffee-cups, except that we’ve got some that are never used, which are a perfect dream! Old Worcester. You’re not a connoisseur, are you, Hastings?”
speaker: Lawrence Cavendish

dialogue: “You miss a lot. A really perfect bit of old china—it’s pure delight to handle it, or even to look at it.”
speaker: Lawrence Cavendish

dialogue: “Well, what am I to tell Poirot?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Tell him I don’t know what he’s talking about. It’s double Dutch to me.”
speaker: Lawrence Cavendish

dialogue: “All right.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “I say, what was the end of that message? Say it over again, will you?”
speaker: Lawrence Cavendish

dialogue: “‘Find the extra coffee-cup, and you can rest in peace.’ Are you sure you don’t know what it means?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “No,”
speaker: Lawrence Cavendish

dialogue: “I don’t. I—I wish I did.”
speaker: Lawrence Cavendish

dialogue: “Pardon me, madame, for recalling unpleasant memories, but I have a little idea”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Of me? Certainly.”
speaker: Mary Cavendish

dialogue: “You are too amiable, madame. What I want to ask is this: the door leading into Mrs. Inglethorp’s room from that of Mademoiselle Cynthia, it was bolted, you say?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Certainly it was bolted,”
speaker: Mary Cavendish

dialogue: “I said so at the inquest.”
speaker: Mary Cavendish

dialogue: “Bolted?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Yes.”
speaker: Mary Cavendish

dialogue: “I mean,”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “you are sure it was bolted, and not merely locked?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Oh, I see what you mean. No, I don’t know. I said bolted, meaning that it was fastened, and I could not open it, but I believe all the doors were found bolted on the inside.”
speaker: Mary Cavendish

dialogue: “Still, as far as you are concerned, the door might equally well have been locked?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Oh, yes.”
speaker: Mary Cavendish

dialogue: “You yourself did not happen to notice, madame, when you entered Mrs. Inglethorp’s room, whether that door was bolted or not?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “I—I believe it was.”
speaker: Mary Cavendish

dialogue: “But you did not see it?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “No. I—never looked.”
speaker: Mary Cavendish

dialogue: “But I did,”
speaker: Lawrence Cavendish

dialogue: “I happened to notice that it was bolted.”
speaker: Lawrence Cavendish

dialogue: “Ah, that settles it.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “You are annoyed, is it not so?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Not at all,”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “That is well. That lifts a great load from my mind.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “I gave Lawrence your message,”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “And what did he say? He was entirely puzzled?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Yes. I am quite sure he had no idea of what you meant.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Mademoiselle Cynthia was not at lunch to-day? How was that?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “She is at the hospital again. She resumed work to-day.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Ah, she is an industrious little demoiselle. And pretty too. She is like pictures I have seen in Italy. I would rather like to see that dispensary of hers. Do you think she would show it to me?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “I am sure she would be delighted. It’s an interesting little place.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Does she go there every day?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “She has all Wednesdays off, and comes back to lunch on Saturdays. Those are her only times off.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “I will remember. Women are doing great work nowadays, and Mademoiselle Cynthia is clever—oh, yes, she has brains, that little one.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Yes. I believe she has passed quite a stiff exam.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Without doubt. After all, it is very responsible work. I suppose they have very strong poisons there?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Yes, she showed them to us. They are kept locked up in a little cupboard. I believe they have to be very careful. They always take out the key before leaving the room.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Indeed. It is near the window, this cupboard?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “No, right the other side of the room. Why?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “I wondered. That is all. Will you come in?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “No. I think I’ll be getting back. I shall go round the long way through the woods.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “I tell you I won’t have it!”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “I tell you, Mary, I won’t have it.”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “Have you any right to criticize my actions?”
speaker: Mary Cavendish

dialogue: “It will be the talk of the village! My mother was only buried on Saturday, and here you are gadding about with the fellow.”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “Oh,”
speaker: Mary Cavendish

dialogue: “if it is only village gossip that you mind!”
speaker: Mary Cavendish

dialogue: “But it isn’t. I’ve had enough of the fellow hanging about. He’s a Polish Jew, anyway.”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “A tinge of Jewish blood is not a bad thing. It leavens the”
speaker: Mary Cavendish

dialogue: “stolid stupidity of the ordinary Englishman.”
speaker: Mary Cavendish

dialogue: “Mary!”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “Well?”
speaker: Mary Cavendish

dialogue: “Am I to understand that you will continue to see Bauerstein against my express wishes?”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “If I choose.”
speaker: Mary Cavendish

dialogue: “You defy me?”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “No, but I deny your right to criticize my actions. Have you no friends of whom I should disapprove?”
speaker: Mary Cavendish

dialogue: “What do you mean?”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “You see!”
speaker: Mary Cavendish

dialogue: “You do see, don’t you, that you have no right to dictate to me as to the choice of my friends?”
speaker: Mary Cavendish

dialogue: “No right? Have I no right, Mary?”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “Mary——”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “None!”
speaker: Mary Cavendish

dialogue: “Mary”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “are you in love with this fellow Bauerstein?”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “Perhaps,”
speaker: Mary Cavendish

dialogue: “Hullo, Hastings. Have you seen the little fellow safely back to his cottage? Quaint little chap! Is he any good, though, really?”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “He was considered one of the finest detectives of his day.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Oh, well, I suppose there must be something in it, then. What a rotten world it is, though!”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “You find it so?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Good Lord, yes! There’s this terrible business to start with. Scotland Yard men in and out of the house like a jack-in-the-box! Never know where they won’t turn up next. Screaming headlines in every paper in the country—damn all journalists, I say! Do you know there was a whole crowd staring in at the lodge gates this morning. Sort of Madame Tussaud’s chamber of horrors business that can be seen for nothing. Pretty thick, isn’t it?”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “Cheer up, John!”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “It can’t last for ever.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Can’t it, though? It can last long enough for us never to be able to hold up our heads again.”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “No, no, you’re getting morbid on the subject.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Enough to make a man morbid, to be stalked by beastly journalists and stared at by gaping moon-faced idiots, wherever he goes! But there’s worse than that.”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “What?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Have you ever thought, Hastings—it’s a nightmare to me—who did it? I can’t help feeling sometimes it must have been an accident. Because—because—who could have done it? Now Inglethorp’s out of the way, there’s no one else; no one, I mean, except—one of us.”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “No, John,”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “it isn’t one of us. How could it be?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “I know, but, still, who else is there?”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “Can’t you guess?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “No.”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “Dr. Bauerstein!”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Impossible!”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “Not at all.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “But what earthly interest could he have in my mother’s death?”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “That I don’t see,”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “but I’ll tell you this: Poirot thinks so.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Poirot? Does he? How do you know?”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “He said twice: ‘That alters everything.’ And I’ve been thinking. You know Inglethorp said he had put down the coffee in the hall? Well, it was just then that Bauerstein arrived. Isn’t it possible that, as Inglethorp brought him through the hall, the doctor dropped something into the coffee in passing?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “It would have been very risky.”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “Yes, but it was possible.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “And then, how could he know it was her coffee? No, old fellow, I don’t think that will wash.”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “You’re quite right. That wasn’t how it was done. Listen.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “But, look here, Bauerstein had had it analysed already?”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “Yes, yes, that’s the point. I didn’t see it either until now. Don’t you understand? Bauerstein had it analysed—that’s just it! If Bauerstein’s the murderer, nothing could be simpler than for him to substitute some ordinary cocoa for his sample, and send that to be tested. And of course they would find no strychnine! But no one would dream of suspecting Bauerstein, or think of taking another sample—except Poirot,”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Yes, but what about the bitter taste that cocoa won’t disguise?”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “Well, we’ve only his word for that. And there are other possibilities. He’s admittedly one of the world’s greatest toxicologists——”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “One of the world’s greatest what? Say it again.”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “He knows more about poisons than almost anybody,”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Well, my idea is, that perhaps he’s found some way of making strychnine tasteless. Or it may not have been strychnine at all, but some obscure drug no one has ever heard of, which produces much the same symptoms.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “H’m, yes, that might be,”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “But look here, how could he have got at the cocoa? That wasn’t downstairs?”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “No, it wasn’t,”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “There’s another thing,”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “Something which makes me doubt if what you say can be true.”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “What’s that?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Why, the fact that Bauerstein demanded a post-mortem. He needn’t have done so. Little Wilkins would have been quite content to let it go at heart disease.”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “Yes,”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “But we don’t know. Perhaps he thought it safer in the long run. Someone might have talked afterwards. Then the Home Office might have ordered exhumation. The whole thing would have come out, then, and he would have been in an awkward position, for no one would have believed that a man of his reputation could have been deceived into calling it heart disease.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Yes, that’s possible,”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “Still,”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “I’m blest if I can see what his motive could have been.”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “Look here,”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “I may be altogether wrong. And, remember, all this is in confidence.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Oh, of course—that goes without saying.”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “Of course! I’d love him to see it. He’d better come to tea there one day. I must fix it up with him. He’s such a dear little man! But he is funny. He made me take the brooch out of my tie the other day, and put it in again, because he said it wasn’t straight.”
speaker: Cynthia Murdoch

dialogue: “It’s quite a mania with him.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Yes, isn’t it?”
speaker: Cynthia Murdoch

dialogue: “Mr. Hastings.”
speaker: Cynthia Murdoch

dialogue: “Yes?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “After tea, I want to talk to you.”
speaker: Cynthia Murdoch

dialogue: “Confound those detectives! I can’t think what they’re after! They’ve been in every room in the house—turning things inside out, and upside down. It really is too bad! I suppose they took advantage of our all being out. I shall go for that fellow Japp, when I next see him!”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “Confound those detectives! I can’t think what they’re after! They’ve been in every room in the house—turning things inside out, and upside down. It really is too bad! I suppose they took advantage of our all being out. I shall go for that fellow Japp, when I next see him!”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “Confound those detectives! I can’t think what they’re after! They’ve been in every room in the house—turning things inside out, and upside down. It really is too bad! I suppose they took advantage of our all being out. I shall go for that fellow Japp, when I next see him!”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “Confound those detectives! I can’t think what they’re after! They’ve been in every room in the house—turning things inside out, and upside down. It really is too bad! I suppose they took advantage of our all being out. I shall go for that fellow Japp, when I next see him!”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “Confound those detectives! I can’t think what they’re after! They’ve been in every room in the house—turning things inside out, and upside down. It really is too bad! I suppose they took advantage of our all being out. I shall go for that fellow Japp, when I next see him!”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “Lot of Paul Prys,”
speaker: Evelyn Howard

dialogue: “Well?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Mr. Hastings—you are always so kind, and you know such a lot.”
speaker: Cynthia Murdoch

dialogue: “Well?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “I want to ask your advice. What shall I do?”
speaker: Cynthia Murdoch

dialogue: “Do?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Yes. You see, Aunt Emily always told me I should be provided for. I suppose she forgot, or didn’t think she was likely to die—anyway, I am not provided for! And I don’t know what to do. Do you think I ought to go away from here at once?”
speaker: Cynthia Murdoch

dialogue: “Good heavens, no! They don’t want to part with you, I’m sure.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Mrs. Cavendish does. She hates me.”
speaker: Cynthia Murdoch

dialogue: “Hates you?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Yes. I don’t know why, but she can’t bear me; and he can’t, either.”
speaker: Cynthia Murdoch

dialogue: “There I know you’re wrong,”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “On the contrary, John is very fond of you.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Oh, yes—John. I meant Lawrence. Not, of course, that I care whether Lawrence hates me or not. Still, it’s rather horrid when no one loves you, isn’t it?”
speaker: Cynthia Murdoch

dialogue: “But they do, Cynthia dear,”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “I’m sure you are mistaken. Look, there is John—and Miss Howard——”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Yes, John likes me, I think, and of course Evie, for all her gruff ways, wouldn’t be unkind to a fly. But Lawrence never speaks to me if he can help it, and Mary can hardly bring herself to be civil to me. She wants Evie to stay on, is begging her to, but she doesn’t want me, and—and—I don’t know what to do.”
speaker: Cynthia Murdoch

dialogue: “Marry me, Cynthia.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Don’t be silly!”
speaker: Cynthia Murdoch

dialogue: “I’m not being silly. I am asking you to do me the honour of becoming my wife.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “funny dear.”
speaker: Cynthia Murdoch

dialogue: “It’s perfectly sweet of you,”
speaker: Cynthia Murdoch

dialogue: “but you know you don’t want to!”
speaker: Cynthia Murdoch

dialogue: “Yes, I do. I’ve got——”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Never mind what you’ve got. You don’t really want to—and I don’t either.”
speaker: Cynthia Murdoch

dialogue: “Well, of course, that settles it,”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “But I don’t see anything to laugh at. There’s nothing funny about a proposal.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “No, indeed,”
speaker: Cynthia Murdoch

dialogue: “Somebody might accept you next time. Good-bye, you’ve cheered me up very much.”
speaker: Cynthia Murdoch

dialogue: “Good afternoon,”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Is Dr. Bauerstein in?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Haven’t you heard?”
speaker: Dr. Bauerstein's Landlady

dialogue: “Heard what?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “About him.”
speaker: Dr. Bauerstein's Landlady

dialogue: “What about him?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “He’s took.”
speaker: Dr. Bauerstein's Landlady

dialogue: “Took? Dead?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “No, took by the perlice.”
speaker: Dr. Bauerstein's Landlady

dialogue: “By the police!”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Do you mean they’ve arrested him?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Yes, that’s it, and——”
speaker: Dr. Bauerstein's Landlady

dialogue: “Great Scott! You were right, then. I couldn’t believe it at the time.”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “No, it is astonishing until you get used to the idea, and see how it makes everything fit in. Now, what are we to do? Of course, it will be generally known to-morrow.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Never mind,”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “we won’t say anything at present. There is no need. As you say, it will be known soon enough.”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “Bonjour, mon ami!”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Poirot,”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “I was never so glad to see anyone. Listen, I have said nothing to anybody but John. Is that right?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “My friend,”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “I do not know what you are talking about.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Dr. Bauerstein’s arrest, of course,”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Is Bauerstein arrested, then?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Did you not know it?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Not the least in the world.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Still, it does not surprise me. After all, we are only four miles from the coast.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “The coast?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “What has that got to do with it?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Surely, it is obvious!”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Not to me. No doubt I am very dense, but I cannot see what the proximity of the coast has got to do with the murder of Mrs. Inglethorp.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Nothing at all, of course,”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “But we were speaking of the arrest of Dr. Bauerstein.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Well, he is arrested for the murder of Mrs. Inglethorp——”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “What?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Dr. Bauerstein arrested for the murder of Mrs. Inglethorp?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Yes.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Impossible! That would be too good a farce! Who told you that, my friend?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Well, no one exactly told me,”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “But he is arrested.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Oh, yes, very likely. But for espionage, mon ami.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Espionage?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Precisely.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Not for poisoning Mrs. Inglethorp?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Not unless our friend Japp has taken leave of his senses,”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “But—but I thought you thought so too?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Do you mean to say,”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “that Dr. Bauerstein is a spy?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Have you never suspected it?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “It never entered my head.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “It did not strike you as peculiar that a famous London doctor should bury himself in a little village like this, and should be in the habit of walking about at all hours of the night, fully dressed?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “No,”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “I never thought of such a thing.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “He is, of course, a German by birth,”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “though he has practised so long in this country that nobody thinks of him as anything but an Englishman. He was naturalized about fifteen years ago. A very clever man—a Jew, of course.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “The blackguard!”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Not at all. He is, on the contrary, a patriot. Think what he stands to lose. I admire the man myself.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “And this is the man with whom Mrs. Cavendish has been wandering about all over the country!”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Yes. I should fancy he had found her very useful,”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “So long as gossip busied itself in coupling their names together, any other vagaries of the doctor’s passed unobserved.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Then you think he never really cared for her?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “That, of course, I cannot say, but—shall I tell you my own private opinion, Hastings?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Yes.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Well, it is this: that Mrs. Cavendish does not care, and never has cared one little jot about Dr. Bauerstein!”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Do you really think so?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “I am quite sure of it. And I will tell you why.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Yes?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Because she cares for someone else, mon ami.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Oh!”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “On top of the wardrobe.”
speaker: Evelyn Howard

dialogue: “Come here, Hastings. Now tell me, what is that initial—J. or L.?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “It might be T., or it might be L.,”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “It certainly isn’t a J.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Good,”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “I, also, am of your way of thinking. It is an L., depend upon it!”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Where did it come from?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Is it important?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Moderately so. It confirms a surmise of mine. Having deduced its existence, I set Miss Howard to search for it, and, as you see, she has been successful.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “What did she mean by ‘On the top of the wardrobe’?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “She meant,”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “that she found it on top of a wardrobe.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “A funny place for a piece of brown paper,”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Not at all. The top of a wardrobe is an excellent place for brown paper and cardboard boxes. I have kept them there myself. Neatly arranged, there is nothing to offend the eye.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Poirot,”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “have you made up your mind about this crime?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Yes—that is to say, I believe I know how it was committed.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Ah!”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Unfortunately, I have no proof beyond my surmise, unless——”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Mademoiselle Dorcas, Mademoiselle Dorcas, un moment, s’il vous plaît!”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “My good Dorcas, I have an idea—a little idea—if it should prove justified, what magnificent chance! Tell me, on Monday, not Tuesday, Dorcas, but Monday, the day before the tragedy, did anything go wrong with Mrs. Inglethorp’s bell?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Yes, sir, now you mention it, it did; though I don’t know how you came to hear of it. A mouse, or some such, must have nibbled the wire through. The man came and put it right on Tuesday morning.”
speaker: Dorcas

dialogue: “See you, one should not ask for outside proof—no, reason should be enough. But the flesh is weak, it is consolation to find that one is on the right track. Ah, my friend, I am like a giant refreshed. I run! I leap!”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “What is your remarkable little friend doing?”
speaker: Mary Cavendish

dialogue: “What is it all about?”
speaker: Mary Cavendish

dialogue: “Really, I can’t tell you. He asked Dorcas some question about a bell, and appeared so delighted with her answer that he is capering about as you see!”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “How ridiculous! He’s going out of the gate. Isn’t he coming back to-day?”
speaker: Mary Cavendish

dialogue: “I don’t know. I’ve given up trying to guess what he’ll do next.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Is he quite mad, Mr. Hastings?”
speaker: Mary Cavendish

dialogue: “I honestly don’t know. Sometimes, I feel sure he is as mad as a hatter; and then, just as he is at his maddest, I find there is method in his madness.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “I see.”
speaker: Mary Cavendish

dialogue: “You are an excellent advocate, I have no doubt, Mr. Hastings, but in this case your talents are quite thrown away. Cynthia will run no risk of encountering any unkindness from me.”
speaker: Mary Cavendish

dialogue: “Mr. Hastings,”
speaker: Mary Cavendish

dialogue: “do you think I and my husband are happy together?”
speaker: Mary Cavendish

dialogue: “Well,”
speaker: Mary Cavendish

dialogue: “whether it is your business or not, I will tell you that we are not happy.”
speaker: Mary Cavendish

dialogue: “You don’t know anything about me, do you?”
speaker: Mary Cavendish

dialogue: “Where I come from, who I was before I married John—anything, in fact? Well, I will tell you. I will make a father confessor of you. You are kind, I think—yes, I am sure you are kind.”
speaker: Mary Cavendish

dialogue: “My father was English,”
speaker: Mary Cavendish

dialogue: “but my mother was a Russian.”
speaker: Mary Cavendish

dialogue: “Ah,”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “now I understand——”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Understand what?”
speaker: Mary Cavendish

dialogue: “A hint of something foreign—different—that there has always been about you.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “My mother was very beautiful, I believe. I don’t know, because I never saw her. She died when I was quite a little child. I believe there was some tragedy connected with her death—she took an overdose of some sleeping draught by mistake. However that may be, my father was broken-hearted. Shortly afterwards, he went into the Consular Service. Everywhere he went, I went with him. When I was twenty-three, I had been nearly all over the world. It was a splendid life—I loved it.”
speaker: Mary Cavendish

dialogue: “Then my father died. He left me very badly off. I had to go and live with some old aunts in Yorkshire.”
speaker: Mary Cavendish

dialogue: “You will understand me when I say that it was a deadly life for a girl brought up as I had been. The narrowness, the deadly monotony of it, almost drove me mad.”
speaker: Mary Cavendish

dialogue: “And then I met John Cavendish.”
speaker: Mary Cavendish

dialogue: “Yes?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “You can imagine that, from my aunts’ point of view, it was a very good match for me. But I can honestly say it was not this fact which weighed with me. No, he was simply a way of escape from the insufferable monotony of my life.”
speaker: Mary Cavendish

dialogue: “Don’t misunderstand me. I was quite honest with him. I told him, what was true, that I liked him very much, that I hoped to come to like him more, but that I was not in any way what the world calls ‘in love’ with him. He declared that that satisfied him, and so—we were married.”
speaker: Mary Cavendish

dialogue: “I think—I am sure—he cared for me at first. But I suppose we were not well matched. Almost at once, we drifted apart. He—it is not a pleasing thing for my pride, but it is the truth—tired of me very soon.”
speaker: Mary Cavendish

dialogue: “Oh, yes, he did! Not that it matters now—now that we’ve come to the parting of the ways.”
speaker: Mary Cavendish

dialogue: “What do you mean?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “I mean that I am not going to remain at Styles.”
speaker: Mary Cavendish

dialogue: “You and John are not going to live here?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “John may live here, but I shall not.”
speaker: Mary Cavendish

dialogue: “You are going to leave him?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Yes.”
speaker: Mary Cavendish

dialogue: “But why?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Perhaps—because I want to be—free!”
speaker: Mary Cavendish

dialogue: “You don’t know, you don’t know, how this hateful place has been prison to me!”
speaker: Mary Cavendish

dialogue: “I understand,”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “but—but don’t do anything rash.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Oh, rash!”
speaker: Mary Cavendish

dialogue: “You know that Dr. Bauerstein has been arrested?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “John was so kind as to break that to me this morning.”
speaker: Mary Cavendish

dialogue: “Well, what do you think?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Of what?”
speaker: Mary Cavendish

dialogue: “Of the arrest?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “What should I think? Apparently he is a German spy; so the gardener had told John.”
speaker: Mary Cavendish

dialogue: “These are quite dead. I must do them again. Would you mind moving—thank you, Mr. Hastings.”
speaker: Mary Cavendish

dialogue: “Gone to London again?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Oh, no, monsieur, he has but taken the train to Tadminster. ‘To see a young lady’s dispensary,’ he said.”
speaker: Poirot's Landlady

dialogue: “Silly ass!”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “I told him Wednesday was the one day she wasn’t there! Well, tell him to look us up to-morrow morning, will you?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Certainly, monsieur.”
speaker: Poirot's Landlady

dialogue: “No, I don’t think I shall. He can come up here if he wants to see us.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Oh!”
speaker: Lawrence Cavendish

dialogue: “What is it?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “I could go if there’s anything special.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “It’s nothing much, but—well, if you are going, will you tell him——”
speaker: Lawrence Cavendish

dialogue: “I think I’ve found the extra coffee-cup!”
speaker: Lawrence Cavendish

dialogue: “What is it?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “You are not ill, I trust?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “No, no, not ill. But I decide an affair of great moment.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Whether to catch the criminal or not?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “‘To speak or not to speak,’ as your so great Shakespeare says, ‘that is the question.’”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “You are not serious, Poirot?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “I am of the most serious. For the most serious of all things hangs in the balance.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “And that is?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “A woman’s happiness, mon ami,”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “The moment has come,”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “and I do not know what to do. For, see you, it is a big stake for which I play. No one but I, Hercule Poirot, would attempt it!”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Aha!”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “So he has found the extra coffee-cup. That is good. He has more intelligence than would appear, this long-faced Monsieur Lawrence of yours!”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “It is true. I have the head of a sieve. However, the other young lady was most kind. She was sorry for my disappointment, and showed me everything in the kindest way.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Oh, well, that’s all right, then, and you must go to tea with Cynthia another day.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “I am sorry for that,”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “I always had hopes of that letter. But no, it was not to be. This affair must all be unravelled from within.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “These little grey cells. It is ‘up to them’—as you say over here.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Are you a judge of finger-marks, my friend?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “No,”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “I know that there are no two finger-marks alike, but that’s as far as my science goes.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Exactly.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “I have numbered them, 1, 2, 3. Will you describe them to me?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “All greatly magnified, I see. No. 1, I should say, are a man’s finger-prints; thumb and first finger. No. 2 are a lady’s; they are much smaller, and quite different in every way. No. 3”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “there seem to be a lot of confused finger-marks, but here, very distinctly, are No. 1’s.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Overlapping the others?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Yes.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “You recognize them beyond fail?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Oh, yes; they are identical.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “I suppose,”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “that as usual, you are not going to explain?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “On the contrary. No. 1 were the finger-prints of Monsieur Lawrence. No. 2 were those of Mademoiselle Cynthia. They are not important. I merely obtained them for comparison. No. 3 is a little more complicated.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Yes?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “It is, as you see, highly magnified. You may have noticed a sort of blur extending all across the picture. I will not describe to you the special apparatus, dusting powder, etc., which I used. It is a well-known process to the police, and by means of it you can obtain a photograph of the finger-prints of any object in a very short space of time. Well, my friend, you have seen the finger-marks—it remains to tell you the particular object on which they had been left.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Go on—I am really excited.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Eh bien! Photo No. 3 represents the highly magnified surface of a tiny bottle in the top poison cupboard of the dispensary in the Red Cross Hospital at Tadminster—which sounds like the house that Jack built!”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Good heavens!”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “But what were Lawrence Cavendish’s finger-marks doing on it? He never went near the poison cupboard the day we were there!”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Oh, yes, he did!”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Impossible! We were all together the whole time.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “No, my friend, there was a moment when you were not all together. There was a moment when you could not have been all together, or it would not have been necessary to call to Monsieur Lawrence to come and join you on the balcony.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “I’d forgotten that,”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “But it was only for a moment.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Long enough.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Long enough for what?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Long enough for a gentleman who had once studied medicine to gratify a very natural interest and curiosity.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Poirot,”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “what was in this particular little bottle?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Hydro-chloride of strychnine,”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Good heavens!”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “They use the pure hydro-chloride of strychnine very little—only occasionally for pills. It is the official solution, Liq. Strychnine Hydro-clor. that is used in most medicines. That is why the finger-marks have remained undisturbed since then.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “How did you manage to take this photograph?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “I dropped my hat from the balcony,”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Visitors were not permitted below at that hour, so, in spite of my many apologies, Mademoiselle Cynthia’s colleague had to go down and fetch it for me.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Then you knew what you were going to find?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “No, not at all. I merely realized that it was possible, from your story, for Monsieur Lawrence to go to the poison cupboard. The possibility had to be confirmed, or eliminated.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Poirot,”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “your gaiety does not deceive me. This is a very important discovery.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “I do not know,”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “But one thing does strike me. No doubt it has struck you too.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “What is that?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Why, that there is altogether too much strychnine about this case. This is the third time we run up against it. There was strychnine in Mrs. Inglethorp’s tonic. There is the strychnine sold across the counter at Styles St. Mary by Mace. Now we have more strychnine, handled by one of the household. It is confusing; and, as you know, I do not like confusion.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “There is a lady below, asking for Mr Hastings.”
speaker: Belgian Roommate

dialogue: “A lady?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “I have been visiting an old woman in the village,”
speaker: Mary Cavendish

dialogue: “and as Lawrence told me you were with Monsieur Poirot I thought I would call for you.”
speaker: Mary Cavendish

dialogue: “Alas, madame,”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “I thought you had come to honour me with a visit!”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “I will some day, if you ask me,”
speaker: Mary Cavendish

dialogue: “That is well. If you should need a father confessor, madame”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “remember, Papa Poirot is always at your service.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Come, will you not walk back with us too, Monsieur Poirot?”
speaker: Mary Cavendish

dialogue: “Enchanted, madame.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Oh, m’am! Oh, m’am! I don’t know how to tell you——”
speaker: Dorcas

dialogue: “What is it, Dorcas?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Tell us at once.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “It’s those wicked detectives. They’ve arrested him—they’ve arrested Mr. Cavendish!”
speaker: Dorcas

dialogue: “Arrested Lawrence?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “No, sir. Not Mr. Lawrence—Mr. John.”
speaker: Dorcas

dialogue: “Yes, she is of those women who show at their best in adversity. It brings out all that is sweetest and truest in them. Her pride and her jealousy have——”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Jealousy?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Yes. Have you not realized that she is an unusually jealous woman? As I was saying, her pride and jealousy have been laid aside. She thinks of nothing but her husband, and the terrible fate that is hanging over him.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Even now,”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “I can hardly believe it. You see, up to the very last minute, I thought it was Lawrence!”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “I know you did.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “But John! My old friend John!”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Every murderer is probably somebody’s old friend,”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “You cannot mix up sentiment and reason.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “I must say I think you might have given me a hint.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Perhaps, mon ami, I did not do so, just because he was your old friend.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “But, Poirot——”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Oh, my friend, have I not said to you all along that I have no proofs. It is one thing to know that a man is guilty, it is quite another matter to prove him so. And, in this case, there is terribly little evidence. That is the whole trouble. I, Hercule Poirot, know, but I lack the last link in my chain. And unless I can find that missing link——”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “When did you first suspect John Cavendish?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Did you not suspect him at all?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “No, indeed.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Not after that fragment of conversation you overheard between Mrs. Cavendish and her mother-in-law, and her subsequent lack of frankness at the inquest?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “No.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Did you not put two and two together, and reflect that if it was not Alfred Inglethorp who was quarrelling with his wife—and you remember, he strenuously denied it at the inquest—it must be either Lawrence or John. Now, if it was Lawrence, Mary Cavendish’s conduct was just as inexplicable. But if, on the other hand, it was John, the whole thing was explained quite naturally.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “So,”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “it was John who quarrelled with his mother that afternoon?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Exactly.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “And you have known this all along?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Certainly. Mrs. Cavendish’s behaviour could only be explained that way.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “And yet you say he may be acquitted?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Certainly I do. At the police court proceedings, we shall hear the case for the prosecution, but in all probability his solicitors will advise him to reserve his defence. That will be sprung upon us at the trial. And—ah, by the way, I have a word of caution to give you, my friend. I must not appear in the case.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “What?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “No. Officially, I have nothing to do with it. Until I have found that last link in my chain, I must remain behind the scenes. Mrs. Cavendish must think I am working for her husband, not against him.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “I say, that’s playing it a bit low down,”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Not at all. We have to deal with a most clever and unscrupulous man, and we must use any means in our power—otherwise he will slip through our fingers. That is why I have been careful to remain in the background. All the discoveries have been made by Japp, and Japp will take all the credit. If I am called upon to give evidence at all”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “it will probably be as a witness for the defence.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “It is quite en règle,”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Strangely enough, I can give evidence that will demolish one contention of the prosecution.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Which one?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “The one that relates to the destruction of the will. John Cavendish did not destroy that will.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “I take it, Dr. Bauerstein, that strychnine, as a drug, acts quickly?”
speaker: Sir Ernest Heavywether

dialogue: “Yes.”
speaker: Dr. Bauerstein

dialogue: “And that you are unable to account for the delay in this case?”
speaker: Sir Ernest Heavywether

dialogue: “Yes.”
speaker: Dr. Bauerstein

dialogue: “Thank you.”
speaker: Sir Ernest Heavywether

dialogue: “In the month of June last, do you remember a parcel arriving for Mr. Lawrence Cavendish from Parkson’s?”
speaker: Mr. Philips

dialogue: “I don’t remember, sir. It may have done, but Mr. Lawrence was away from home part of June.”
speaker: Dorcas

dialogue: “In the event of a parcel arriving for him whilst he was away, what would be done with it?”
speaker: Mr. Philips

dialogue: “It would either be put in his room or sent on after him.”
speaker: Dorcas

dialogue: “By you?”
speaker: Mr. Philips

dialogue: “No, sir, I should leave it on the hall table. It would be Miss Howard who would attend to anything like that.”
speaker: Dorcas

dialogue: “Don’t remember. Lots of parcels come. Can’t remember one special one.”
speaker: Evelyn Howard

dialogue: “You do not know if it was sent after Mr. Lawrence Cavendish to Wales, or whether it was put in his room?”
speaker: Mr. Philips

dialogue: “Don’t think it was sent after him. Should have remembered it if it was.”
speaker: Evelyn Howard

dialogue: “Supposing a parcel arrived addressed to Mr. Lawrence Cavendish, and afterwards it disappeared, should you remark its absence?”
speaker: Mr. Philips

dialogue: “No, don’t think so. I should think someone had taken charge of it.”
speaker: Evelyn Howard

dialogue: “I believe, Miss Howard, that it was you who found this sheet of brown paper?”
speaker: Mr. Philips

dialogue: “Yes, I did.”
speaker: Evelyn Howard

dialogue: “How did you come to look for it?”
speaker: Mr. Philips

dialogue: “The Belgian detective who was employed on the case asked me to search for it.”
speaker: Evelyn Howard

dialogue: “Where did you eventually discover it?”
speaker: Mr. Philips

dialogue: “On the top of—of—a wardrobe.”
speaker: Evelyn Howard

dialogue: “On top of the prisoner’s wardrobe?”
speaker: Mr. Philips

dialogue: “I—I believe so.”
speaker: Evelyn Howard

dialogue: “Did you not find it yourself?”
speaker: Mr. Philips

dialogue: “Yes.”
speaker: Evelyn Howard

dialogue: “Then you must know where you found it?”
speaker: Mr. Philips

dialogue: “Yes, it was on the prisoner’s wardrobe.”
speaker: Evelyn Howard

dialogue: “That is better.”
speaker: Mr. Philips

dialogue: “Where was the letter written from?”
speaker: Sir Ernest Heavywether

dialogue: “From Styles Court.”
speaker: Parkson's Assistant

dialogue: “The same address to which you sent the parcel?”
speaker: Sir Ernest Heavywether

dialogue: “Yes.”
speaker: Parkson's Assistant

dialogue: “And the letter came from there?”
speaker: Sir Ernest Heavywether

dialogue: “Yes.”
speaker: Parkson's Assistant

dialogue: “How do you know?”
speaker: Sir Ernest Heavywether

dialogue: “I—I don’t understand.”
speaker: Parkson's Assistant

dialogue: “How do you know that letter came from Styles? Did you notice the postmark?”
speaker: Sir Ernest Heavywether

dialogue: “No—but——”
speaker: Parkson's Assistant

dialogue: “Ah, you did not notice the postmark! And yet you affirm so confidently that it came from Styles. It might, in fact, have been any postmark?”
speaker: Sir Ernest Heavywether

dialogue: “Y—es.”
speaker: Parkson's Assistant

dialogue: “In fact, the letter, though written on stamped notepaper, might have been posted from anywhere? From Wales, for instance?”
speaker: Sir Ernest Heavywether

dialogue: “That hateful man! What a net he has drawn around my poor John! How he twisted every little fact until he made it seem what it wasn’t!”
speaker: Mary Cavendish

dialogue: “Well,”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “it will be the other way about to-morrow.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Yes,”
speaker: Mary Cavendish

dialogue: “Mr. Hastings, you do not think—surely it could not have been Lawrence—Oh, no, that could not be!”
speaker: Mary Cavendish

dialogue: “Ah!”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “He is a clever man, that Sir Ernest.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Do you think he believes Lawrence guilty?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “I do not think he believes or cares anything! No, what he is trying for is to create such confusion in the minds of the jury that they are divided in their opinion as to which brother did it. He is endeavouring to make out that there is quite as much evidence against Lawrence as against John—and I am not at all sure that he will not succeed.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Acting on information received, Superintendent Summerhaye and myself searched the prisoner’s room, during his temporary absence from the house. In his chest of drawers, hidden beneath some underclothing, we found: first, a pair of gold-rimmed pince-nez similar to those worn by Mr. Inglethorp”
speaker: Inspector Japp

dialogue: “secondly, this phial.”
speaker: Inspector Japp

dialogue: “What day was it when you searched the prisoner’s room?”
speaker: Sir Ernest Heavywether

dialogue: “Tuesday, the 24th of July.”
speaker: Inspector Japp

dialogue: “Exactly a week after the tragedy?”
speaker: Sir Ernest Heavywether

dialogue: “Yes.”
speaker: Inspector Japp

dialogue: “You found these two objects, you say, in the chest of drawers. Was the drawer unlocked?”
speaker: Sir Ernest Heavywether

dialogue: “Yes.”
speaker: Inspector Japp

dialogue: “Does it not strike you as unlikely that a man who had committed a crime should keep the evidence of it in an unlocked drawer for anyone to find?”
speaker: Sir Ernest Heavywether

dialogue: “He might have stowed them there in a hurry.”
speaker: Inspector Japp

dialogue: “But you have just said it was a whole week since the crime. He would have had ample time to remove them and destroy them.”
speaker: Sir Ernest Heavywether

dialogue: “Perhaps.”
speaker: Inspector Japp

dialogue: “There is no perhaps about it. Would he, or would he not have had plenty of time to remove and destroy them?”
speaker: Sir Ernest Heavywether

dialogue: “Yes.”
speaker: Inspector Japp

dialogue: “Was the pile of underclothes under which the things were hidden heavy or light?”
speaker: Sir Ernest Heavywether

dialogue: “Heavyish.”
speaker: Inspector Japp

dialogue: “In other words, it was winter underclothing. Obviously, the prisoner would not be likely to go to that drawer?”
speaker: Sir Ernest Heavywether

dialogue: “Perhaps not.”
speaker: Inspector Japp

dialogue: “Kindly answer my question. Would the prisoner, in the hottest week of a hot summer, be likely to go to a drawer containing winter underclothing. Yes, or no?”
speaker: Sir Ernest Heavywether

dialogue: “No.”
speaker: Inspector Japp

dialogue: “In that case, is it not possible that the articles in question might have been put there by a third person, and that the prisoner was quite unaware of their presence?”
speaker: Sir Ernest Heavywether

dialogue: “I should not think it likely.”
speaker: Inspector Japp

dialogue: “But it is possible?”
speaker: Sir Ernest Heavywether

dialogue: “Yes.”
speaker: Inspector Japp

dialogue: “That is all.”
speaker: Sir Ernest Heavywether

dialogue: “You deny having ordered a black beard from Parkson’s on June 29th?”
speaker: Sir Ernest Heavywether

dialogue: “I do.”
speaker: Lawrence Cavendish

dialogue: “Ah! In the event of anything happening to your brother, who will inherit Styles Court?”
speaker: Sir Ernest Heavywether

dialogue: “Answer my question, if you please.”
speaker: Sir Ernest Heavywether

dialogue: “I suppose,”
speaker: Lawrence Cavendish

dialogue: “that I should.”
speaker: Lawrence Cavendish

dialogue: “What do you mean by you ‘suppose’? Your brother has no children. You would inherit it, wouldn’t you?”
speaker: Sir Ernest Heavywether

dialogue: “Yes.”
speaker: Lawrence Cavendish

dialogue: “Ah, that’s better,”
speaker: Sir Ernest Heavywether

dialogue: “And you’d inherit a good slice of money too, wouldn’t you?”
speaker: Sir Ernest Heavywether

dialogue: “Really, Sir Ernest,”
speaker: Judge

dialogue: “these questions are not relevant.”
speaker: Judge

dialogue: “On Tuesday, the 17th July, you went, I believe, with another guest, to visit the dispensary at the Red Cross Hospital in Tadminster?”
speaker: Sir Ernest Heavywether

dialogue: “Yes.”
speaker: Lawrence Cavendish

dialogue: “Did you—while you happened to be alone for a few seconds—unlock the poison cupboard, and examine some of the bottles?”
speaker: Sir Ernest Heavywether

dialogue: “I—I—may have done so.”
speaker: Lawrence Cavendish

dialogue: “I put it to you that you did do so?”
speaker: Sir Ernest Heavywether

dialogue: “Yes.”
speaker: Lawrence Cavendish

dialogue: “Did you examine one bottle in particular?”
speaker: Sir Ernest Heavywether

dialogue: “No, I do not think so.”
speaker: Lawrence Cavendish

dialogue: “Be careful, Mr. Cavendish. I am referring to a little bottle of Hydro-chloride of Strychnine.”
speaker: Sir Ernest Heavywether

dialogue: “N—o—I am sure I didn’t.”
speaker: Lawrence Cavendish

dialogue: “Then how do you account for the fact that you left the unmistakable impress of your finger-prints on it?”
speaker: Sir Ernest Heavywether

dialogue: “I—I suppose I must have taken up the bottle.”
speaker: Lawrence Cavendish

dialogue: “I suppose so too! Did you abstract any of the contents of the bottle?”
speaker: Sir Ernest Heavywether

dialogue: “Certainly not.”
speaker: Lawrence Cavendish

dialogue: “Then why did you take it up?”
speaker: Sir Ernest Heavywether

dialogue: “I once studied to be a doctor. Such things naturally interest me.”
speaker: Lawrence Cavendish

dialogue: “Ah! So poisons ‘naturally interest’ you, do they? Still, you waited to be alone before gratifying that ‘interest’ of yours?”
speaker: Sir Ernest Heavywether

dialogue: “That was pure chance. If the others had been there, I should have done just the same.”
speaker: Lawrence Cavendish

dialogue: “Still, as it happens, the others were not there?”
speaker: Sir Ernest Heavywether

dialogue: “No, but——”
speaker: Lawrence Cavendish

dialogue: “In fact, during the whole afternoon, you were only alone for a couple of minutes, and it happened—I say, it happened—to be during those two minutes that you displayed your ‘natural interest’ in Hydro-chloride of Strychnine?”
speaker: Sir Ernest Heavywether

dialogue: “I have nothing more to ask you, Mr. Cavendish.”
speaker: Sir Ernest Heavywether

dialogue: “I should like to make one thing clear. I utterly reject and disapprove of Sir Ernest Heavywether’s insinuations against my brother. My brother, I am convinced, had no more to do with the crime than I have.”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “I understand you to say that it never entered your head that the witnesses at the inquest could possibly have mistaken your voice for that of Mr. Inglethorp. Is not that very surprising?”
speaker: Mr. Philips

dialogue: “No, I don’t think so. I was told there had been a quarrel between my mother and Mr. Inglethorp, and it never occurred to me that such was not really the case.”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “Not when the servant Dorcas repeated certain fragments of the conversation—fragments which you must have recognized?”
speaker: Mr. Philips

dialogue: “I did not recognize them.”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “Your memory must be unusually short!”
speaker: Mr. Philips

dialogue: “No, but we were both angry, and, I think, said more than we meant. I paid very little attention to my mother’s actual words.”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “You have produced this note very opportunely. Tell me, is there nothing familiar about the hand-writing of it?”
speaker: Mr. Philips

dialogue: “Not that I know of.”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “Do you not think that it bears a marked resemblance to your own hand-writing—carelessly disguised?”
speaker: Mr. Philips

dialogue: “No, I do not think so.”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “I put it to you that it is your own hand-writing!”
speaker: Mr. Philips

dialogue: “No.”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “I put it to you that, anxious to prove an alibi, you conceived the idea of a fictitious and rather incredible appointment, and wrote this note yourself in order to bear out your statement!”
speaker: Mr. Philips

dialogue: “No.”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “Is it not a fact that, at the time you claim to have been waiting about at a solitary and unfrequented spot, you were really in the chemist’s shop in Styles St. Mary, where you purchased strychnine in the name of Alfred Inglethorp?”
speaker: Mr. Philips

dialogue: “No, that is a lie.”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “I put it to you that, wearing a suit of Mr. Inglethorp’s clothes, with a black beard trimmed to resemble his, you were there—and signed the register in his name!”
speaker: Mr. Philips

dialogue: “That is absolutely untrue.”
speaker: John Cavendish

dialogue: “Then I will leave the remarkable similarity of hand-writing between the note, the register, and your own, to the consideration of the jury,”
speaker: Mr. Philips

dialogue: “What is it, Poirot?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Ah, mon ami, things are going badly, badly.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “No, I thank you, madame. I will mount to my room.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “No, mon ami, I am not in my second childhood! I steady my nerves, that is all. This employment requires precision of the fingers. With precision of the fingers goes precision of the brain. And never have I needed that more than now!”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “What is the trouble?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “It is this, mon ami! That I can build card houses seven stories high, but I cannot”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “find”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “ that last link of which I spoke to you.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “It is done—so! By placing—one card—on another—with mathematical—precision!”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “What a steady hand you’ve got,”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “I believe I’ve only seen your hand shake once.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “On an occasion when I was enraged, without doubt,”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Yes indeed! You were in a towering rage. Do you remember? It was when you discovered that the lock of the despatch-case in Mrs. Inglethorp’s bedroom had been forced. You stood by the mantelpiece, twiddling the things on it in your usual fashion, and your hand shook like a leaf! I must say——”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Good heavens, Poirot!”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “What is the matter? Are you taken ill?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “No, no,”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “It is—it is—that I have an idea!”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Oh!”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “One of your ‘little ideas’?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Ah, ma foi, no!”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “This time it is an idea gigantic! Stupendous! And you—you, my friend, have given it to me!”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “What is the matter with Monsieur Poirot? He rushed past me crying out: ‘A garage! For the love of Heaven, direct me to a garage, madame!’ And, before I could answer, he had dashed out into the street.”
speaker: Mary Cavendish

dialogue: “He’ll be stopped by a policeman in another minute. There he goes, round the corner!”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “What can be the matter?”
speaker: Mary Cavendish

dialogue: “I don’t know. He was building card houses, when suddenly he said he had an idea, and rushed off as you saw.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Well,”
speaker: Mary Cavendish

dialogue: “I expect he will be back before dinner.”
speaker: Mary Cavendish

dialogue: “Madame, I have your permission to hold a little réunion in the salon? It is necessary for everyone to attend.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “You know, Monsieur Poirot, that you have carte blanche in every way.”
speaker: Mary Cavendish

dialogue: “You are too amiable, madame.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Miss Howard—here. Mademoiselle Cynthia. Monsieur Lawrence. The good Dorcas. And Annie. Bien! We must delay our proceedings a few minutes until Mr. Inglethorp arrives. I have sent him a note.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Miss Howard—here. Mademoiselle Cynthia. Monsieur Lawrence. The good Dorcas. And Annie. Bien! We must delay our proceedings a few minutes until Mr. Inglethorp arrives. I have sent him a note.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Miss Howard—here. Mademoiselle Cynthia. Monsieur Lawrence. The good Dorcas. And Annie. Bien! We must delay our proceedings a few minutes until Mr. Inglethorp arrives. I have sent him a note.”

speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Miss Howard—here. Mademoiselle Cynthia. Monsieur Lawrence. The good Dorcas. And Annie. Bien! We must delay our proceedings a few minutes until Mr. Inglethorp arrives. I have sent him a note.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “If that man comes into the house, I leave it!”
speaker: Evelyn Howard

dialogue: “No, no!”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Messieurs, mesdames, as you all know, I was called in by Monsieur John Cavendish to investigate this case. I at once examined the bedroom of the deceased which, by the advice of the doctors, had been kept locked, and was consequently exactly as it had been when the tragedy occurred. I found: first, a fragment of green material; second, a stain on the carpet near the window, still damp; thirdly, an empty box of bromide powders.
speaker: Hercule Poirot

speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “To take the fragment of green material first, I found it caught in the bolt of the communicating door between that room and the adjoining one occupied by Mademoiselle Cynthia. I handed the fragment over to the police who did not consider it of much importance. Nor did they recognize it for what it was—a piece torn from a green land armlet.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Now there was only one person at Styles who worked on the land—Mrs. Cavendish. Therefore it must have been Mrs. Cavendish who entered the deceased’s room through the door communicating with Mademoiselle Cynthia’s room.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “But that door was bolted on the inside!”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “When I examined the room, yes. But in the first place we have only her word for it, since it was she who tried that particular door and reported it fastened. In the ensuing confusion she would have had ample opportunity to shoot the bolt across. I took an early opportunity of verifying my conjectures. To begin with, the fragment corresponds exactly with a tear in Mrs. Cavendish’s armlet. Also, at the inquest, Mrs. Cavendish declared that she had heard, from her own room, the fall of the table by the bed. I took an early opportunity of testing that statement by stationing my friend Monsieur Hastings in the left wing of the building, just outside Mrs. Cavendish’s door. I myself, in company with the police, went to the deceased’s room, and whilst there I, apparently accidentally, knocked over the table in question, but found that, as I had expected, Monsieur Hastings had heard no sound at all. This confirmed my belief that Mrs. Cavendish was not speaking the truth when she declared that she had been dressing in her room at the time of the tragedy. In fact, I was convinced that, far from having been in her own room, Mrs. Cavendish was actually in the deceased’s room when the alarm was given.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “I proceeded to reason on that assumption. Mrs. Cavendish is in her mother-in-law’s room. We will say that she is seeking for something and has not yet found it. Suddenly Mrs. Inglethorp awakens and is seized with an alarming paroxysm. She flings out her arm, overturning the bed table, and then pulls desperately at the bell. Mrs. Cavendish, startled, drops her candle, scattering the grease on the carpet. She picks it up, and retreats quickly to Mademoiselle Cynthia’s room, closing the door behind her. She hurries out into the passage, for the servants must not find her where she is. But it is too late! Already footsteps are echoing along the gallery which connects the two wings. What can she do? Quick as thought, she hurries back to the young girl’s room, and starts shaking her awake. The hastily aroused household come trooping down the passage. They are all busily battering at Mrs. Inglethorp’s door. It occurs to nobody that Mrs. Cavendish has not arrived with the rest, but—and this is significant—I can find no one who saw her come from the other wing.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Am I right, madame?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Quite right, monsieur. You understand that, if I had thought I would do my husband any good by revealing these facts, I would have done so. But it did not seem to me to bear upon the question of his guilt or innocence.”
speaker: Mary Cavendish

dialogue: “In a sense, that is correct, madame. But it cleared my mind of many misconceptions, and left me free to see other facts in their true significance.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “The will!”
speaker: Lawrence Cavendish

dialogue: “Then it was you, Mary, who destroyed the will?”
speaker: Lawrence Cavendish

dialogue: “No,”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “There is only one person who could possibly have destroyed that will—Mrs. Inglethorp herself!”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Impossible!”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “She had only made it out that very afternoon!”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Nevertheless, mon ami, it was Mrs. Inglethorp. Because, in no other way can you account for the fact that, on one of the hottest days of the year, Mrs. Inglethorp ordered a fire to be lighted in her room.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “The temperature on that day, messieurs, was 80 degrees in the shade. Yet Mrs. Inglethorp ordered a fire! Why? Because she wished to destroy something, and could think of no other way. You will remember that, in consequence of the War economics practiced at Styles, no waste paper was thrown away. There was therefore no means of destroying a thick document such as a will. The moment I heard of a fire being lighted in Mrs. Inglethorp’s room, I leaped to the conclusion that it was to destroy some important document—possibly a will. So the discovery of the charred fragment in the grate was no surprise to me. I did not, of course, know at the time that the will in question had only been made this afternoon, and I will admit that, when I learnt that fact, I fell into a grievous error. I came to the conclusion that Mrs. Inglethorp’s determination to destroy her will arose as a direct consequence of the quarrel she had that afternoon, and that therefore the quarrel took place after, and not before the making of the will.
speaker: Hercule Poirot

You will remember that, in consequence of the War economics practiced at Styles, no waste paper was thrown away. There was therefore no means of destroying a thick document such as a will. The moment I heard of a fire being lighted in Mrs. Inglethorp’s room, I leaped to the conclusion that it was to destroy some important document—possibly a will. So the discovery of the charred fragment in the grate was no surprise to me. I did not, of course, know at the time that the will in question had only been made this afternoon, and I will admit that, when I learnt that fact, I fell into a grievous error. I came to the conclusion that Mrs. Inglethorp’s determination to destroy her will arose as a direct consequence of the quarrel she had that afternoon, and that therefore the quarrel took place after, and not before the making of the will.
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Here, as we know, I was wrong, and I was forced to abandon that idea. I faced the problem from a new standpoint. Now, at four o’clock, Dorcas overheard her mistress saying angrily: ‘You need not think that any fear of publicity, or scandal between husband and wife will deter me.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Looking at the matter psychologically, I drew one deduction which I was convinced was correct. The second ‘scandal’ she spoke of was not the same as the first—and it concerned herself!
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Let us reconstruct. At four o’clock, Mrs. Inglethorp quarrels with her son, and threatens to denounce him to his wife—who, by the way, overheard the greater part of the conversation. At four-thirty, Mrs. Inglethorp, in consequence of a conversation on the validity of wills, makes a will in favour of her husband, which the two gardeners witness. At five o’clock, Dorcas finds her mistress in a state of considerable agitation, with a slip of paper—‘a letter,’ Dorcas thinks—in her hand, and it is then that she orders the fire in her room to be lighted. Presumably, then, between four-thirty and five o’clock, something has occurred to occasion a complete revolution of feeling, since she is now as anxious to destroy the will, as she was before to make it. What was that something?
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “As far as we know, she was quite alone during that half-hour. Nobody entered or left that boudoir. What then occasioned this sudden change of sentiment?
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “One can only guess, but I believe my guess to be correct. Mrs. Inglethorp had no stamps in her desk. We know this, because later she asked Dorcas to bring her some. Now in the opposite corner of the room stood her husband’s desk—locked. She was anxious to find some stamps, and, according to my theory, she tried her own keys in the desk. That one of them fitted I know. She therefore opened the desk, and in searching for the stamps she came across something else—that slip of paper which Dorcas saw in her hand, and which assuredly was never meant for Mrs. Inglethorp’s eyes. On the other hand, Mrs. Cavendish believed that the slip of paper to which her mother-in-law clung so tenaciously was a written proof of her own husband’s infidelity. She demanded it from Mrs. Inglethorp who assured her, quite truly, that it had nothing to do with that matter. Mrs. Cavendish did not believe her. She thought that Mrs. Inglethorp was shielding her stepson. Now Mrs. Cavendish is a very resolute woman, and, behind her mask of reserve, she was madly jealous of her husband. She determined to get hold of that paper at all costs, and in this resolution chance came to her aid. She happened to pick up the key of Mrs. Inglethorp’s despatch-case, which had been lost that morning. She knew that her mother-in-law invariably kept all important papers in this particular case.
speaker: Hercule Poirot

She happened to pick up the key of Mrs. Inglethorp’s despatch-case, which had been lost that morning. She knew that her mother-in-law invariably kept all important papers in this particular case.
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “One can only guess, but I believe my guess to be correct. Mrs. Inglethorp had no stamps in her desk. We know this, because later she asked Dorcas to bring her some. Now in the opposite corner of the room stood her husband’s desk—locked. She was anxious to find some stamps, and, according to my theory, she tried her own keys in the desk. That one of them fitted I know. She therefore opened the desk, and in searching for the stamps she came across something else—that slip of paper which Dorcas saw in her hand, and which assuredly was never meant for Mrs. Inglethorp’s eyes. On the other hand, Mrs. Cavendish believed that the slip of paper to which her mother-in-law clung so tenaciously was a written proof of her own husband’s infidelity. She demanded it from Mrs. Inglethorp who assured her, quite truly, that it had nothing to do with that matter. Mrs. Cavendish did not believe her. She thought that Mrs. Inglethorp was shielding her stepson. Now Mrs. Cavendish is a very resolute woman, and, behind her mask of reserve, she was madly jealous of her husband. She determined to get hold of that paper at all costs, and in this resolution chance came to her aid. dialogue: “Mrs. Cavendish, therefore, made her plans as only a woman driven desperate through jealousy could have done. Some time in the evening she unbolted the door leading into Mademoiselle Cynthia’s room. Possibly she applied oil to the hinges, for I found that it opened quite noiselessly when I tried it. She put off her project until the early hours of the morning as being safer, since the servants were accustomed to hearing her move about her room at that time. She dressed completely in her land kit, and made her way quietly through Mademoiselle Cynthia’s room into that of Mrs. Inglethorp.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “With this latter idea in my mind, I examined all the coffee-cups most carefully, remembering that it was Mrs. Cavendish who had brought Mademoiselle Cynthia her coffee the night before. I took a sample from each cup, and had them analysed—with no result. I had counted the cups carefully, in the event of one having been removed. Six persons had taken coffee, and six cups were duly found. I had to confess myself mistaken.
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Then I discovered that I had been guilty of a very grave oversight. Coffee had been brought in for seven persons, not six, for Dr. Bauerstein had been there that evening. This changed the face of the whole affair, for there was now one cup missing. The servants noticed nothing, since Annie, the housemaid, who took in the coffee, brought in seven cups, not knowing that Mr. Inglethorp never drank it, whereas Dorcas, who cleared them away the following morning, found six as usual—or strictly speaking she found five, the sixth being the one found broken in Mrs. Inglethorp’s room.
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “I was confident that the missing cup was that of Mademoiselle Cynthia. I had an additional reason for that belief in the fact that all the cups found contained sugar, which Mademoiselle Cynthia never took in her coffee. My attention was attracted by the story of Annie about some ‘salt’ on the tray of cocoa which she took every night to Mrs. Inglethorp’s room. I accordingly secured a sample of that cocoa, and sent it to be analysed.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “But that had already been done by Dr. Bauerstein,”
speaker: Lawrence Cavendish

dialogue: “Not exactly. The analyst was asked by him to report whether strychnine was, or was not, present. He did not have it tested, as I did, for a narcotic.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “For a narcotic?”
speaker: Lawrence Cavendish

dialogue: “Yes. Here is the analyst’s report. Mrs. Cavendish administered a safe, but effectual, narcotic to both Mrs. Inglethorp and Mademoiselle Cynthia. And it is possible that she had a mauvais quart d’heure in consequence! Imagine her feelings when her mother-in-law is suddenly taken ill and dies, and immediately after she hears the word ‘Poison’! She has believed that the sleeping draught she administered was perfectly harmless, but there is no doubt that for one terrible moment she must have feared that Mrs. Inglethorp’s death lay at her door. She is seized with panic, and under its influence she hurries downstairs, and quickly drops the coffee-cup and saucer used by Mademoiselle Cynthia into a large brass vase, where it is discovered later by Monsieur Lawrence. The remains of the cocoa she dare not touch. Too many eyes are upon her. Guess at her relief when strychnine is mentioned, and she discovers that after all the tragedy is not her doing.
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Yes. Here is the analyst’s report. Mrs. Cavendish administered a safe, but effectual, narcotic to both Mrs. Inglethorp and Mademoiselle Cynthia. And it is possible that she had a mauvais quart d’heure in consequence! Imagine her feelings when her mother-in-law is suddenly taken ill and dies, and immediately after she hears the word ‘Poison’! She has believed that the sleeping draught she administered was perfectly harmless, but there is no doubt that for one terrible moment she must have feared that Mrs. Inglethorp’s death lay at her door. She is seized with panic, and under its influence she hurries downstairs, and quickly drops the coffee-cup and saucer used by Mademoiselle Cynthia into a large brass vase, where it is discovered later by Monsieur Lawrence. The remains of the cocoa she dare not touch. Too many eyes are upon her. Guess at her relief when strychnine is mentioned, and she discovers that after all the tragedy is not her doing.
speaker: Hercule Poirot
