dialogue: “We are now able to account for the symptoms of strychnine poisoning being so long in making their appearance. A narcotic taken with strychnine will delay the action of the poison for some hours.”

dialogue: “All you have said is quite true, Monsieur Poirot. It was the most awful hour of my life. I shall never forget it. But you are wonderful. I understand now——”
speaker: Mary Cavendish

dialogue: “What I meant when I told you that you could safely confess to Papa Poirot, eh? But you would not trust me.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “I see everything now,”
speaker: Lawrence Cavendish

dialogue: “The drugged cocoa, taken on top of the poisoned coffee, amply accounts for the delay.”
speaker: Lawrence Cavendish

dialogue: “Exactly. But was the coffee poisoned, or was it not? We come to a little difficulty here, since Mrs. Inglethorp never drank it.”

dialogue: “No. You will remember my speaking of a stain on the carpet in Mrs. Inglethorp’s room? There were some peculiar points about that stain. It was still damp, it exhaled a strong odour of coffee, and imbedded in the nap of the carpet I found some little splinters of china. What had happened was plain to me, for not two minutes before I had placed my little case on the table near the window, and the table, tilting up, had deposited it upon the floor on precisely the identical spot. In exactly the same way, Mrs. Inglethorp had laid down her cup of coffee on reaching her room the night before, and the treacherous table had played her the same trick.
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “What happened next is mere guess work on my part, but I should say that Mrs. Inglethorp picked up the broken cup and placed it on the table by the bed. Feeling in need of a stimulant of some kind, she heated up her cocoa, and drank it off then and there. Now we are faced with a new problem. We know the cocoa contained no strychnine. The coffee was never drunk. Yet the strychnine must have been administered between seven and nine o’clock that evening. What third medium was there—a medium so suitable for disguising the taste of strychnine that it is extraordinary no one has thought of it?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “There was no need to introduce it. It was already there—in the mixture. The strychnine that killed Mrs. Inglethorp was the identical strychnine prescribed by Dr. Wilkins. dialogue: “There was no need to introduce it. It was already there—in the mixture. The strychnine that killed Mrs. Inglethorp was the identical strychnine prescribed by Dr. Wilkins. To make that clear to you, I will read you an extract from a book on dispensing which I found in the Dispensary of the Red Cross Hospital at Tadminster:
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue:
“‘The following prescription has become famous in text books:
Strychninae Sulph. . . . . .1 gr.
Potass Bromide . . . . . . .3vi
Aqua ad. . . . . . . . . . . . .3viii
Fiat Mistura

dialogue: This solution deposits in a few hours the greater part of the strychnine salt as an insoluble bromide in transparent crystals. A lady in England lost her life by taking a similar mixture: the precipitated strychnine collected at the bottom, and in taking the last dose she swallowed nearly all of it!
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Now there was, of course, no bromide in Dr. Wilkins’ prescription, but you will remember that I mentioned an empty box of bromide powders. One or two of those powders introduced into the full bottle of medicine would effectually precipitate the strychnine, as the book describes, and cause it to be taken in the last dose. You will learn later that the person who usually poured out Mrs. Inglethorp’s medicine was always extremely careful not to shake the bottle, but to leave the sediment at the bottom of it undisturbed.
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Throughout the case, there have been evidences that the tragedy was intended to take place on Monday evening. On that day, Mrs. Inglethorp’s bell wire was neatly cut, and on Monday evening Mademoiselle Cynthia was spending the night with friends, so that Mrs. Inglethorp would have been quite alone in the right wing, completely shut off from help of any kind, and would have died, in all probability, before medical aid could have been summoned. But in her hurry to be in time for the village entertainment Mrs. Inglethorp forgot to take her medicine, and the next day she lunched away from home, so that the last—and fatal—dose was actually taken twenty-four hours later than had been anticipated by the murderer; and it is owing to that delay that the final proof—the last link of the chain—is now in my hands.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “A letter in the murderer’s own hand-writing, mes amis! Had it been a little clearer in its terms, it is possible that Mrs. Inglethorp, warned in time, would have escaped. As it was, she realized her danger, but not the manner of it.”

dialogue: “Poirot, you old villain,”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “I’ve half a mind to strangle you! What do you mean by deceiving me as you have done?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “I did not deceive you, mon ami. At most, I permitted you to deceive yourself.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Yes, but why?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Well, it is difficult to explain. You see, my friend, you have a nature so honest, and a countenance so transparent, that—enfin, to conceal your feelings is impossible! If I had told you my ideas, the very first time you saw Mr. Alfred Inglethorp that astute gentleman would have—in your so expressive idiom—‘smelt a rat’! And then, bonjour to our chances of catching him!”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “I think that I have more diplomacy than you give me credit for.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “My friend,”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “I implore you, do not enrage yourself! Your help has been of the most invaluable. It is but the extremely beautiful nature that you have, which made me pause.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Well,”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “I still think you might have given me a hint.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “But I did, my friend. Several hints. You would not take them. Think now, did I ever say to you that I believed John Cavendish guilty? Did I not, on the contrary, tell you that he would almost certainly be acquitted?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Yes, but——”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “And did I not immediately afterwards speak of the difficulty of bringing the murderer to justice? Was it not plain to you that I was speaking of two entirely different persons?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “No,”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “it was not plain to me!”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Then again,”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “at the beginning, did I not repeat to you several times that I didn’t want Mr. Inglethorp arrested now? That should have conveyed something to you.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Do you mean to say you suspected him as long ago as that?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Yes. To begin with, whoever else might benefit by Mrs. Inglethorp’s death, her husband would benefit the most. There was no getting away from that. When I went up to Styles with you that first day, I had no idea as to how the crime had been committed, but from what I knew of Mr. Inglethorp I fancied that it would be very hard to find anything to connect him with it. When I arrived at the château, I realized at once that it was Mrs. Inglethorp who had burnt the will; and there, by the way, you cannot complain, my friend, for I tried my best to force on you the significance of that bedroom fire in midsummer.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Yes, yes,”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Go on.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Well, my friend, as I say, my views as to Mr. Inglethorp’s guilt were very much shaken. There was, in fact, so much evidence against him that I was inclined to believe that he had not done it.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “When did you change your mind?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “When I found that the more efforts I made to clear him, the more efforts he made to get himself arrested. Then, when I discovered that Inglethorp had nothing to do with Mrs. Raikes and that in fact it was John Cavendish who was interested in that quarter, I was quite sure.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “But why?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Simply this. If it had been Inglethorp who was carrying on an intrigue with Mrs. Raikes, his silence was perfectly comprehensible. But, when I discovered that it was known all over the village that it was John who was attracted by the farmer’s pretty wife, his silence bore quite a different interpretation. It was nonsense to pretend that he was afraid of the scandal, as no possible scandal could attach to him. This attitude of his gave me furiously to think, and I was slowly forced to the conclusion that Alfred Inglethorp wanted to be arrested. Eh bien! from that moment, I was equally determined that he should not be arrested.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Wait a minute. I don’t see why he wished to be arrested?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Because, mon ami, it is the law of your country that a man once acquitted can never be tried again for the same offence. Aha! but it was clever—his idea! Assuredly, he is a man of method. See here, he knew that in his position he was bound to be suspected, so he conceived the exceedingly clever idea of preparing a lot of manufactured evidence against himself. He wished to be arrested. He would then produce his irreproachable alibi—and, hey presto, he was safe for life!”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “But I still don’t see how he managed to prove his alibi, and yet go to the chemist’s shop?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Is it possible? My poor friend! You have not yet realized that it was Miss Howard who went to the chemist’s shop?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Miss Howard?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “But, certainly. Who else? It was most easy for her. She is of a good height, her voice is deep and manly; moreover, remember, she and Inglethorp are cousins, and there is a distinct resemblance between them, especially in their gait and bearing. It was simplicity itself. They are a clever pair!”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “I am still a little fogged as to how exactly the bromide business was done,”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Bon! I will reconstruct for you as far as possible. I am inclined to think that Miss Howard was the master mind in that affair. You remember her once mentioning that her father was a doctor? Possibly she dispensed his medicines for him, or she may have taken the idea from one of the many books lying about when Mademoiselle Cynthia was studying for her exam. Anyway, she was familiar with the fact that the addition of a bromide to a mixture containing strychnine would cause the precipitation of the latter. Probably the idea came to her quite suddenly. Mrs. Inglethorp had a box of bromide powders, which she occasionally took at night. What could be easier than quietly to dissolve one or more of those powders in Mrs. Inglethorp’s large sized bottle of medicine when it came from Coot’s? The risk is practically nil. The tragedy will not take place until nearly a fortnight later. If anyone has seen either of them touching the medicine, they will have forgotten it by that time. Miss Howard will have engineered her quarrel, and departed from the house. The lapse of time, and her absence, will defeat all suspicion. Yes, it was a clever idea! If they had left it alone, it is possible the crime might never have been brought home to them. But they were not satisfied. They tried to be too clever—and that was their undoing.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “They arranged a plan to throw suspicion on John Cavendish, by buying strychnine at the village chemist’s, and signing the register in his hand-writing.
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “On Monday Mrs. Inglethorp will take the last dose of her medicine. On Monday, therefore, at six o’clock, Alfred Inglethorp arranges to be seen by a number of people at a spot far removed from the village. Miss Howard has previously made up a cock and bull story about him and Mrs. Raikes to account for his holding his tongue afterwards. At six o’clock, Miss Howard, disguised as Alfred Inglethorp, enters the chemist’s shop, with her story about a dog, obtains the strychnine, and writes the name of Alfred Inglethorp in John’s handwriting, which she had previously studied carefully.
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “But, as it will never do if John, too, can prove an alibi, she writes him an anonymous note—still copying his hand-writing—which takes him to a remote spot where it is exceedingly unlikely that anyone will see him.
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “So far, all goes well. Miss Howard goes back to Middlingham. Alfred Inglethorp returns to Styles. There is nothing that can compromise him in any way, since it is Miss Howard who has the strychnine, which, after all, is only wanted as a blind to throw suspicion on John Cavendish.
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “But now a hitch occurs. Mrs. Inglethorp does not take her medicine that night. The broken bell, Cynthia’s absence—arranged by Inglethorp through his wife—all these are wasted. And then—he makes his slip.
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Mrs. Inglethorp is out, and he sits down to write to his accomplice, who, he fears, may be in a panic at the non-success of their plan. It is probable that Mrs. Inglethorp returned earlier than he expected. Caught in the act, and somewhat flurried he hastily shuts and locks his desk. He fears that if he remains in the room he may have to open it again, and that Mrs. Inglethorp might catch sight of the letter before he could snatch it up. So he goes out and walks in the woods, little dreaming that Mrs. Inglethorp will open his desk, and discover the incriminating document.
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “But this, as we know, is what happened. Mrs. Inglethorp reads it, and becomes aware of the perfidy of her husband and Evelyn Howard, though, unfortunately, the sentence about the bromides conveys no warning to her mind. She knows that she is in danger—but is ignorant of where the danger lies. She decides to say nothing to her husband, but sits down and writes to her solicitor, asking him to come on the morrow, and she also determines to destroy immediately the will which she has just made. She keeps the fatal letter.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “It was to discover that letter, then, that her husband forced the lock of the despatch-case?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Yes, and from the enormous risk he ran we can see how fully he realized its importance. That letter excepted, there was absolutely nothing to connect him with the crime.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “There’s only one thing I can’t make out, why didn’t he destroy it at once when he got hold of it?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Because he did not dare take the biggest risk of all—that of keeping it on his own person.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “I don’t understand.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Look at it from his point of view. I have discovered that there were only five short minutes in which he could have taken it—the five minutes immediately before our own arrival on the scene, for before that time Annie was brushing the stairs, and would have seen anyone who passed going to the right wing. Figure to yourself the scene! He enters the room, unlocking the door by means of one of the other doorkeys—they were all much alike. He hurries to the despatch-case—it is locked, and the keys are nowhere to be seen. That is a terrible blow to him, for it means that his presence in the room cannot be concealed as he had hoped. But he sees clearly that everything must be risked for the sake of that damning piece of evidence. Quickly, he forces the lock with a penknife, and turns over the papers until he finds what he is looking for.
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “But now a fresh dilemma arises: he dare not keep that piece of paper on him. He may be seen leaving the room—he may be searched. If the paper is found on him, it is certain doom. Probably, at this minute, too, he hears the sounds below of Mr. Wells and John leaving the boudoir. He must act quickly. Where can he hide this terrible slip of paper? The contents of the waste-paper-basket are kept and in any case, are sure to be examined. There are no means of destroying it; and he dare not keep it. He looks round, and he sees—what do you think, mon ami?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “In a moment, he has torn the letter into long thin strips, and rolling them up into spills he thrusts them hurriedly in amongst the other spills in the vase on the mantle-piece.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “No one would think of looking there,”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “And he will be able, at his leisure, to come back and destroy this solitary piece of evidence against him.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Then, all the time, it was in the spill vase in Mrs. Inglethorp’s bedroom, under our very noses?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Yes, my friend. That is where I discovered my ‘last link,’ and I owe that very fortunate discovery to you.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “To me?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Yes. Do you remember telling me that my hand shook as I was straightening the ornaments on the mantelpiece?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Yes, but I don’t see——”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “No, but I saw. Do you know, my friend, I remembered that earlier in the morning, when we had been there together, I had straightened all the objects on the mantelpiece. And, if they were already straightened, there would be no need to straighten them again, unless, in the meantime, someone else had touched them.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Dear me,”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “so that is the explanation of your extraordinary behaviour. You rushed down to Styles, and found it still there?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Yes, and it was a race for time.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “But I still can’t understand why Inglethorp was such a fool as to leave it there when he had plenty of opportunity to destroy it.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Ah, but he had no opportunity. I saw to that.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “You?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Yes. Do you remember reproving me for taking the household into my confidence on the subject?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Yes.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Well, my friend, I saw there was just one chance. I was not sure then if Inglethorp was the criminal or not, but if he was I reasoned that he would not have the paper on him, but would have hidden it somewhere, and by enlisting the sympathy of the household I could effectually prevent his destroying it. He was already under suspicion, and by making the matter public I secured the services of about ten amateur detectives, who would be watching him unceasingly, and being himself aware of their watchfulness he would not dare seek further to destroy the document. He was therefore forced to depart from the house, leaving it in the spill vase.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “But surely Miss Howard had ample opportunities of aiding him.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Yes, but Miss Howard did not know of the paper’s existence. In accordance with their prearranged plan, she never spoke to Alfred Inglethorp. They were supposed to be deadly enemies, and until John Cavendish was safely convicted they neither of them dared risk a meeting. Of course I had a watch kept on Mr. Inglethorp, hoping that sooner or later he would lead me to the hiding-place. But he was too clever to take any chances. The paper was safe where it was; since no one had thought of looking there in the first week, it was not likely they would do so afterwards. But for your lucky remark, we might never have been able to bring him to justice.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “I understand that now; but when did you first begin to suspect Miss Howard?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “When I discovered that she had told a lie at the inquest about the letter she had received from Mrs. Inglethorp.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Why, what was there to lie about?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “You saw that letter? Do you recall its general appearance?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Yes—more or less.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “You will recollect, then, that Mrs. Inglethorp wrote a very distinctive hand, and left large clear spaces between her words. But if you look at the date at the top of the letter you will notice that ‘July 17th’ is quite different in this respect. Do you see what I mean?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “No,”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “I don’t.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “You do not see that that letter was not written on the 17th, but on the 7th—the day after Miss Howard’s departure? The ‘1’ was written in before the ‘7’ to turn it into the ‘17th’.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “But why?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “That is exactly what I asked myself. Why does Miss Howard suppress the letter written on the 17th, and produce this faked one instead? Because she did not wish to show the letter of the 17th. Why, again? And at once a suspicion dawned in my mind. You will remember my saying that it was wise to beware of people who were not telling you the truth.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “And yet,”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “after that, you gave me two reasons why Miss Howard could not have committed the crime!”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “And very good reasons too,”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “For a long time they were a stumbling-block to me until I remembered a very significant fact: that she and Alfred Inglethorp were cousins. She could not have committed the crime single-handed, but the reasons against that did not debar her from being an accomplice. And, then, there was that rather over-vehement hatred of hers! It concealed a very opposite emotion. There was, undoubtedly, a tie of passion between them long before he came to Styles. They had already arranged their infamous plot—that he should marry this rich, but rather foolish old lady, induce her to make a will leaving her money to him, and then gain their ends by a very cleverly conceived crime. If all had gone as they planned, they would probably have left England, and lived together on their poor victim’s money.
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “They are a very astute and unscrupulous pair. While suspicion was to be directed against him, she would be making quiet preparations for a very different dénouement. She arrives from Middlingham with all the compromising items in her possession. No suspicion attaches to her. No notice is paid to her coming and going in the house. She hides the strychnine and glasses in John’s room. She puts the beard in the attic. She will see to it that sooner or later they are duly discovered.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “I don’t quite see why they tried to fix the blame on John,”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “It would have been much easier for them to bring the crime home to Lawrence.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Yes, but that was mere chance. All the evidence against him arose out of pure accident. It must, in fact, have been distinctly annoying to the pair of schemers.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “His manner was unfortunate,”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Yes. You realize, of course, what was at the back of that?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “No.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “You did not understand that he believed Mademoiselle Cynthia guilty of the crime?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “No,”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Impossible!”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Not at all. I myself nearly had the same idea. It was in my mind when I asked Mr. Wells that first question about the will. Then there were the bromide powders which she had made up, and her clever male impersonations, as Dorcas recounted them to us. There was really more evidence against her than anyone else.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “You are joking, Poirot!”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “No. Shall I tell you what made Monsieur Lawrence turn so pale when he first entered his mother’s room on the fatal night? It was because, whilst his mother lay there, obviously poisoned, he saw, over your shoulder, that the door into Mademoiselle Cynthia’s room was unbolted.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “But he declared that he saw it bolted!”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Exactly,”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “And that was just what confirmed my suspicion that it was not. He was shielding Mademoiselle Cynthia.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “But why should he shield her?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Because he is in love with her.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “There, Poirot, you are quite wrong! I happen to know for a fact that, far from being in love with her, he positively dislikes her.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Who told you that, mon ami?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Cynthia herself.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “La pauvre petite! And she was concerned?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “She said that she did not mind at all.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Then she certainly did mind very much,”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “They are like that—les femmes!”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “What you say about Lawrence is a great surprise to me,”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “But why? It was most obvious. Did not Monsieur Lawrence make the sour face every time Mademoiselle Cynthia spoke and laughed with his brother? He had taken it into his long head that Mademoiselle Cynthia was in love with Monsieur John. When he entered his mother’s room, and saw her obviously poisoned, he jumped to the conclusion that Mademoiselle Cynthia knew something about the matter. He was nearly driven desperate. First he crushed the coffee-cup to powder under his feet, remembering that she had gone up with his mother the night before, and he determined that there should be no chance of testing its contents. Thenceforward, he strenuously, and quite uselessly, upheld the theory of ‘Death from natural causes’.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “And what about the ‘extra coffee-cup’?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “I was fairly certain that it was Mrs. Cavendish who had hidden it, but I had to make sure. Monsieur Lawrence did not know at all what I meant; but, on reflection, he came to the conclusion that if he could find an extra coffee-cup anywhere his lady love would be cleared of suspicion. And he was perfectly right.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “One thing more. What did Mrs. Inglethorp mean by her dying words?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “They were, of course, an accusation against her husband.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Dear me, Poirot,”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “I think you have explained everything. I am glad it has all ended so happily. Even John and his wife are reconciled.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Thanks to me.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “How do you mean—thanks to you?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “My dear friend, do you not realize that it was simply and solely the trial which has brought them together again? That John Cavendish still loved his wife, I was convinced. Also, that she was equally in love with him. But they had drifted very far apart. It all arose from a misunderstanding. She married him without love. He knew it. He is a sensitive man in his way, he would not force himself upon her if she did not want him. And, as he withdrew, her love awoke. But they are both unusually proud, and their pride held them inexorably apart. He drifted into an entanglement with Mrs. Raikes, and she deliberately cultivated the friendship of Dr. Bauerstein. Do you remember the day of John Cavendish’s arrest, when you found me deliberating over a big decision?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Yes, I quite understood your distress.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Pardon me, mon ami, but you did not understand it in the least. I was trying to decide whether or not I would clear John Cavendish at once. I could have cleared him—though it might have meant a failure to convict the real criminals. They were entirely in the dark as to my real attitude up to the very last moment—which partly accounts for my success.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Do you mean that you could have saved John Cavendish from being brought to trial?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Yes, my friend. But I eventually decided in favour of ‘a woman’s happiness’. Nothing but the great danger through which they have passed could have brought these two proud souls together again.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “I perceive your thoughts, mon ami,”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “No one but Hercule Poirot would have attempted such a thing! And you are wrong in condemning it. The happiness of one man and one woman is the greatest thing in all the world.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Yes, madame,”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “I have brought him back to you.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Perhaps you are right, Poirot,”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Yes, it is the greatest thing in the world.”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “I—I only——”
speaker: Cynthia Murdoch

dialogue: “I—I only——”
speaker: Cynthia Murdoch

dialogue: “Come in,”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “I—only wanted to tell you something——”
speaker: Cynthia Murdoch

dialogue: “I—only wanted to tell you something——”
speaker: Cynthia Murdoch

dialogue: “Yes?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “You dears!”
speaker: Cynthia Murdoch

dialogue: “You dears!”
speaker: Cynthia Murdoch

dialogue: “What on earth does this mean?”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “It means that she has discovered Monsieur Lawrence does not dislike her as much as she thought,”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “But——”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “Here he is.”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Eh! Monsieur Lawrence,”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “We must congratulate you, is it not so?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “What is it, mon ami?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Nothing,”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “They are two delightful women!”
speaker: Arthur Hastings

dialogue: “And neither of them is for you?”
speaker: Hercule Poirot

dialogue: “Never mind. Console yourself, my friend. We may hunt together again, who knows? And then——”
speaker: Hercule Poirot
